column1: The advanced statistics course is about acquiring a robust understanding of advanced statistical methods and techniques for business analytics, in terms of both foundation and application. In addition, the course provides training in advanced programming skills, specifically using the statistical software R.
In particular, the following topics will be covered:

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The learning objectives of this course are:

column2: • Understand and apply the main statistical concepts required for advanced statistical data analysis, e.g., central limit theorem, least squares, maximum likelihood, bootstrapping, hypothesis testing, multivariate analysis, functional transformations, and limited dependent variables.

• Understand and apply the main building blocks of a programming language, e.g., data structures, flow control, environments. Solve non-trivial statistical problems using a programming language and environment, e.g., R and RStudio
• Demonstrate the ability to effectively communicate ideas, solution approaches, and findings to diverse stakeholders.
• Critically reflect on ethical ramifications of data collection, and proposed implementations of analytical findings.

column1: This course covers advanced topics in time series econometrics and forecasting, including:
The focus is on techniques that are found useful in applications to macroeconomic variables (such as output and inflation), and financial time series variables (asset returns and volatility).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Study state-of-the-art techniques in time series econometrics and forecasting.

• Learn how these can be useful in various macroeconomic and financial applications; with a focus on business cycle analysis and modeling and forecasting asset returns and their volatilities and correlations.
• Learn how to deal with issues, both theoretical and empirical, that an econometrician working in these areas faces.
• Gain experience with actually implementing the studies techniques, learning how to do model specification, parameter estimation and inference, specification testing, and forecasting.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107301,2022,Advanced Time Series Econometrics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. DJC van Dijk'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructors: Prof. H.P. Boswijk (UvA), Dr P. Gorgi (VU) and Prof. D.J. van Dijk (EUR)

The first part of this course covers nonlinear and non-Gaussian time series models, including models for discrete data with time-varying parameters and stochastic volatility models. We study estimation and inference methods, such as the extended Kalman filter and simulation-based methods.

The second part covers the formulation, estimation and testing of univariate and multivariate volatility models. We also discuss the use of high-frequency data in realized volatility measurement, and its use in volatility modelling.
The third part of the course covers non-linear regime-switching models, large-scale factor models, and forecast combination and evaluation.
For each topic, we discuss theoretical aspects of the models and methods. Real-data applications from economics and finance will show how the methods can be used in practice.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructors: Dr A.J. Hummel  (UvA) and Dr B.A. Bruegemann (VU)

The content of the course is adjusted annually to pick up new topics from the macroeconomic research frontier. Each class meeting (after the first) has two parts. In the first hour, students discuss a frontier paper with the aim of identifying the main contribution of the paper, determining if this paper is convincing, and coming up with an idea for further research on the topic. In the remainder of the class, one of the instructors gives a lecture introducing the topic of the frontier paper of the following week.

To ensure high quality discussions for the frontier papers, it is important that you have thought about the paper before the class meeting. To make the preparation more fun and to give you opportunities to learn from each other, we will do this using a team-based learning approach. In the first week of the course we will form teams of 2 students that will remain fixed for the duration of the course. Each team prepares a brief presentation about the paper, and submits it before the class meeting. At the beginning of each class meeting, one randomly selected team will use its presentation to lead the discussion using its presentation.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: 1. be exposed to hot topics picked from the research frontier in macroeconomics
2. practice their ability to identify promising research questions
3. understand content that combines recent papers from the research frontier with advanced material that bridges the gap between the first-year macro sequence and the research frontier
Knowledge and understanding: Students deepen their understanding of the topics covered in the course by reading and discussing recent papers.
Application of knowledge and understanding: Students should be able to identify promising research questions. Where necessary, novel tools that are required to understand papers will be introduced.
Making judgements: Students judge the contribution of the papers that are covered during the discussion lecture, and of the paper they select for the referee report.
Communication: Students practice their (oral and verbal) communication skills by (i) presenting papers from the research frontier and (ii) by writing a referee report.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course targets students with an active interest in behavioral research in management that seek to use insights from organizational behavior in their own research – regardless of whether this is in organizational behavior, strategic management, innovation management, behavioral operations management, or another area of behavioral research in management. Basic knowledge of behavioral research is therefore required, so the course can concentrate on advanced coverage of the state of the science.

On the basis of review/conceptual articles as well as exemplars of empirical research, the course covers a series of key themes in organizational behavior (e.g., teams, leadership, creativity & innovation, social networks). The format is a combination of short lectures and, interactive discussion  to develop an in-depth understanding of the current state of play in a series of subareas of organizational behavior. The bottom line aim of the sessions is to provide input for participants’ own research – the course should not only develop one’s knowledge of research in organizational behavior, but also lead to actionable knowledge that can be translated into the own research efforts.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: State of the science coverage of key themes in organizational behavior, with the emphasis on the possibilities to use this knowledge in the own research.

column1: Flow cytometry is used by many different applications from phenotypical characterization of cell sub-populations, analysis of phosphorylated proteins, cell proliferation, cell death to detection of very rare cell sub-populations. However, each of these methods has its challenges.
This course gives users with a solid knowledge in flow cytometry the opportunity to attend lectures covering many of these applications.
These lectures are given by experienced users and therefore not only give an introduction into these applications but also suggest protocols, discuss challenges and solutions.
Participants have the opportunity to discuss questions and, most importantly, have a contact person if they want to use an application for their own research.
Using Flow cytometry by many different applications.
Be sure to register at least one week prior to start of the course.
You will receive all details about the location the final program for the course one week prior to the start of the course.

column1: *The program may be subject to change.
Attendance – Attendance is mandatory for this course
This course includes mandatory attendance. It is necessary to meet the attendance requirement in order to pass: if you do not meet this requirement, you will not be awarded the course EC points.

Attendance is compulsory for the entire course, students may be absent for a maximum of 20% of the course. Attendance is registered during the online and live sessions of the course via Academy Attendance. Students should register their attendance on all course days of their courses.

The moderator will issue a code and the link of the Academy Attendance website during the course. Log in with your ERNA-ID (e.g., 123456AB@eur.nl) and ‘check in’ on your mobile device. The screen will instantly show whether registration has worked or not.
N.B. it is not possible to register attendance after class so make sure to ‘check in’.

Your evaluation is important to us, as it helps us improve the course in coming years. On the last day of the course, you will receive an e-mail with a link to the evaluation form. Note that your answers will be processed anonymously. You will have one week to submit the evaluation form.

Certificates-of-attendance will not be provided for PhD candidates and Research Master students. Other participants can e-mail the graduateschool@erasmusmc.nl to request a certificate after completing this course.

As an Erasmus MC PhD candidate, please ensure that the OSIRIS student number (the first six digits of the ERNA account) is registered in the Hora Finita account. This can be found under 'Research phase', 'TSP' tab, under the heading 'Education'. Please add the course using the course code to your Hora Finita portfolio. Once these two steps are completed the EC’s will be automatically transferred and approved.

Erasmus MC Graduate School charges a cancellation fee of €75 for all cancellations made more than 22 days before the start of the course. Fifty percent of the course fee, with a minimum of €75, is due for cancellations made between 21 and 10 days before the start date. The full course fee is due for cancellations made less than 10 days before the start date, or in case of no-show without cancellation. For Erasmus MC PhD candidates the full course fee in case of the cancellation policy will be the equivalent of the number of course days times €100. All invoices will be sent to the head of department or for external participants to the e-mail address provided upon registration. Those who register for a PhD course agree with these financial conditions.

column1: This elective contributes to the academic knowledge and skills of Master students by discussing the law and practice of cross-border trade and logistics from academic, business and regulatory perspectives. In total, twelve sessions of three hours cover a number of preparatory topics and topics that conclude and synthesize.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This elective course challenges the students to obtain knowledge, skills, and insights on the role of international regulations as well as legal aspects of cross-border supply chain management. The aim of the elective is to provide the student with enhanced knowledge and understanding on how customs and tax regimes interact with supply chain management and how public law, customs, FTA regulate and facilitate cross-border trade and logistics. The course offers a broader and more comprehensive perspective on the management of such cross-border supply-chains.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/108822,2022,Advanced valuation & value creation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['drs. HT Haanappel'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Understanding and analyzing business value is a key competitive advantage in decision making in M&A, private equity as well as fundamental for any other corporate investment decision. A sound business valuation requires, amongst others:

column2: • Analysis of the company, the competitive position and its strategy;
• Conduct historical financial and value creation analysis;
• A valuation method/approach that fits the valuation context and standard of value.

column1: In this course we discuss various (advanced) approaches to measure and analyze business value and value creation both from an academic and practitioners perspective. We will expand on the students basic theoretical knowledge on business valuation and value creation analysis and take this one step deeper. This course is highly relevant for students that pursue a career in M&A, private equity and/or valuation advisory.

Students should have followed an intermediate course in corporate finance and have a sound basis in financial reporting and financial statement analysis before taking this course. For those who have followed a prior valuation course, this course offers plenty of room and material to consolidate and deepen your skills and understanding of value creation and business valuation.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course provides a solid knowledge of the academic underpinnings for valuing companies and how to apply it in practice. On completion of this course, students should be able to:

column2: • Learn about different valuation methods and how they fit in a specific valuation context;
• Analyze a company’s strategy and business model from a value (creating) perspective;
• Measure value creation using different return metrics (a.o. RONIC, ROIC, CFROI and ROE);
• Understand the key value drivers of the business and how they can be used to forecast financial statements;
• Consolidate the basic DCF approach and to take this knowledge one level deeper(e.g. terminal value calculation, discounting conventions, debt and cash like items etc.);
• Understand the theoretical foundations of the WACC and learn best practices in estimating the WACC-parameters;
• Conduct valuation of companies with a changing capital structure using the APV- framework;
• Perform a market-based valuations using trading and transaction multiples and understand the drivers behind multiples;
• Understand residual income models and how they reconcile to DCF-valuation;
• Learn how valuation from a corporate perspective differs from the valuation from a private equity point of view;
• Conduct LBO analysis including the importance of financial leverage, buyout financing instruments, value enhancements during the holding period and monetizing on value creation in the exit;
• Tackle complex valuation issues such as: deferred taxes, provisions, leases,startups, financial distress, country risk etc.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/108842,2022,Advertising and Communication,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. B Van den Bergh'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Consumers encounter communications about brands anytime and anywhere. Marketing managers require useful frameworks to effectively communicate and advertise their products and services. This course discusses all aspects involved in designing effective marketing communications campaigns. The purpose of the course is to get introduced to the major topics in marketing communications and to further develop your communication skills through written projects, team-based work, and oral presentations.

The goal of this course is to help students set marketing communications objectives for a variety of products/services; understand and apply the principles that are necessary for persuasive advertising, from strategic principles (information, influence, emotion and mere exposure) to more specific tactics (resistance, acceptance, message, attention); generate, select and evaluate creative ideas for an advertising campaign; set a campaign budget and select appropriate media (still/motion) for a marketing communications campaign, taking into account strategic and tactical rules for implementation of the media plan; and propose/design an advertising campaign and discuss, present and defend the proposed campaign.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course students will be able to:

column2: • recognize, understand and explain the principles behind effective marketing communication
• analyze and evaluate existing marketing communications by identifying their strengths and weaknesses
• create and develop an effective marketing campaign

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106537,2022,Advertising, Gender and the Body",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. AMM Hermans'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Looking at Gillette’s (2019) controversial ad on toxic masculinity, Ariel India’s (2015-now) ‘share the load’ campaign, and beauty and fashion brands’ adoption of body positivity discourses, we can see that representations and constructions of gender and body (issues) in marketing have changed over the past decades. This course will consider the concept of gender as it is represented and/or constructed in marketing materials, particularly within the beauty market. Essential to this exploration, we will adopt a cross-cultural and intersectional approach as we examine the concepts of masculinities and femininities more widely, with a special focus on the body. As the body is pivotal in contemporary consumerist societies, an overview of the current conception of the body as malleable will be provided. In order to gain an understanding of advertising trends and themes, we will explore both the producers and content of current marketing materials.

As part of this course, students will have the opportunity to pitch and conduct their own research project related to the overarching focus of the course. This project will be qualitative in nature and will draw on insights from discourse analysis, thematic analysis and/or qualitative content analysis.
NOTE: This course will comprise six seminars instead of eight and students will hand in their final assignments on the 20th of December 2022

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: Dit practicum biedt studenten een eerste kennismaking met de praktijk van het schrijven van een beleidsadvies. Studenten zullen eerst leren over de betekenis van beleid voor jongeren en andere actoren in de stedelijke context. Vervolgens gaan studenten in een Rotterdams beleidsstuk over jeugdcriminaliteit op zoek naar de problemen die de gemeente wil aanpakken, de doelen die de gemeente nastreeft en de middelen die de gemeente inzet om de doelen te bereiken. Studenten leren de (soms impliciete) veronderstellingen in het beleidsstuk te analyseren en op basis van theoretische en empirische inzichten hier kritisch op te reflecteren.

column1: Aan het einde van het practicum zijn studenten in staat om:

2. Kritisch te reflecteren op voorgaande vier onderdelen aan de hand van de wetenschappelijke literatuur (eindtermen 8 en 12):

column2: • wetenschappelijke literatuur bij een specifieke vraagstelling te vinden;

• verbanden tussen bronnen te leggen, informatie uit verschillende bronnen te integreren, tegenstrijdigheden, ontbrekende informatie en inconsistenties te identificeren en bronnen kritisch te beschouwen.

column1: 3. Een inhoudelijke evaluatie van een beleidsstuk op het terrein van jeugdcriminaliteit en –deviantie te schrijven (eindtermen 13, 14, 15 en 19):

column2: • op een heldere en sluitende wijze schriftelijk te argumenteren in antwoord op een afgebakende vraagstelling;

column1: The list of skills necessary for working in any organisational environment is long. In this course, we will use the method of process consultation to pay attention to how people can advise. This will result in increased communication, advisory and coaching skills.

This course focuses on how students communicate and react to other people in different contexts. The course is designed to enable the students to build and develop their advisory skills and to increase knowledge of the concepts behind them, so as to widen the choice of possible actions in a given situation and to develop the understanding of the strengths and weakness of their advisory skills. By the end of the course we will have provided the students with an opportunity to learn about and practice by understanding and diagnosing contexts and give advice.

This elective is built up around lectures and workshops provided by the teacher and around 6-8 workshops (provided by the students). The sessions consist of experiential learning, theory, group exercises, and individual exercises and are provided by the lecturer, a consultant, or the teams themselves. During these sessions, we will explore various consultancy skills like questioning, analysing situations, problem sensing versus problem solution, relation building, handling intake process, teambuilding, et cetera.
The advisory skills course is all about skills; it is not something you can learn from a book. Therefore, the general rule is that you are present at all sessions.

column1: Particularly since the start of the 18th century, philosophers began to reflect on the question of art resulting in the emergence of ‘aesthetics’ as an  independent  philosophical discipline. This has resulted in the formation of various theories of and perspectives on the ‘nature’ of art – from the theory of mimesis to expression theories; from formalism to post-structuralism, and beyond. The emergence of these perspectives are linked with the role of art in society and culture, and influence the criteria under  which art is created, produced and consumed. In contemporary modernity questions on the status and legitimation of the arts are still pressing given the rise of theories about the post-postmodern, including metamodernism. In this course, various philosophers and their aesthetic theories will be discussed – e.g. Plato, Aristotle, Baudrillard, DantoHegel, Kant, Lyotard, and Nietzsche – as well as that their theories will be illustrated with reference to examples from art history. Amongst other examples, Nietzsche’s theory of the ‘tragic in art’ will be explained in the context of pre-war American blues music, and Hegel’s and Danto’s theory on the ‘end of art’ will be illustrated with examples ranging from contemporary (conceptual) art and pop culture, such as Duchamp’s urinal and Simon Reynolds’ retromania.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Students will be acquainted with theories and concepts from the field of aesthetics. Following a thematic and historical overview of aesthetic theory they will familiarize themselves with various philosophical perspectives on the question ‘What is art?’. Though the course focuses on Western aesthetic theory, students are encouraged to take a comparative perspective on the study of art, art history, aesthetics and the art world.</body>

column1: Fulltime students: every no show at tutorials after the first no show leads to a subtraction of a 1 point (out of ten) from your final mark.
-Obligatory weekly critical reading response as preparation for the lectures and tutorials
Plenary lecture: 1 x per week (2 hrs)
Tutorials: 1 x per week (debate on the basis of the critical reading responses, close-reading exercises, preparatory questions, 2 hrs).
For details, see course manual on Canvas.

This module offers an introduction to a diversity of philosophical perspectives on art. Besides the classical points of view of Plato, Aristoteles, Kant, and Hegel, we will focus on 20th century philosophers: Benjamin and the Frankfurt School, Jameson, Baudrillard, Lyotard, Derrida, and Rancière. Contrary to philosophy’s traditional derogatory treatment of art, these philosophers have elaborated a new complicity between art and philosophy. Instead of speaking about art, they have started a dialogue between art and philosophy that in some cases even culminates in an aestheticization of thought and a self-reflective turn towards the artificiality of philosophy. The course is organized around three thematic clusters: 1) art and truth; 2) Marxist cultural critique; 3) modernist philosophies of art.

column1: To acquire a global overview of the philosophical sub-discipline of Aesthetics, of its history and development, and of its contemporary relevance;
To acquire a limited but relevant toolbox for a critical attitude towards art and its changing socio-political significance;
To learn about various ways in which art and philosophy have come to interfere in the course of the 20<sup>th</sup> century.</body>

column1: For this course students are expected to already have a basic understanding of the bipolar and related disorders and depressive disorders, as well as classification of these disorders according to the DSM-5. The objectives of this course are the theoretical backgrounds, clinical presentation, treatment and differential diagnostics of these disorders in adults. A secondary objective is to study these aspects in children and young people. By the end of the course, which will be tested by means of an exam and course assignments, the student will be up to date on the most recent developments in affective disorders, as well as being able to independently study the relevant literature.

Lectures will primarily address the illnesses from a clinical perspective and these will be illustrated with video footage or imagery. Both the epidemiology and etiology will be discussed as well as psychopharmacology and psychological treatment, mainly focusing on CBT as well as there being an extensive focus on theoretical background.

There will also be an emphasis on modern models and the course will pay sufficient attention to neuroanatomy, neurobiology and psychological processes, e.g. information processing, memory, emotions and social interaction.

The course will be pay attention to the application of theoretical insights and guidelines in clinical situations. Students will work in teams on course assignments, which will be evaluated with a pass/fail qualification.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The overall objective for this course is to be able to define and describe affective disorders, classify the different affective disorders using DSM-5 and use this knowledge for diagnosis and treatment plans.
The specific aims of this course are as follows:
1. To have knowledge of the symptomatology and DSM-5 classification of affective disorders.
2. To have knowledge of the etiology of these disorders.
3. To have knowledge of the biological and psychological treatment of these disorders.
4. To be able to critically read and summarise scientific articles on these disorders.
5. The relate the above to pathology in children.

column1: De ontwikkeling van het kind vormt de basis van het werk van pedagogen. De vraag die daarbij vaak centraal staat is: “hoe zorg ik ervoor dat een kind zich zo optimaal mogelijk kan ontwikkelen?”. Volgens het ecologische model van Bronfenbrenner vindt de ontwikkeling van het kind plaats door interacties tussen (kenmerken van) het kind en diens omgeving. In het blok ‘Afstemming binnen opvoeding en onderwijs’ kijken we naar (de ontwikkeling van) het kind in context. Naast de interacties tussen kindkenmerken en omgevingsinvloeden, komt ook het samenspel tussen de verschillende omgevingen van het kind aan bod. We richten we ons vooral op de onmiddellijke omgeving waarin het kind zich begeeft (microsysteem), zoals het gezin, leeftijdsgenoten en de school. Theorie wordt afgewisseld met thema’s uit de praktijk (zoals passend onderwijs, gesloten residentiële jeugdzorg en pesten) om het belang aan te tonen van de ‘fit’ tussen kindkenmerken, opvoedingssituaties en onderwijs.

column1: <body>Aan het einde van dit blok zijn studenten in staat om:

column2: • het ecologische model van Bronfenbrenner te beschrijven en toe te passen op de verschillende onderwerpen uit het blok (eindterm 1);

• de invloed van kindkenmerken en proximale processen in belangrijke microsystemen (gezin, school en peers) en de relatie tussen microsystemen (mesoniveau) op de ontwikkeling van kinderen en jongeren te beschrijven (eindtermen 1 en 5);
• de ontwikkeling van kinderen en jongeren te beschrijven binnen maatschappelijke en culturele aspecten en veranderingen over tijd in de maatschappij (het macrosysteem) (eindterm 4);

• een wetenschappelijk onderbouwde mening te vormen over de afstemming tussen belangrijke microsystemen (zoals ouders en school) in het bijdragen aan een zo optimaal mogelijke ontwikkeling van het kind (eindtermen 3 en 14)

column1: Gedurende het afstudeerproject loopt een student stage bij een afdeling/organisatie die aansluit bij de inhoud van de opleiding. Dit kunnen diverse organisaties zijn, bijvoorbeeld een zorginstelling, overheid, zorgverzekeraar, consultancybureau of een onderzoeksinstelling.

Tijdens de stage werken studenten aan een voor de stage-instelling relevant vraagstuk. Studenten moeten de kennis en vaardigheden die zij hebben opgedaan in de eerdere jaren van de bachelor toepassen bij het analyseren van en/of adviseren over dit vraagstuk.
Naast de afstudeeropdracht heeft de stage ook als doel dat de student ervaring op kan doen in de toekomstige beroepspraktijk en kan werken aan persoonlijke en professionele ontwikkeling.

Tijdens de stage krijgt de student begeleiding vanuit zowel de stage-instelling als ESHPM. De begeleiding vanuit ESHPM is in de eerste plaats gericht op methodologische en inhoudelijke ondersteuning bij het afstudeerproject.
Daarnaast zullen intervisie en coaching bijeenkomsten worden georganiseerd om de studenten te helpen bij de persoonlijke en professionele ontwikkeling.
Van de stage-instelling wordt verwacht dat zij de dagelijkse begeleiding van de student op zich nemen en dat ze de student gelegenheid geven om mee te lopen in de organisatie.</body>

column3: De Master Beleid en Politiek dient afgerond te worden met een Masterscriptie, die wetenschappelijk verantwoord dient te zijn. Er dient sprake te zijn van het gebruik van wetenschappelijke literatuur, van de toepassing van wetenschappelijke bestuurskundige kennis en inzichten, het empirisch materiaal dient op een transparante en navolgbare te zijn geanalyseerd, en bovenal dient sprake te zijn van wetenschappelijke reflectie op theorie en praktijk. Verder dient de Masterscriptie aan de gebruikelijke vereisten te voldoen, zoals een heldere en systematische opbouw (inleiding met probleemstelling, werkwijze, theoretisch kader, empirische analyse, resultaten, conclusie, reflectie) duidelijke vormgeving, correcte bronvermelding e.d. (zie Handleiding Masterscriptie). De docenten van de Master geven tevoren hun onderwerpen van expertise en belangstelling aan (zie tabblad afstudeerdocenten). Daaruit kunnen studenten kiezen. Het staat studenten overigens vrij om zelf met onderwerpen te komen. Studenten kunnen eventueel gezamenlijk een Masterscriptie schrijven. Daarbij gaat het dan wel om een groepje van twee personen. De individuele bijdrage moet echter wel herkenbaar en toetsbaar zijn, aangezien de eindbeoordeling individueel plaats vindt. Gedurende het afstudeertraject worden afspraken gemaakt over de te volgen werkwijze, de fasen in het project, deadlines en op te leveren deelproducten in het afstudeertraject. Student en docent stellen daartoe een 'contract' op met rechten en plichten voor beide partijen.

In het afstudeertraject zijn methodische seminars voorzien die gezamenlijk door alle studenten van de Master verplicht worden gevolgd. Aan de hand van concrete voorbeelden van bestaande onderzoeken zullen de studenten in groepsverband getraind worden in het doen van onderzoek. Daarbij zal het accent vooral komen te liggen op a) het werken met een probleemstelling, c) het werken met een conceptueel model, c) op het operationaliseren en meetbaar maken van centrale begrippen en d) het formuleren van wetenschappelijk gefundeerde en praktisch bruikbare aanbevelingen.

Omdat studenten een verplichte stage moeten lopen, is het raadzaam om in het eerste blok een stageplek te verwerven. In blokken drie en/of vier dient er een stage gelopen te worden en tegelijkertijd gewerkt te worden aan de scriptie. In het vierde blok wordt de Masterscriptie afgerond. Aan het begin van onderwijsblok 3 dient een definitieve opzet van de afstudeerscriptie gemaakt te worden. Iedere student beschrijft op één A4 de eerste globale opzet van de scriptie:

column4: <li>

column5: aanleiding en doelstelling voor het afstudeer onderzoek;

column4: <li>

column5: probleemstelling, nader onderverdeeld in deelvragen;

column4: <li>

column5: opzet en wijze van aanpak, onderzoeksmethode;

column4: <li>

column5: theoretische invalshoek, literatuur;

column4: <li>

column5: empirische analyse, informatieverzameling;

column4: <li>

column5: concept hoofdstuk indeling.

column3: Studenten worden in blok 3 aan de hand van hun voorstel ingedeeld in scriptiekringen die worden begeleid door een docent van de opleiding bestuurskunde. Een kring bestaat doorgaans uit 3 tot 5 personen. Meestal gaat het om scripties die een zekere verwantschap met elkaar hebben. Deze kringen komen periodiek bij elkaar. In de kring worden de vorderingen tot dan toe besproken, waarbij studenten over en weer verplicht elkaars stukken lezen en daarop ook commentaar leveren. De bedoeling is dat op deze manier leerkringen ontstaan, waar studenten elkaars ervaringen en problemen met elkaar kunnen delen. Doorgaans gaat het om ervaringen waarmee een ieder tegelijkertijd wordt geconfronteerd. Deelname aan de scriptiekringen, het tijdig uitwisselen van elkaar stukken en actieve deelname zijn verplicht.</body>

column1: Na afloop van deze module kan de student:
• zelfstandig een relevante probleemstelling formuleren voor een praktijkgericht wetenschappelijk onderzoek;
• zelfstandig wetenschappelijke literatuur gebruiken om empirisch materiaal op een verantwoorde wijze te analyseren;
• zelfstandig een methodologische verantwoording geven van de keuzes in het onderzoek;
• verschillende empirische bevindingen koppelen aan theoretische concepten;
• zelfstandig (een) wetenschappelijk gefundeerde conclusie(s) formuleren in aansluiting op de vraagstelling;
• zelfstandig aanbevelingen formuleren op basis van empirische bevindingen en theoretische aspecten;
• persoonlijke reflectie geven ten aanzien van het eigen onderzoek;
• zelfstandig een onderzoeksrapportage schriftelijk presenteren volgens wetenschappelijke standaarden.

B Vermeeren', 'dr. L Vandenbussche, MSc', 'dr. NJL Cannaerts', 'dr. VMF Homburg', 'dr.ir. J Eshuis', 'prof.dr. AJ Steijn', 'prof.dr. L den Dulk', 'T Janssen, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De Master Management van HR en Verandering wordt afgerond met een master thesis. In deze thesis laat de student zien in staat te zijn een bestuurskundige probleemstelling op academisch niveau te kunnen uitwerken en onderzoeken. De thesis of scriptie is dan ook van wetenschappelijk niveau en wordt zodanig verantwoord. Dit betekent dat wetenschappelijke literatuur wordt verwerkt, wetenschappelijke bestuurskundige kennis en inzichten worden toegepast, empirisch materiaal op verantwoorde wijze wordt verzameld en geanalyseerd en reflectie plaatsvindt op de bestuurskundige theorie en praktijk. Verder dient de Master thesis aan de gebruikelijke vereisten te voldoen, zoals een heldere en systematische opbouw (zie Handleiding Masterscriptie).

De onderwerpkeuze wordt getoetst aan de bestuurskundige relevantie waar het het studiegebied van management van HR en verandering betreft. Studenten kiezen een thema, gekoppeld aan een afstudeerkring en afstudeerbegeleider. Tijdens het verloop van het afstudeeronderzoek zullen groepjes studenten rond een gekozen thema in de afstudeerkring regelmatig met de afstudeerbegeleider bijeenkomen om de onderzoeksvoortgang en tussentijdse producten met elkaar te bespreken en verder te ontwikkelen. Gedurende het afstudeertraject worden tussen de student en de begeleidend docent afspraken gemaakt over de te volgen werkwijze, de fasen in het project, deadlines en op te leveren deelproducten in het afstudeertraject.

Aanvullend op het afstudeertraject worden de verplichte seminars van het Atelier MHVR en de seminars over methoden en technieken gevolgd (zie hiervoor de desbetreffende studiegidstekst). De seminars over methoden en technieken volgen daarbij in de tijd de opbouw van het afstudeeronderzoek zodat het afstudeertraject zo veel als mogelijk wordt ondersteund. Het afstudeertraject omvat tevens een stage (zie hiervoor opnieuw de desbetreffende studiegidstekst). De verwerving van een stageplaats vindt hoofdzakelijk in het tweede blok plaats. Ook hierbij is het Atelier ondersteunend. Studenten lopen stage in blok 3 en blok 4 en werken gelijktijdig aan de scriptie.</body>

• zelfstandig een methodologische verantwoording geven van de keuzes in het onderzoek;

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Met een masterthesis (scriptie) wordt de studie afgerond. De thesis vormt het bewijs van vakbekwaamheid bij het integreren van kennis. De student toont aan in staat te zijn een bestuurskundige probleemstelling op academisch niveau te kunnen onderzoeken en daarover op een heldere wijze te rapporteren.

De masterthesis dient wetenschappelijk verantwoord te zijn. Ofschoon organisatieontwerp of -advies wel onderwerp van afstuderen kan zijn, is kritiekloos toepassen van een bestaand 'model' niet voldoende. Er dient sprake te zijn van het gebruik van wetenschappelijke literatuur, van de toepassing van wetenschappelijke bestuurskundige kennis en inzichten, het empirisch materiaal dient verantwoord te zijn geanalyseerd, en bovenal dient sprake te zijn van wetenschappelijke reflectie op theorie en praktijk.

In de eerste helft van het jaar worden probleemstelling, opzet en werkwijze gereed gemaakt. Vervolgens wordt gewerkt aan de definitieve opzet van de thesis en vindt bestudering van relevante theoretische literatuur plaats. In het derde blok vindt, gekoppeld aan de stage, de verzameling van empirisch materiaal plaats. In het vierde blok volgt de analyse en wordt de masterthesis afgerond.

Het afstudeertraject wordt in seminars ondersteund. Deze seminars zijn opgenomen in het atelierprogramma. Het afstudeertraject heeft een omvang van 15 ECTS, ongeveer drie maanden werktijd en sluit zo goed mogelijk aan op de stage (10 ECTS), die kan worden gebruikt voor de verzameling van empirisch materiaal. Studenten die stage en scriptie combineren - wat meestal zo is - zijn gemiddeld 4-6 maanden bezig met het afstudeertraject. In het atelier zal aan het begin van blok 2 aandacht worden besteed aan het zoeken van een stageplaats en aan de eisen die er aan een stageplaats moeten worden gesteld.

Studenten schrijven in principe individueel een masterthesis. Er worden afstudeerkringen gevormd van meerdere studenten die verwante afstudeerprojecten doen. Elke afstudeerkring wordt begeleid door een docent.</mystyle></body>

column1: This course offers a comprehensive introduction to the global airline industry and a rigorous economic analysis of airline competition and pricing, the role of airports and the international regulatory environment. We follow the developments in the industry since its worldwide deregulation and liberalization and examine the perspectives of its many stakeholders, in particular, airlines, airports, passengers and governments. We use concepts from industrial organization economics and micro theory in order to describe how these players have contributed to the evolution of competition in the airline industry. By reviewing older and recent developments, such as changing airline business models and the growth of emerging airlines and airports, students are challenged to think creatively about the future and the implications for the evolution of competition in the airline industry.
The following topics will be adressed in the course:

column2: • Competition models and the economics of entry and exit
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand the economic theory of competition in concentrated markets and be able to apply it the context of the airline industry
• Evaluate empirical findings of the industrial organization literature from the airline industry
• Gain insight in the economics of the airline industry from a practical perspective
• Gain in depth knowledge of developments in passenger and cargo transport from a historical perspective

column1: De leerinhoud van het vak is onderverdeeld in drie thema’s:

De uitgaven aan gezondheidszorg worden in Nederland grotendeels betaald uit verplichte premies en belastingen, dat wel zeggen collectief gefinancierd. Een grote meerderheid van de Nederlanders is namelijk bereid mee te betalen aan het zorggebruik van anderen (solidariteit). Door de omvangrijke collectieve financiering van de zorguitgaven bestaat er een sterk verband tussen de overheidsfinanciën en de gezondheidszorg. Om de overheidsfinanciën ‘gezond’ te houden proberen beleidsmakers in Den Haag de groei van de collectief gefinancierde zorguitgaven te beheersen. Hierdoor is sprake van schaarste in de gezondheidszorg.

Bij de organisatie van gezondheidszorg wordt in Nederland in toenemende mate gebruikgemaakt van marktprikkels. Dit betekent dat voor de afstemming van vraag en aanbod van zorg niet langer wordt vertrouwd op gedetailleerde aanbod- en prijsregulering door de overheid. In plaats daarvan speelt onderlinge concurrentie een steeds belangrijkere rol. Zorgaanbieders hebben aanzienlijke vrijheden gekregen en dienen nu veel meer dan in het verleden te wedijveren om de gunst van patiënten en zorginkopers. Deze marktwerking is een middel om te komen tot betere zorg tegen de juiste prijs. De zorg is echter geen gewone markt, maar een markt met bijzondere tekortkomingen waardoor marktwerking zonder regulering niet tot optimale uitkomsten leidt. Dit wordt marktfalen genoemd en is reden voor de overheid om in te grijpen in de zorg. Helaas geldt dat strakke regulering van de gezondheidszorg geen wondermiddel is. De overheid kan namelijk ook falen. Veel beleidsdiscussies gaan dan ook over de vraag welke rol is weggelegd voor de markt en welke rol de overheid moet spelen.

In vergelijking met andere landen is er in Nederland nauwelijks een financiële belemmering voor toegang tot gezondheidszorg. Nederlanders zijn namelijk goed verzekerd voor zorgkosten. Bovendien is er een breed gedragen streven naar risicosolidariteit. Dit betekent dat gezonde mensen met lage zorgkosten net zo veel premie betalen als zieke mensen met hoge zorgkosten. Maar om dit te realiseren én in stand te houden is ook, op verschillende manieren, overheidsingrijpen noodzakelijk.
<body>Na afloop van dit vak kun je:

column2: • de collectieve financiering van de gezondheidszorg alsmede de oorzaken en gevolgen van de stijgende uitgaven aan gezondheidszorg vanuit economisch perspectief uitleggen;
• de oorzaken en gevolgen van marktfalen op zorgverleningsmarkten, de zorgverzekeringsmarkt en op zorginkoopmarkten met behulp van inzichten vanuit de algemene economische wetenschap analyseren; en
• vanuit economisch perspectief uitleggen welk overheidsingrijpen noodzakelijk is voor het goed functioneren van markten in de gezondheidszorg.

column1: Sayings such as “To know your present you must know your past” abound. This is true for the field of accounting as well. As an example, the European Artificial Intelligence (AI) Act (2021), the Digital Markets Act and the Digital Services Act (2022) raised the issue of auditing AI systems. Can the task of auditing financial statements inform the audit of AI systems? Understanding the historical developments of financial auditing and its extension to other fields such as environmental auditing could give us hints as to how the auditing profession might develop to audit the new technologies contained in the term AI.

Fundamentally, this course aims to prepare the modern accountant. It does so by giving students a sound foundation into the historical developments of the five main sub-domains of accounting (i.e., financial reporting, auditing, financial statement analysis, management accounting and accounting information systems), while exploring how each of the five sub-domains are affected by technological innovations and algorithms. In order to achieve its fundamental purpose, the course requires students to read influential and critical accounting papers and discuss them, and link fundamental accounting developments with the innovations introduced by algorithms.

Because the course is essentially about algorithms and the models used or produced by algorithms, the workshops focus on building algorithms using the standard approach of tidy modeling with R (Kuhn and Silge) and communicating about algorithms, models and results in a reproducible way via R markdown documents (Xie, Allaire and Grolemund).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After following this course, students should be able to:

column2: • Critically discuss major historical developments in the five main sub-domains of accounting (i.e., financial reporting, auditing, financial statement analysis, management accounting and accounting information systems)
• Identify how the five main sub-domains of accounting are affected by innovations introduced by algorithms
• Link foundational knowledge in accounting with innovations introduced by algorithms
• Use a standard approach to build and communicate about algorithms

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: “Bad” algorithms abound and can lead to lost revenue, discrimination, disinformation, or even bodily harm. New European regulations on Artificial Intelligence force organizations to control the risks introduced by algorithms. But how can one be in control when it comes to algorithms?

The role of algorithms in organizations is twofold: on the one hand algorithms are used to control organizations, yet on the other hand algorithms themselves need to be controlled by organizations. This elective considers both perspectives. Firstly, to achieve their organizational goals, that is, to “be in control”, organizations use information from algorithms. To understand the use of algorithms for control purposes, this course will zoom in on control areas where information from algorithms is used such as personnel selection, performance management, and feedback and reporting. Secondly, to be in control, organizations also require information about algorithms. To understand how organizations aim to gain control over algorithms, this course will zoom in on risk areas of algorithms such as bias, opacity, and lack of accountability.
In terms of hands-on application, this course will focus on a domain where mitigating the unintended consequences of algorithms has received a lot of attention: text classification.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After following this course, students should be able to:

column2: • Discuss the concept of control and its overlap with the domain of algorithms
• Explain how organizations use algorithms for control purposes (e.g., in control areas such as personnel selection, performance measurement, feedback and reporting)
• Use text analysis methods, in general, and to investigate risk areas of algorithms
• Critically evaluate algorithms in order to gain control over algorithms
• Communicate information according to Minto’s pyramid principle
• Use discussion frameworks as a mean of communication and knowledge sharing

column1: For creating a well-diversified portfolio that could sustain financial turmoil, it is important to have knowledge not only about investments in traditional markets (stocks and bonds) but also in markets of other asset classes (i.e. the pros and cons of alternative investment categories such as hedge funds, real estate, commodities and private equity). The aim of this course is to provide students with more detailed knowledge of investment possibilities outside the traditional markets for stocks and bonds.

This online course is set up to be academically rigorous while practical insights from investment professionals ensure the critical link with the investment world. The course begins with an overview of basic knowledge related to investments in financial markets, e.g. the return and risk characteristics of investment strategies, the Efficient Market Hypothesis, and asset pricing models (e.g. the Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM)). Second, we will discuss several alternative investments e.g. hedge funds, real estate, commodities and private equity.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course, students should be able to:

column2: • Understand and explain the theories underlying traditional investments (in stocks and bonds) and a range of alternative investments (e.g. hedge funds, real estate, commodities, and private equity).
• Understand and determine the return and risk characteristics and the trade-off of traditional investments and a range of alternative investments.
• Create portfolios consisting of traditional and/or alternative investments and to determine their performance.
• Determine whether and which (traditional and/or alternative) investments add value to an existing portfolio.
• Use Excel to construct, calculate and evaluate the performance of portfolios consisting of traditional and/or alternative investments.
• Understand and summarize academic articles published in top finance journals.

column1: <body>Cultural analysis is an approach to the study of culture through its objects. In this course you will be introduced to some of the fundamental methods and concepts of cultural object analysis. You will learn how to find and select meaningful objects for cultural analysis, and explore different approaches to studying the meaning and significance of cultural objects their role within and relationship to the cultural context(s) in which they circulate, as well as how people make or have made sense of these objects. Positioned somewhere between textual analysis and cultural studies, cultural analysis is fundamentally and by necessity interdisciplinary, and uses as its tools concepts that have often travelled across disciplinary boundaries. During this course you will engage with theories and concepts that you may recognize from literary analysis, visual analysis, art history, discourse analysis, gender and postcolonial studies, and media studies. In this course you will learn how to operationalize these theories and concepts into a methodology for the analysis of cultural objects as a critical, reflexive, and situated research praxis.</body>

column1: People generally attach great importance to their health and would name it as one of the key aspects for a happy life. Nonetheless, many people do not adhere to a healthy lifestyle and therefore seem to behave in conflict with their own life goals. Smoking, physical inactivity, rejecting vaccination and screening or not adhering to physicians’ recommendations are popular examples. This raises the question as to how we can change behaviour and improve health and wellbeing. This is a question of concern to individuals, schools, companies and governments, and is the central question in this minor. The past decades have seen many different approaches as to how behaviour change can potentially be realised. Traditionally in many fields, but economics especially, individuals are seen as ‘rational decision-makers’, i.e. they know what they want, and make reasoned choices to achieve their goal of a better health and happiness. In this view, policies or interventions to promote behaviour change are only necessary when individuals are misinformed or choice is limited.
In particular, two issues arise that are the focus of this minor:

column2: • The approach to behaviour and what incentivizes behaviour change employed in traditional economics often times does not apply successfully to health, as for most people health is very different from most other commodities. Questions of how to approach issues in health are the domain of health economics, which is one of the core components of this minor.

• We all know that often people do not behave rationally when it concerns their own health and wellbeing. Understanding such non-rational behaviour requires insights from for example psychology and sociology, which are both central to behavioural economics – the second core component of this minor.

column1: You will be introduced to the key concepts from behavioural and health economics, with examples related to health and healthcare. We will apply these concepts to i) understand health behaviour, both rational and non-rational, and ii) explore what this means for individuals, organisations and governments aiming to promote healthier behaviour (e.g., through nudging, boosting, incentives and regulation). Using these insights, you will select an actual health issue of your interest (e.g., excessive drinking, smartphone use in traffic), design an intervention, and reflect on it critically.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Explain the traditional economic approach to rational choice, and discuss the merits and limitations of this approach for understanding and changing behaviour.
• Explain why behavioural and health economics exist as separate disciplines, and discuss how they differ from traditional economics.
• Give examples of heuristics and biases in intertemporal choice, risky choice, and social choice that violate traditional assumptions about rationality.

• Apply these behavioural insights to understand and analyse health behaviour, in at least three settings: lifestyle choice, patient and physician decision-making, and preferences for health and wellbeing.

• Differentiate between, provide arguments for and against, and give examples of appropriate applications in health for the following four common (policy) interventions: a) nudging, b) boosting, c) (financial) incentives, d) regulation.
• Apply insights from behavioural and health economics to develop and evaluate an intervention aimed at promoting health and/or wellbeing.
• Discuss challenges to promoting health and wellbeing for individuals, organisations and governments, such as cost-effectiveness and ethical considerations.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106272,2022,Analytics in Accounting & Financial Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. CD Peter', 'prof.dr. E Peek']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course ‘Analytics in Accounting & Financial Management’ introduces students to analytical methods that support the creation and communication of business-relevant knowledge from accounting and financial management data. Accounting and financial management specialists inside and outside the firm use data analytics in various tasks. Examples of such tasks are forecasting sales, uncollectible accounts, and cash flows to support budgeting and planning decisions; journal entry validation to support data accuracy analysis and fraud detection; and investment selection using big data and scenario modeling. This course familiarizes students with essential analytical tools in accounting and financial management. It covers the following areas:

column2: • Data management. Creating knowledge from data requires identifying and managing decision-relevant data. The course brings students hands-on experience with relational database management systems (SQL), eXtensible Business Reporting Language (XBRL) data, and R procedures for collecting, cleaning, and structuring data.
• Data visualization. Students learn to create data visualizations and dashboards that help evaluate data quality, communicate insights, and support informed decision-making.

• Analysis of structured financial data. Students learn to understand and apply descriptive analytics (e.g., identifying red flags in accounting data), diagnostic analytics (e.g., understanding cost variances), and predictive analytics (e.g., in financial forecasting, budgeting, and reporting) using the above tools and supervised machine learning techniques (such as regression, k-nearest neighbor classification, and decision trees).

• Analysis of textual data. Students learn to understand and apply various approaches in textual data analysis, helping them capitalize on the increasing availability of textual data relevant to accounting and financial decisions.

column1: The course consists of (1) lectures that focus on theory and illustrations and (2) workshops that focus on skills development, with an emphasis on data analytics using R.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After following this course, students should be able to:

column2: • Use relational databases and eXtensible Business Reporting Language (XBRL) data.
• Create data visualizations that support decision-making in accounting and financial management.
• Evaluate supervised machine learning techniques, including (logistic) regression, k-nearest neighbor classification, and decision trees.
• Apply descriptive, diagnostic, and predictive analytics in various accounting and financial management contexts.
• Apply R programming skills to analyze, visualize, and communicate accounting, financial, and textual data.
• Create a strategy and plan to address a problem in accounting and financial management using data analytics and communicate the findings.

column1: Consumers use various technologies in their everyday life, such as mobile applications, internet browsers, social networks, and wearables. In doing so, consumers leave a digital footprint - a stream of data that describes their online activities. Sometimes, they explicitly share content with other people (e.g. social networks, forums) or have direct communication with a company (e.g. online customer service). Data that consumers intentionally submit online is defined as active digital footprint. At the same time, consumers also leave a passive digital footprint: their search history, the news they read online, the location and time when they use a device. Both active and passive digital footprints can reveal consumer attitudes, interests, and preferences. This brings numerous opportunities and challenges for companies, consumers, and public policy makers.

This course is suitable for students with a solid understanding of fundamental programming principles who want to learn advanced scientific computing practices (e.g., collecting data using APIs, version control systems). As a core component of the course assessment, students will work through the steps of a data science research project (e.g., study design, data collection, data processing, data analysis). The lectures and workshops will cover data collection and data processing with R and RStudio. It is assumed that students already have an in-depth understanding of study design and data analysis, from previous courses in the BAM program. If you are unsure about the level of your R programming experience, please contact the lecturer before signing up for this class.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students who actively participate in all sessions and successfully complete their assignments will be able to:

column2: • Implement advanced methods to collect digital footprints.
• Adopt advanced scientific computing practices in their data collection and analysis workflow.
• Recognize legal and ethical aspects that impact how companies collect and use digital footprints.
• Provide managerial and policy recommendations supported by empirical results and theoretical insights from studying the literature.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course gives an introduction to the application of econometric techniques to problems in business and management. Focus will be upon the implementation of the linear regression model with non-experimental data. Attention will be paid to estimation, hypothesis testing, specification analysis, misspecification, interpretation, causality, model choice, autocorrelation, heteroskedasticity, and robust inference. A large number of illustrations will be covered and students are expected to complete a small empirical research project. The course will conclude with a short introduction to alternative estimation techniques, like instrumental variables and maximum likelihood.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>In the course Applied Econometrics you will be introduced to the linear model in econometrics, including OLS, GLS and IV estimation. Towards the end of the course you should be able:

column2: • to interpret and evaluate estimation results, including adequacy of employed estimators and test procedures;
• to judge the appropriateness of certain assumptions (homoscedasticity, linearity, parameter constancy), and to test them statistically;
• to perform your own empirical study, including model building and selection, misspecification testing, and economic interpretation and forecasting.

column1: Game theory is a mathematical tool, which provides a unified analytical structure for studying all situations of conflict and cooperation. It is viewed as one of the outstanding intellectual advances of the last decades (as exemplified by several Nobel Prizes). Game theory intersects with many disciplines. This course will introduce the basic ideas of game theory and apply them to the strategic settings in different fields including economics, business, political science, history, international relations, and evolutionary biology.

A setting is strategic when it is characterised by interdependence, i.e. in order to choose the best action a person needs to consider how others around him decide on their actions. A strategy, the core concept in this course, is fundamental to social interaction. Throughout the course we will incrementally introduce game theoretic concepts in order (i) to understand how individuals actually behave in strategic situations and how strategic forces influence final outcomes (positivist approach), and (ii) to be able to say something about how they should be advised to behave (normative approach).  This course includes topics from non-cooperative, cooperative, and evolutionary game theory.
The aim of this course is three-fold:

column2: • Master the game-theoretic way of thinking;
• Practice the logic of a game-theoretic argument by applying it to examples in different disciplines;
• Be able to improve upon multi-person strategic situations.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The aim of this course is three-fold:
1. Master the game theoretic way of thinking;
2. Practice the logic of a game-theoretic argument by applying it to examples in different disciplines;
3. Be able to improve upon multi-person strategic situations.
​To be more precise, by the end of the course you will be able to:
- Represent strategic situations in a game-theoretic form by distinguishing different elements of the game;

- Solve for the equilibrium of the game by appropriately applying different solution concepts (Nash equilibrium, mixed strategy Nash equilibrium, sub-game perfect equilibrium, Bayesian Nash equilibrium, Perfect Bayesian Nash equilibrium, Shapley value, Core);
- Evaluate equilibrium results from the efficiency perspective;
- Formulate suggestions regarding how to improve inefficient outcomes.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Machine learning (ML) is nowadays at the crux of the business model for most consulting firms and many modern entrepreneurial ventures. Its applications in the business world span a wide range of areas that go beyond simple forecasting exercises. The purpose of this course is to equip the students with the overall knowledge needed to professionally link between a consulting client and the technical data analysts. The course aims to be non-technical, with minimum math knowledge or programming experience and is targeted for students seeking a career in strategy consulting, project management, or strategic entrepreneurship. Nonetheless, students will also be coached to broadly apply some ML techniques themselves and generate strategic analytics and forecasts efficiently. The course content includes

column2: • Introduction to Machine Learning (including a comparison to legacy data analytic methods)
• The different types of ML algorithms and their typical applications
• Introduction to the topics and questions in consulting that could leverage machine learning
• How ML is applied and deployed strategically in different areas of business (i.e.  Supply chain, HR, customer experience, finance and retail) and what to expect in the future.
• The steps often taken between the project proposition by a client and the final analysis delivered by the consulting company, and how they fit within the context of change management.
• How ventures leverage Machine Learning to get ahead of the competition, and how consulting ventures apply ML differently to outcompete incumbent consulting firms

• The common deliveries and results following a machine learning analysis (i.e. importance plots, partial dependence plots, confusion matrices, etc.), and the approach to present the results in a meaningful way for a (non-technical) business audience.

• Guest lectures from prominent entrepreneurial and consulting firms that provide ML solutions in the business world on what they seek when recruiting non-technical strategy consultants and project managers, what the new recruits’ mission entails, and the type of work and projects they engage in.

column1: The course will also include a practice part in which students will be familiarized with the different techniques used by data analysts when conducting ML so they can actively engage in machine learning “speak” when necessary. These techniques include:

column2: • Techniques for choosing the space of tuning parameters and cross-validation.
• Techniques for optimizing run-time through parallelization, reducing the dimension of the data, and estimating total run-time.
• Techniques for aggregating predictions across multiple ML algorithms, and also across different datasets to boost prediction power.

• Techniques to overcome the common pitfalls when preparing data for machine learning, including normalizing variables with extreme outliers, retaining the original information in the data even after normalization, and structuring the ML code, etc.
• Techniques to present the results in a meaningful way for a (non-technical) managerial audience

column1: During coding practice, the ML algorithms we will cover are mainly Decision trees, Random forests, Random ferns, Gradient Boosting (i.e. XGboost), and Neural Networks (NN).
Much of the code for these algorithms and the above techniques will be provided for the students, so they can focus on the application side of ML, which would require minimal coding.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course the students should be able to:

column2: • Identify business problems and questions that require machine learning solutions
• Recognize the potential ML solutions and techniques for different (client) problems.
• Recognize and implement the best practices for ML coding and inform the client on realistic estimates of the ML solution’s run-time and the expected delivery date of the solution.
• Report both on the ML approach needed for solving the problem, and also present the results and draw meaningful conclusions for a non-technical audience.
• Interlink between technical and non-technical agents (i.e. data analysts vs clients), and coherently communicate ML problems and solutions between the two.

column1: <body>This course focuses on both qualitative and quantitative research methods. Students will need to apply research methods in the research workshops and, of course, in their MA thesis project. In addition, they need to be able to assess the quality of studies carried out by others. This course will familiarize them with a number of essential concepts and approaches in empirical research. We start out exploring the logical links between research questions, sampling, and choosing the best method to answer your question. General notions such as inductive and deductive research shall be introduced and linked to choices to be made during the research process. After this introduction, several research methods will be introduced. Regarding qualitative research, the emphasis will be on different types of interviews (semi-structured in-depth interview, narrative interview, active interviewing) and how to analyze these systematically. Quantitative research will also be addressed by familiarizing students with the statistical program SPSS, with a focus on assessing relations between (sets of) variables and reflecting on causality.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Having completed this course, students should be able to:

column2: • Understand which sampling methods best fit which research questions
• Understand research ethics and their impact on doing empirical research
• Distinguish between different methods of qualitative research, most notably different types of interviewing and when to apply these
• Understand and carry out descriptive statistics and assess (causal and non-causal) relations between dependent and independent variables

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course provides students with knowledge of econometric methods which are relevant for applied economics. In particular, it first refreshes the essentials of the standard regression model. It then covers methods that can be useful when the dependent variable of interest is endogenous: instrumental variables and linear panel data models. Finally, the last part of the course covers methods for binary outcomes.

Students follow a hands-on approach to understanding empirical econometric methods, in this way getting the opportunity to develop experience with the application of these methods in their own field of specialization.

The course consists of online materials, question hours and group practical work. The lecturers present and discuss each method and relevant applications in online videos. For each part of the course: i) a first set of videos introduce the empirical methods; ii) in a second set of videos, the lecturers explain how to implement the methods in Stata, with special focus on the interpretation of the results. Students put into practice the acquired skills through group assignments which are practical empirical applications with real world datasets.
1. Linear regression models (linear regression; conditions for causality; specification tests, model selection).
2. Endogeneity and instrumental variables estimation (causality, identifying and dealing with endogeneity)
3. Linear panel data models (random effects models; fixed effects models; difference-in-differences).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The main aim of this course is to become acquainted with econometric methods relevant for applied economics and their application. More specifically, after the course the students should be able to:
• Apply the main econometric methods that are suited to analyze cross-section, panel data and binary outcomes data;
• Explain the advantages and disadvantages of each method;
• Understand the assumptions and limitations of each method and empirical application;
• Use the statistical software Stata to analyze datasets that are relevant for their specialization.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: We have introduced two relatively small changes in the structure of the course: i) Structure of the exercise lecture to introduce students to Stata and start working on the example assignment; ii) a small change in the discussion session on papers using panel data methods (part of assignment 2).
These two changes were partly driven by feedback from students.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
