column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course consists of two parts: personnel economics and public economics.

column2: • The first part of the course focuses on incentives and workers' motivation inside organisations. The role of monetary and non-monetary incentives in motivating, selecting, and attracting workers to organisations is studied. Topics include the effects of pay-for-performance on motivating and selecting workers, optimal hiring and firing policies, education, team-work, promotion tournaments, and benefits.

• The second part of the course focuses on the functioning of markets in case of public goods, externalities, and asymmetric information, and the role of the government in reducing the inefficiencies that arise when markets do not function perfectly. This includes distributional questions, and a discussion of the limits of government intervention. The normative analysis of government intervention is pared to a positive analysis of collective decision-making.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand how economic theory can be used to study how organizations can attract, select, and motivate employees.
• Understand how economic theory can be used to study the functioning of markets in case of market failures, and the effects of government intervention on efficiency and distribution.

• Apply concepts and techniques taught in the first-year Microeconomics course and the Mathematics courses to analyze the effects of proposed responses to problems faced by decision-makers in the public sector as well as in organizations more generally.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104870,2022,Applied Multivariate Data Analysis,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. BR Bocanegra', 'dr. O Lindemann', 'MHM de Moor']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: This course is meant as a preparation for the research you will have to do for your Master’s thesis. You will refresh old knowledge and gain new knowledge concerning the most common univariate and multivariate statistical techniques. In addition, this course will teach you ways to analyse complicated research designs with multiple variables, and evaluate the use of these techniques in actual research.

The course builds on the statistics you learned during courses 1.3, 2.2 and 2.8/3.5. The techniques that you will learn during this course are generalizations of these familiar techniques. The techniques discussed in this course are multiple regression, Moderation and Mediation, ANOVA, ANCOVA, repeated measures ANOVA, and mixed ANOVA. These techniques all stem from the general linear model (GLM).

column3: The emphasis is on being able to apply these techniques based on research questions such as:

- “Is a new treatment method more effective than treatment as usual in reducing anxiety problems among depressed older people? And is this effect still visible a year after completion of the treatment?” Or:
- “What aspects of internal control are effective predictors of counterproductive behaviour at work?”

Each technique will first be studied extensively in a lecture, after which the student will gain more insight into the techniques by working on data-analysis assignments that will be discussed during the tutorial group meetings.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: The objective of this course is to consolidate and expand your knowledge and understanding of several (univariate and multivariate) data analysis techniques that are common in the field of psychological research.
The emphasis is on the application of the techniques in actual research and the interpretation of results.

column3: After taking this course you should be able to choose the appropriate data analysis technique given the research question, perform the analysis in SPSS, check the assumptions, interpret the results, and report them in accordance with the APA norms. Furthermore, you should be able to read research articles more critically.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Applied Statistics 1 introduces exploratory statistics, probability theory and explanatory statistics.
Topics include statistical measures and graphics for the exploration of a single variable and relations between two variables, inlcuding linear regression.
In addition, probability theory is treated (together with Bayes theorem) and distributions of random variables, such as the Poisson distribution that is important in the analysis of queuing problems.
Other topics are the estimation of the mean and hypothesis testing of the mean with known and unknown standard deviation.
In addition, hypothesis testing for variances and differences in proportions are treated. Some of the exercises make use of SPSS.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Acquire knowledge of basic statistical methods and techniques.
• Develop a critical appreciation of quantitative thinking in a business and economics setting.
• Develop an ability to apply basic statistical methodology. In particular, being able to perform basic hypothesis testing procedures.
• Develop an ability to meaningfully interpret statistical findings in a business and economics setting.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/105075,2022,Applied Statistics 2,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. C Cavicchia'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course follows on the course on descriptive statistics in Applied Statistics 1 (FEB11005) and prepares the ground for active scientific research in later courses (Methods and Techniques FEB12012, Research Project FEB12013, in seminar and thesis projects, and later in jobs requiring skills in doing and interpreting applied research).

The course treats statistical models and methods that are often applied in economics. The right method depends on the research question of interest and on the nature of the available data. The main topics are the following: testing, contingency tables, ANOVA, non-parametric tests, regression (simple and multiple, time series).
During the tutorials, exercises are solved and discussed, and tutorial points can be earned. In addition, students gain experience in applying statistics by means of software.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students acquire knowledge of basic statistical methods for estimation and testing, as well as their practical application in economics and business.
• Students gain experience in using statistical data and methods in order to test scientific hypotheses and to support decision making.
• Students acquire practical skills in using the statistical software package SPSS to perform applied data analysis.
• Students are prepared for performing their own research, i.e., they learn to formulate formal hypotheses and to choose the appropriate statistical technique for answering research questions.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: De cursus Arabisch voor beginners 1+2 is een dubbele cursus: aan het eind van het traject is de stof van twee cursusniveaus behandeld. De cursus bestaat uit 20 lessen van 2,5 uur. Voordeel is dat je tussendoor geen examen hoeft te doen. Je stroomt dus automatisch door van niveau beginners 1 naar niveau beginners 2.
Wat leer je tijdens de cursus Arabisch beginners 1+2?

Tijdens deze cursus leer je de beginselen van de Arabische taal, waarbij de nadruk ligt op de vaardigheden lezen, luisteren, schrijven en spreken in een alledaagse context. Onderwerpen die aan bod komen zijn bijvoorbeeld:

bescheiden woordenschat zodat je in veelvoorkomende en alledaagse situaties kunt communiceren. Het eindniveau van de cursus is beginners 2, vergelijkbaar met het A1.2 niveau van het Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Het Language & Training Centre organiseert eenmaal per jaar cursussen Arabisch in de periode januari-juni.
• Deze cursus is toegankelijk voor cursisten met een academische achtergrond (hbo/wo).
• De steuntaal van deze cursus is Engels. In de lessen wordt echter zoveel mogelijk Arabisch gesproken.
• Het cursusmateriaal kost ± € 45,- en is niet bij de cursusprijs inbegrepen. In de bevestigingsbrief die je ontvangt als de cursus doorgaat, informeren we je over de details.
• Van de deelnemers wordt verwacht dat zij naast de wekelijkse contacturen ongeveer drie uur per week aan zelfstudie besteden.
• De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 12 en maximaal 16 voor lessen op de campus en 15 voor online lessen. Bij minder dan 12 inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.

• Aanwezigheid bij de lessen is niet verplicht, wel raadzaam. Tijdens de laatste les vindt er een mondelinge toets en een luistertoets plaats. Om voor de cursus te kunnen slagen, dien je aanwezig te zijn.
• De cursus wordt afgesloten met een schriftelijk examen. Met dyslexie kun je extra tijd krijgen voor dit examen. Vergeet niet om je dyslexieverklaring met je verzoek naar ltc@eur.nl te sturen.
• Je ontvangt een certificaat als je de cursus afsluit met een 5,5 of hoger.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/108223,2022,Argumentation and Rhetoric in the Public Sphere,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. AG Fokkema'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

When listening to a UN peace intervention speech or reading an Op-ed piece attacking the exploits of an oil company in Nigeria, you often have a hunch about how well (or how misleadingly) this act of public discourse is construed. When scrolling down that Op-ed piece to see the audiences’ reactions, you equally have a gut feeling about the validity of those reactions. This course helps you to establish a solid backing for these intuitions, enabling a sophisticated critical qualitative content analysis of argumentation in the public sphere. But it will do more.

Argumentation is used in persuasive communication, such as in the examples above. Far more interestingly though, argumentation structures are also used in any communicative act of decision making, whether these be on private matters or regarding commercial transactions, health care, or political issues. This is where “real-life” argumentation as part of human communication comes into play. This course seeks to raise an awareness exactly of these processes of decision making and will stimulate students to analyze and monitor such processes in both their own and the public sphere, paying specific attention to cultural and national idiosyncrasies and differences. To this end, students will first read and think about the building blocks of argumentation. They will be constantly encouraged to match these elementals to real life situations. Analyzing argumentation therefore is no end in itself but serves to grasp the potential of decision making.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The role and use of argumentative and rhetorical strategies in communication in the public sphere;

column1: Student have developed the skills to:

column2: • Conduct a critical content analysis of argumentative and rhetorical strategies in communication in the public sphere;

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This course will explore questions in the philosophy of science and discuss them in relation to examples from all areas of management science. These topics include:

column2: • How do we decide what is scientific and what is not? How can we demarcate science from other activities?
• What makes science hard? What are the problems of induction and underdetermination, and how can they be addressed?
• What are the goals of science? What are concepts of causality? What counts as a good explanation? When are models successful?
• How can we evaluate science? What are the notions of scientific revolutions, paradigms and research programmes? Can science be objective and value-free?

column1: Each session includes a lecture part that introduces key concepts in philosophy of science, and a seminar part in which the readings as well as examples from all areas of management science are discussed.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: A good piece of academic writing gives support for its conclusions. Academic writing is thus argumentative writing: we write to persuade.

column2: • review some of the principles of good argumentation from Module 1.1, and
• evaluate and develop the argumentative writing of your draft papers.
• Is it clear what precisely you want to convince the reader of?
• What is the support you offer for your conclusions?
• Is it easy for the reader to reconstruct your argument (for instance, in a diagram)?
• How can you write more simply and directly?
• How can you improve your writing process?

column1: We will also do a lot of actual writing, and complete different practical writing exercises that will allow you to advance your paper drafts.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: How people consume arts and culture, how they make meaning in and through their engagement with art and how taste formations and patterns of cultural consumption remake social inequality remain critical issues in sociology. Moreover, for the cultural industries, questions of how to develop and expand art audiences, how to explore and cultivate novel forms of cultural participation and how to address structural inequalities in the sector present timely and important concerns. In this course, we will therefore become familiarised with and critically reflect upon some of the key debates and theories that focus on the nexus between art, taste, cultural participation, social identities, and inequality. In particular, students will become acquainted with how art and cultural consumption – both offline and online – have been theorised in relationship to subjectivity formations, the self and the negotiation of wider social, political and spatial identities, as well as with regards to the reproduction of classed, raced and gendered inequalities. We will develop an interdisciplinary approach to analyse the multifaceted ways in which people consume and engage with culture, how they make meaning in and through their participation with art and how people’s tastes and consumption practices tie in with wider social and economic institutions, structures and hierarchies. To that end, this research-led course brings into conversation seminal scholarship in sociology, cultural studies and media studies with contemporary research on and examples of arts and cultural production, and drawn from different national and genre contexts.

Rather than merely focusing on one particular topic or theoretical perspective in the study of arts and cultural participation, this course will shed light on a variety of different yet partly interconnected themes, concerns and theoretical approaches. We will start by outlining some general concerns in the sociology of arts and culture today, before zooming more closely into questions of cultural participation and the importance and role of the audience. In this connection, we will explore how audiences are not passive recipients of art but actively take part in the cultural circuit of production, dissemination and consumption. Following on from this, we will discuss in more detail how arts and culture present meaningful sites of social and political identity formation, both locally and transnationally, online and offline. We will also analyse how people’s specific cultural tastes and consumption practices can become vectors of classed, gendered and raced boundary-drawing and hence contributors in the remaking of social hierarchies and inequality. Lastly, we will think about different spaces of cultural consumption and explore the ambivalent and contested role of cultural policy for questions of audience development and cultural participation with a special emphasis on ‘diversity’ in the arts discourses.

By encouraging students to carefully think through these different topics and apply different theoretical vantage points to the study of art audiences and cultural participation, the course moreover seeks to support students in developing independent research and writing skills which will help them, amongst others, with their Master theses.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Students will develop a critical understanding of core debates and new developments in the sociology of arts and culture with a focus on art engagement, taste, cultural participation and consumption.
• Students will learn to apply different theoretical perspectives to the analysis of contemporary trends and dynamics in the cultural and creative industries.

• Students will learn how to examine a range of cultural and media texts including film, music, art, TV, and digital media, and become familiarised with a variety of (qualitative) methodological approaches.

• Students will learn to present and discuss their analyses in class and in small groups, developing the skills to communicate ideas effectively, both verbally and in writing, and work both autonomously and in dialogue with others.

column1: The aim of this course is to provide non-arts students an introduction to the traditional narrative of the history of Western (-European) art and culture, from the late Middle Ages onwards. In this course, the students will be introduced to the visual arts, architecture, literature and philosophy from the late Middle Ages  onwards. Students will gain insight into how the various disciplines are interrelated.

Each lecture will cover a particular period – Renaissance, Baroque, etc. – for which we will discuss some of the masterpieces that were produced during that era, and place them in their context. In eight lectures, we will travel through Western (-European) art history, and the students will learn to analyze, identify, contextualize, and discuss works of art. The ultimate goal of this course is to present an interesting introduction to the history of Western (-European) art and culture that students will remember.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Knowledge of – and insight into – the most relevant developments and trends in the field of the history of Western (-European) art and culture, from the Late Middle Ages to the present
• Knowledge of – and insight into – the major concepts and features for each of the discussed periods in the history of Western (-European) art and culture.
• Knowledge of – and insight into – the different movements (both in terms of style and culture in general) and the most important artists and art works, from the Late Middle Ages onwards.
• Enumerate important movements in the history of Western (-European) art and culture accompanied by their main characteristics and examples.

column1: Learning objectives in terms of academic skill set:

column2: • Being able to reflect critically on the historical development of Western (-European) art and culture, from the Late Middle Ages onwards.
• Comprehend and being able to translate literature into a coherent written argument, while using correct academic references.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Who can decide who can be rightfully called an artist? Why do so many people aspire an artistic career when the probability of making it is so small? What are social circumstances that spur innovation in the arts and cultural industries? How do certain social groups try to acquire status through the consumption of established art forms? And how do various groups differ with regards to the meaning they attribute to art and popular culture? Throughout this course, we will try to formulate an answer to these questions by taking a sociological perspective on the production, distribution and reception of the arts and (popular) culture. Art and culture are therefore not considered to be the products of individual geniuses, but as a social construction in which, in addition to artists, also the public, the government, the media and education are involved.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course provides an introduction to the sociology of culture and the arts as a scientific discipline. The goal is to familiarize students with the social character of the production, distribution and appreciation of art and cultural products by applying relevant theoretical sociological concepts and approaches to the practice of the sectors of the arts and culture.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Artificlal Intelligence is widely recognised as a technology that will disrupt and transform the way we do things in many walks of life. In view of the potential development, its impact on processes and actions will very likely transform professional behavior in the private and public sector and increasingly also the ways in which we develop scientific research. A reduction of these consequences of new technology to the field of techno science is pointless, where we already see the debate evolving into the entire academic and professional landscape. In Erasmus University Rotterdam’s teaching and research this development has led to an increase in attention to AI across the board, dispersed over the various schools and curricula. As part of a strategic impulse that allows student from every school the benefit of the accumalation of new insights this minor on the topic of AI is on offer.

The debate in the European context is very much focussed on trustworthy human centered AI, which broadens the perspective from the pure engineering of good AI to a holistic approach that embraces the ethical, legal, social, economic an cultural aspects (ELSEC) of this technological change. Moreover, Erasmus University Rotterdam is very strong in medical and social sciences and humanities disciplines which determines its student population. Consequently, to serve the wide variety of students with the contemporary developments around AI inevitably leads to the multidisciplinary approach of the topic as reflected in the (sub)title. Students need to be confronted with the ELSEC aspects, in order to make the connection with their major field of study, and with the diversity of disciplines that study the effects of AI introduction into research and professional practices. That multidisciplinary character of the teaching is not limited to the fields present in the EUR curricula, but comprises the technological side of AI; to the level that can reasonably be attainable for SSH bachelor students. For the computer science discipline, the ambition is therefore to bring student insight into what type of perceptions of reality define computation, some of the process behind this and what is the specific nature of AI in the field of computation. Where concrete and active skills in mathematics cannot be presupposed, a familiarity with model thinking is the best way to learn about how IT engineers work.

Students will be confronted with the variety of disciplinary perspectives on AI by activating lectures, exposure to the basic building blocks of AI development, and self-study materials, whereby all participants will be brought outside their regular comfort zone of disciplinary experience. This learning process will be continued and reinforced by the groupwork that is embedded in the program of the minor. The groups will by definition show a multi-disciplinary composition. The students will be coached particularly in the discovery of unfamiliar perspectives and the final assessment product will be scored on the level of discipline combination/integration. Student will be expected to reach a foundational level of insight into the benefits and risks of AI deployment in areas within their field of study, but also basic level of insight into the benefits and risks in other areas.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Conceptual - Students conceptualize basic knowledge about AI principles

column2: • ILO 1 Define the basic principles of AI (in the context of society)
• ILO 2 Illustrate the basic principles of AI through the use of conceptual models
• ILO 3 Understand the modular development and learning processes prominent in current AI development

column1: Multi-disciplinary - Students compare and contrast knowledge surrounding AI in society through a multi-disciplinary lens

column2: • ILO 4 Identify and describe the opportunities and challenges when AI is developed and deployed (in society) from at least 2-3 disciplinary perspectives.

column1: Disciplinary - Students deepen their disciplinary understanding of AI’s implication, threats and opportunities

column2: • ILO 5 Critique the role of AI in students’ own disciplinary field

column1: ILO 6 Create a representation (in any form) to illustrate disciplinary knowledge integration

column1: <body>What counts as “fair” and “dignified” labor as global work becomes increasingly automated? What does a “compassionate” and “inclusive” Artificial Intelligence (AI) driven system of healthcare, welfare or education system look like? Do cultural values matter as tech companies outsource platform moderation and design governance for their consumers around the world? Whose morality counts in embedding these values in design? These are just some of the contemporary and urgent questions we face as nations find themselves competing in the AI arms race. The field of artificial intelligence (AI) and ethics has exponentially grown in the last decade with rising and contested discourses on the responsibilities and impacts of innovations such as automation, deep learning, and predictive analytics in our everyday lives. This course critically examines diverse and context specific design approaches to our social systems and institutions and invites students to reimagine alternative paradigms that align with values such as sustainability, democracy, inclusiveness, and equity for an ethical global future. Students deconstruct normative notions and universalisms related to technological innovation such as privacy, trust, transparency, and smart design. These efforts are essential if we are to design ethical media systems and regulatory bodies and policies for the wellbeing of a global public.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The concepts and contemporary debates on AI and Ethics and the impact of technological design on diverse contexts and cultures;
• Analyze global technological developments and their relation to global values of equity, sustainability and resilience, and democratic governance
• Compare/ contrast different design initiatives and reimagine alternatives that can stimulate inclusive and responsible design systems
• Apply design thinking to novel problems shaped by innovations like AI, automation, and the internet of things (IoT)

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104618,2022,Artificial Intelligence: The Present and Future of Work,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. W van Zoonen', 'RA Morgan, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course we will consider what happens if artificial intelligence (AI) is used in the workplace to (attempt to) 'augment' or even 'replace' people. These questions are becoming increasingly urgent as employers increasingly experiment or implement data-driven technologies and machine learning. In practice, we see a variety of developments around work. In some sectors, for instance in financial services, tasks can be increasingly automated. Yet, new types of work are also emerging with AI, such as cloudwork.

In this course you will learn how you can contribute to debates and practical dilemmas about AI and work from different social science perspectives. Starting from the idea that technologies never act alone, but depend on social institutions and relations, we will discuss the consequences for different aspects of the work context. Examples of topics are: the practical and ethical dilemmas facing professionals such as surgeons or judges, the effects of national policies, the reproduction of existing inequalities, and underlying notions of ‘intelligence’ that shape technologies. We also turn the debate around: what do developments around AI tell us about the role of work in our lives?

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Analyse AI-enabled technologies as situated, socio-technical systems
• Interpret AI-enabled automation in the context of labour relations and policies
• Assess the ethical consequences of AI for professionals
• Assess the consequences of AI-enabled automation for work organisations and professional fields
• Develop recommendations for addressing practical issues regarding the application of AI in organisations

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107172,2022,Arts Education,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. CJM van Eijck'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Arts education is an important institutionalized way to familiarize people with the arts. School, governments and cultural institutions invest in this for very different reasons. Arts education early in life could make it more likely that pupils will evolve into members of the audience for the arts. It might also be beneficial for cognitive or emotional development to be engaged with the arts. In an even more instrumental way, arts education may be initiated with the goal of creating external effects, such as getting higher grades in maths or creating a more caring school climate. This course will look at the different ways in which the arts have been taught inside and outside of schools, what the aims have been, and to what extent claims regarding the impact of engagement with the arts can be substantiated. For that purpose, different approaches to arts education will be addressed, ranging from approaches that focus mainly on teaching art history to approaches that prefer to stimluate spontaneous expression through the arts. Students will evaluate their own experiences with arts education and develop a plan for an arts course based on the literature and examples discussed in class</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course will familiarize students with a number of central concepts and insights with regard to arts education as it takes place both within shools and in cultural institutions. We will discuss the goals that arts education sets for itself, the methods by which the arts are taught, and the potential impact of arts education on people’s cognition and well-being

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106330,2022,Arts, Culture, and Media",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['D Ribeiro Povoa', 'DR Geveke, MA', 'EW Vermunt', 'I Vitola', 'MF Rodriguez Rodriguez']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The media fulfil a key role in the realm of arts and culture. A multitude of agents (e.g. cultural producers, artists, marketing managers, critics, consumers) are involved in the communication about arts and culture, and all have their own goals and strategies. In this course, we review the relationship between arts, culture and the media by focusing on: the media industry, its strategies, its working practices and conventions, as well as new business models to sell and distribute arts and cultural products in the internet era; the media users, who actively engage with and create artistic and cultural content, from active audiences to media fans; the technologies that enable the arts and culture to circulate via the media, from the printed press to Web 2.0, and how these changing technologies and increasing digitization shape our connection to the arts and culture; and the media content that circulates, reflecting on how it relates to social reality, delving into questions of ideologies and representation of diversity in media content. Throughout, the course offers a comprehensive account of classic and contemporary theories and research on media and culture. Moreover, the course also focuses on the role of the media in cultural legitimation, addressing the changing role that gatekeepers and media critics play in this respect. We conclude the course by bringing all these elements together and reflecting on how cultural globalization and digitization change the level playing field in artistic and cultural production and consumption.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course, students have knowledge and understanding of:
A.       Key theories on the media and its role in society
B.       Key concepts in media production, content and reception
C.       Role of media in cultural legitimation, discourse, fandom
D.       Influences shaping media content (incl. diversity, digitization, globalization, sustainable development)
At the end of this course, students have developed the ability and/or propensity to:
F.        Analyse issues in the field of arts, culture and the media
H.       Critically reflect on own media use
I.        Communicate knowledge in oral/written form</body>

column1: What is the impact of a cultural organisation? Does it create societal impact? If so, how much? What would have occurred if the organisation would not have existed, and what would occur if the organisation would cease to exist? Those questions can be addressed by impact assessment, which is useful not only because it provides insight in the scope and size of an organisation’s impact, but also because it offers the opportunity to learn and to navigate the organisation. All organisations have an impact on society. This impact can include both intended and unintended effects, which in turn can be either positive or negative. Organisations are increasingly being held responsible for these effects.

The present course entails a scientifically-grounded approach to impact assessment, with a focus on arts, culture, and creativity. In line with the new Strategy 2024 of the Erasmus University (‘Creating Positive Societal Impact’), the course provides students with the knowledge, skills, tools and experience for conducting a social impact assessment in the cultural sector, in close collaboration with cultural organisations and with the involvement of experts.

The course is developed by means of a collaboration between the Erasmus School for History, Culture and Communication (https://www.eur.nl/en/eshcc/), and the Impact Centre Erasmus (https://www.eur.nl/ice/).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The course prepares students for the cultural labour market by giving them a deep understanding of the roles that organisations can play in society and equip them with the tools to effectively assess these roles, in a close dialogue with people working in the field. It teaches students how to conduct a social impact study: Students learn how to develop and validate a theory of change for a cultural organisation and how to develop a measurement plan; they will collect and analyse the data needed for the impact assessment of a cultural organisation; they will present and report their results.</body>

column1: In this course, theoretical perspectives on assessment and its impact on learning will be discussed. In the first part of the course, the concept of “testing as a tool for learning” will be presented in relation to how this can facilitate student/employee learning. Assessment can be a powerful device in aiding learners in their learning process and facilitating learning outcomes. Concepts such as self-regulated learning and formative assessment will be specifically discussed. Additionally, data-driven teaching and adaptive training will be explored in order to present teachers/trainers with evidence-based tools for curriculum development.

In the high-stakes testing culture, which is characterized by large incentives for good performance and negative consequences for poor performance, people often experience anxiety and perform more poorly on exams than expected given their skill level. The second project of this course is about strategies to optimize test performance. These strategies will focus on characteristics of the learner/testee, the teacher, the learning/test task, and the test environment.

Assessment in education and training needs to be accurate to make valid instruments that can be used for future learning and development of students or employees. However, assessments are prone to preconceived or unreasoned opinions or feelings, also called biases. Bias in self-assessments, peer assessments, teacher or trainer assessments, or in testing in general, endanger the accuracy of assessment. In the third part of the course you will learn about different types of bias in assessment and testing, and what can be done to reduce or prevent them.

Peer assessment can be an important educational tool for both teachers and students. Teachers can use peer assessment to reduce their workload and students can use it to enhance their learning. In the fourth project of this course, you will learn about peer-assessment, identifying effective forms of peer assessment, the underlying cognitive mechanisms, necessary conditions, and characteristics of effective peer feedback.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Students will be able to identify the role testing/assessment has in the regulation of the learning process and apply the concept of testing as a tool for learning in order to facilitate student/employee learning.

• Students will be able to apply knowledge about methods to improve learning outcomes (test performance) by managing characteristics of the learner/testee, the teacher, the learning/test task, and the test environment.

• Students will be able to identify biases in self-assessment, peer assessment, teacher/trainer assessments and testing in general as well as critique tests and testing practices in order to reduce or prevent biases.

• Students will be able to apply knowledge about effective forms of peer assessment, its underlying mechanisms, necessary conditions for peer assessment, and characteristics of effective peer feedback.

column1: The aim of this course is to provide a profound and state-of-the-art insight into asset pricing, both from a theoretical and empirical perspective. The field of asset pricing aims to explain the prices of financial assets such as stocks, fixed income instruments and derivative securities. The field is highly relevant for financial management, because asset pricing models form the basis for many practical management applications such as capital budgeting, risk management, portfolio selection and performance evaluation. During this course, you will be introduced to the key insights from 50 years of theoretical, empirical and methodological research. The course consists of two parts. One part focuses on the theory of asset pricing in the unifying framework of stochastic discount factors. The other part concentrates on testing asset pricing models and covers both empirical and methodological issues.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• •    You learn about the derivation, implications and testing of the CAPM.
•    You learn what factor models are and the role they play in asset pricing.
•    You learn how to test factor models.
•    You learn about firm and asset characteristics, cross-sectional anomalies, and how they are related to asset pricing models.
•    You learn about the utility-based approach to asset pricing.
•    You learn about the market-based approach to asset pricing.
•    You learn about machine learning techniques in asset pricing.
•    You learn how to design research in asset pricing.

column1: nstructors: Prof. R.J.A. Laeven (UvA), Prof. M.H. Vellekoop (UvA)

This course provides an introductory yet comprehensive and rigorous treatment of modern asset pricing theory. Asset pricing is concerned with determining the value of an uncertain future payoff. Equivalently, it is concerned with explaining (variation in) expected returns on risky assets. It covers the following topics:
1. Expected utility, risk aversion and single period portfolio choice;
4. Stochastic discount factors and the Fundamental Theorem of Asset Pricing;
5. Dynamic programming and pricing in incomplete markets;

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Financial statements are an important source of information for stakeholders like shareholders, creditors, employees, the general public etc., to value their prospective claims. Over time, accounting scandals like Enron, Worldcom, AIG and Lehman Brothers have indicated that managers have incentives to use their discretion to affect financial reporting in order to serve their own benefits. Thus, to reassure stakeholders and restore and strengthen their confidence in financial statements, regulators require firms to have their financial statements assured by third parties, namely auditors or certified public accountants (CPAs). CPAs are the equivalent to Dutch Register Accountants (RAs).
This course addresses the function and relevance of auditors in more detail and considers the decisions and dilemmas that auditors are faced with as part of their job.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:

column2: • Explain the demand for audit and other assurance services, the organization of the CPA profession and the types of services they provide;
• Evaluate the audit responsibilities and objectives, the ethical and independence responsibilities, and legal liability of CPAs;
• Assess audit risk and a company’s internal controls;
• Perform tests of controls, substantive tests of transactions, substantive analytical procedures, and tests of details of balances;
• Describe the completion phase of the audit;
• Formulate an audit opinion for a given audit situation;
• Develop in teams multiple viewpoints on specific auditing cases and scientific articles.;
• Conduct a presentation of a scientific article.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104791,2022,Atelier Governance en Management van Complexe Systemen,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. MJ Nederhand', 'dr. WAH Spekkink']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Het Atelier bestaat uit een drietal sporen:

column2: • Design Atelier: Studenten gaan aan de slag met een ontwerpopdracht van een externe praktijkopdrachtgever. Onder begeleiding van een docent managen de studenten de samenwerking met de opdrachtgever en andere betrokkenen, van het eerste overleg over de vraag van de opdrachtgever tot het opleveren van het advies en zorgen dat dit wordt ingebed in de beleidspraktijk. De opdrachtgevende organisatie speelt een belangrijke rol in de aansturing en de beoordeling van de ontwerpopdracht. Studenten nemen kennis van het ontwerpgericht denken en leren de verschillende stappen en activiteiten die in een bestuurskundig ontwerpproces toegepast kunnen worden. Aan de hand van een concrete casus die door een praktijkorganisatie is ingebracht, passen ze deze ontwerpbenadering toe en werken ze toe naar een praktisch bruikbaar ontwerp (voor bijvoorbeeld een proces, een beleidsinstrument of een sturingsaanpak) dat past bij de vraag van de opdrachtgever.

• Workshops met professionals: We organiseren, gedurende het jaar, workshops met professionals uit de praktijk die in hun werk met complexe bestuurlijke vraagstukken te maken krijgen. Met hen wordt stilgestaan bij de professionele vaardigheden die de bestuurskundige professional moet hebben, met name als het aankomt op het opereren in complexe maatschappelijke en politiek-bestuurlijke contexten. De exacte opzet kan per workshop verschillen, maar het uitgangspunt is dat de studenten na een interactieve presentatie van de gastspreker aan de slag gaan met een opdracht (tijdens de workshop) waarvan ze het eindresultaat aan de gastspreker zullen presenteren.
• Methodenseminars: Gedurende het stage- en scriptietraject worden er, als onderdeel van het Atelier, ook methodenseminars aangeboden ter ondersteuning van het uitvoeren van het scriptieonderzoek.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Na afloop van de module kan de student:

column2: • Relevante ontwerpmethoden en -technieken identificeren en selecteren om deze in een concrete casus toe te passen.
• Middels deze ontwerpbenadering een gefundeerd en bruikbaar ontwerp ontwikkelen.
• Op professionele wijze werken in opdracht van een opdrachtgever.
• Bewust op eigen rol, positie, assumpties en inbreng in het ontwerpproces reflecteren.
• Constructieve feedback geven aan anderen ten behoeve van het ontwerpproces.
• Theoretische inzichten uit de literatuur over complexiteit gebruiken om ideeën voor oplossingen aan te dragen voor problemen in de bestuurskundige praktijk.
• Reflecteren op de meerwaarde van de eigen opgedane kennis en competenties voor het toekomstige werkveld.

In het atelier introductie bestuurskunde wordt de student vertrouwd gemaakt met de beoefening van de bestuurswetenschappen. In werkgroepverband komen diverse onderwerpen aan de orde, waarop in het latere verloop van de opleiding verdere verdieping plaatsvindt. Door het kleinschalige karakter en de op samenwerking gerichte werkwijze wordt gestimuleerd dat de studenten zich snel thuis voelen aan de universiteit. Tevens krijgen zij een beeld voorgeschoteld van de analytische houding die in een academische omgeving van hen verwacht wordt. De werkvormen bestaan voornamelijk uit discussies en schrijfopdrachten. Inhoudelijk wordt aangesloten bij de vakken Inleiding Beleid en Inleiding Management (van de minor Beleid en Management in de Publieke Sector). Onderwerpen uit deze vakken worden toegepast op de praktijk, waarbij zoveel mogelijk aansluiting met de actualiteit wordt gezocht.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Na afloop van de module Atelier Introductie Bestuurskunde is de student in staat om:

column2: • Het wetenschapsobject van de bestuurskunde te benoemen;
• Zelfstandig en in groepen werkzaamheden op academisch niveau in werkgroepverband uit te voeren;
• De basisbegrippen van de bestuurskunde te reproduceren;
• Op academisch niveau te argumenteren, te presenteren en te refereren.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Het Atelier Management van HR en Verandering (MHRV) bestaat uit twee fasen. In een eerste fase staan kennisontwikkeling en toepassing alsook het ontwikkelen van praktijkvaardigheden centraal. Meer concreet wordt in deze eerste fase van het atelier (blok 1 en 2) de nadruk gelegd op verdieping van de theoretische vakken van MHRV en de praktische toepassing hiervan via werkbezoeken, een stagemarkt en een ontwerpopdracht. Aan de hand van een concrete ontwerpopdracht worden vaardigheden geoefend en competenties ontwikkeld en op de proef gesteld die een publiek manager met een MHRV achtergrond in de organisatiepraktijk nodig heeft. Hierbij moet gedacht worden aan (persoonlijke) presentatie- en adviesvaardigheden. Studenten nemen kennis van het ontwerpgericht denken en leren de verschillende stappen en activiteiten die in een bestuurskundig ontwerpproces toegepast worden. Aan de hand van een concrete casus die door een praktijkorganisatie is ingebracht, passen ze deze ontwerpbenadering toe en werken ze toe naar een praktisch bruikbaar ontwerp (voor bijvoorbeeld een veranderinterventie, een beleidsinstrument of een samenwerkingsarrangement) dat past bij de vraag van de opdrachtgever. De opdrachtgevende organisatie speelt een belangrijke rol in de aansturing en de beoordeling van de ontwerpopdracht.

In de tweede fase (blok 3 en 4) ligt de nadruk op onderzoeksmethodologie en worden de opgedane kennis en vaardigheden in de praktijk gebracht in de stage en het verder opzetten en uitvoeren van het eigen afstudeeronderzoek. Studenten kiezen daarvoor een thema, gekoppeld aan een afstudeerkring en afstudeerbegeleider. Tijdens het verloop van de stage en het afstudeeronderzoek zullen groepjes studenten rond het gekozen thema in de afstudeerkring regelmatig met de afstudeerbegeleider bijeenkomen om de onderzoeksvoortgang en tussentijdse producten met elkaar te bespreken en verder te ontwikkelen. Daarnaast volgen de studenten enkele M&T seminars die aansluiten bij het eigen afstudeeronderzoek. De stage en het afstudeeronderzoek worden afgerond met een masterthesis en de verdediging hiervan.</body>

column1: <body>Na afloop van het atelier kan de student:

column2: • Beargumenteren hoe inhoudelijk de diverse vakken van MHRV onderling samenhangen;
• De bestuurskundige ontwerpbenadering in een concrete MHRV casus toepassen;

• In opdracht van een publieke opdrachtgever deze ontwerpbenadering toepassen en met behulp van deze ontwerpbenadering een gefundeerd en bruikbaar ontwerp voor een concreet MHRV vraagstuk ontwikkelen;
• Dit ontwerp overtuigend presenteren en reflecteren op de kwaliteit en toepasbaarheid ervan;
• In teamverband en in cocreatie met stakeholders het proces van probleemdefinitie tot toetsing van een mogelijke oplossing doorlopen;
• Op basis van verworven kennis en kunde zelfstandig aan de thesis werken.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104777,2022,Atelier Publiek Management,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. M van der Steen', 'prof.dr. MJW van Twist']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In het Atelier wordt gewerkt aan de integratie van theorie en praktijk en aan de verwerving van professionele competenties. Aan de orde komen onder meer praktijkcases, praktijkgericht debat, oefeningen en opdrachten die de student – in aansluiting op de academiemodules – toerusten voor een succesvol afstudeertraject en vervolgens een professioneel functioneren op academisch niveau. Het atelier vormt daarmee een belangrijke integratiemodule in het curriculum.

In een serie inhoudelijke bijeenkomsten wordt ingegaan op het professioneel adviseren van publieke organisaties. Studenten gebruiken het geleerde om een ontwerp of advies te maken voor een organisatie in de publieke sector, over de aanpak van een probleem of een vraagstuk waar de organisatie mee te maken heeft. Het gaat hierbij om levensechte vraagstukken, die worden aangedragen door organisaties uit de publieke sector. Het ontwerp/advies wordt ook gepresenteerd aan de opdrachtgever.

Het Atelier is onderdeel van het afstudeertraject, waarin studenten stage lopen en een scriptie schrijven. Ter ondersteuning daarvan worden methodeseminars aangeboden waarvan de studenten er enkele moeten volgen. Informatie hierover wordt apart aangeboden, via Canvas en informatiebijeenkomsten (door de coördinators van de master).</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Na afloop van het Atelier Publiek Management kan de student:

column2: • Verschillende conceptuele benaderingen en strategieën van management en advisering onderscheiden;
• De aangedragen ideeën over management en advisering toepassen op actuele vraagstukken en concrete casuïstiek;
• Reflecteren op de theorie en de praktijk van strategische advisering in de publieke sector;
• Professioneel adviseren over de aanpak van belangrijke vraagstukken in de publieke sector;
• Reflecteren op de eigen stijl van adviseren.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104783,2022,Atelier/Professional Development Master Beleid en Politiek,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['ir. G Brinkman', 'W Korf']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De inhoudelijke basis voor het atelier Beleid en Politiek schuilt in de missie van de opleiding. De missie van de Master opleiding Beleid en Politiek kan in het kort als volgt worden weergegeven: De opleiding Beleid en Politiek leidt op tot publieke professionals, die in staat zijn om overheidsbeleid op academische denkniveau vanuit verschillende disciplinaire invalshoeken te analyseren en te vertalen naar bestuurlijke uitdagingen en oplossingen, waarbij zij zich bewust zijn van de dynamische maatschappelijke omgeving van het overheidsbestuur, waaronder de waardenpluriformiteit van bestuur en samenleving en de verregaande internationalisering van het maatschappelijk verkeer.

Vanuit deze missie kan een vijftal competenties worden afgeleid waarover afgestudeerden dienen te beschikken: analytisch, onderzoekend, oplossingsgericht, reflexief en overtuigend. In het atelier worden deze competenties ontwikkeld en versterkt.

Aan de hand van een concrete ontwerpopdracht worden deze competenties ontwikkeld en op de proef gesteld. Studenten nemen kennis van het ontwerpgericht denken en leren de verschillende stappen en activiteiten die in een bestuurskundig ontwerpproces toegepast worden. Aan de hand van een concrete casus die door een praktijkorganisatie is ingebracht, passen ze deze ontwerpbenadering toe en werken ze toe naar een praktisch bruikbaar ontwerp (voor bijvoorbeeld een proces, een beleidsinstrument of een sturingsaanpak) dat past bij de vraag van de opdrachtgever. De opdrachtgevende organisatie speelt een belangrijke rol in de aansturing en de beoordeling van de ontwerpopdracht.
Daarnaast zullen methoden en techniekencompetenties geoefend worden in het verlengde van het afstudeertraject. Daarvoor (zie ook afstudeeropdracht) zullen vier onderzoekseminars worden aangeboden.

Tot slot worden enkele bijeenkomsten georganiseerd met docenten die de praktijk van het openbaar bestuur van nabij kennen. Met hen wordt stilgestaan bij de professionele vaardigheden die de bestuurskundige professional moet hebben, met name als het aankomt op het opereren in complexe maatschappelijke en politiek-bestuurlijke contexten.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body> Na afloop van deze module kan de student:

column2: • De bestuurskundige ontwerpbenadering in een concrete casus toepassen
• In opdracht van een publieke opdrachtgever deze ontwerpbenadering toepassen en met behulp van deze ontwerpbenadering een gefundeerd en bruikbaar ontwerp voor een concreet vraagstuk ontwikkelen
• Dit ontwerp overtuigend presenteren en reflecteren op de kwaliteit en toepasbaarheid ervan
• een beredeneerde en verantwoorde keuze maken voor de eigen onderzoeksmethode en -ontwerp in de scriptie, de theoretische invalshoek en de prescriptieve vertaling van het onderzoek;
• reflecteren op het eigen leerproces binnen de stage en de scriptie;
• reflecteren op de context van het toekomstige werkveld en de consequenties daarvan voor de vereiste competenties en professionele houding als bestuurskundige professional.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Peoples’ attitudes and emotions are exceptionally important in employment organisations. Not only because of the significance of the quality of work for employees themselves, but also for diagnosing problems in organisations. The relationship with behavioural intentions and employment behaviour (for example turnover) also plays a role. Central within this module are the determinants and consequences of peoples’ views on their work, work motivation, emotional labour and emotional intelligence.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: It is the main objective of the course to have students gain knowledge and understand the role of attitudes and emotions in organizations. More specifically, students should:

column2: • Have understanding and knowledge of the nature of attitudes, how they are formed, how they are measured, and how they play a role within organizational settings.
• Have understanding and knowledge of the nature of emotions, how they come into existence, how they are measured, and how they play a role within an organizational setting.
• Have understanding and knowledge of the nature of emotional labor, its antecedents and consequences.
• Have understanding and knowledge of the nature of emotional intelligence, its antecedents and consequences.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106545,2022,Audience Engagement,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. SMR Driessen', 'FKS Robinson']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The starting point of this seminar is the widespread use of the internet and subsequently the way in which new media technologies have influenced user and producer interaction in the creative industries.  The seminar offers a critical analysis of various theoretical perspectives on audience engagement. Internet positivists underline the value of actively participating audience members – engaged audience members can co-create, help with promotion activities and are a key asset for   organizations in the creative industries in retaining a sustainable business model. Cultural critics are more skeptical towards audience engagement – especially when it comes to content creation. They believe that user-generated content could possibly undermined our culture. On a more practical level, many organizations struggle with engaging their audiences. Although it is sometimes assumed that online all users are active and engaged participants, in reality, there is a participation gap. Most people are lurkers and will not necessarily participate or engage in a more active way.

This seminar provides a state-of-the-art overview of the way engagement has been conceptualized   in academia, how its understanding has developed from a more passive form of engagement to a more active form of engagement, and how particularly new media technologies offer new tools to reshape the audience-producer relationship through engagement. We will focus on topics that are related to societal and cultural aspects of engagement, such as the possibilities of and limits to self- expression, the different levels of engagement and their motivational aspects, and the way engagement is incorporated into the strategies of organizations in the creative industries. During this seminar, you will be challenged to apply your theoretical knowledge to a practical case in which you will advise an organization in the creative industries about a specific problem concerning audience engagement.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Analyze recent and future trends in audience engagement
• Reflect in a critical way on the claims made by academics from various perspectives
• Take up and defend various positions in academic discourse
• Analyze an empirical case independently and in a team
• Compare and contrast various perspectives in a team and work towards a common line of reasoning
• Solve a challenge based on a communal interpretation of academic literature
• Collaborate to formulate a practical advice for an organization
• Jointly present a solution to an organization in an engaging way

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106357,2022,Audience Studies: Current Perspectives,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. TL Koren', 'E Naclerio']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After having been familiarized with classic academic literature on the reception of culture and media in previous courses, students now dive into current perspectives and approaches in the field of audience studies. We explore the state of the art in this academic paradigm, looking at various types of audiences and an array of media forms. How do audiences use and interpret media (content) in today’s ever more mediatized world? Which role does music play in people’s everyday life? How does gaming affect players? Why do people watch reality TV? How do we interpret Hollywood films around the world? And how do we effectively research these questions?
We discuss theoretical foundations and relevant concepts but also take a hands-on approach, in which students are encouraged to analyze and present case studies of their own interest.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Current theoretical perspectives and approaches in the field of audience studies;
• Current developments in the reception and use of media

column1: Students have developed the skills to:

column2: • Apply relevant theoretical insights and methods in the analysis of audience reception of media;
• Analyze and critically reflect upon current research in the field of audience studies;
• Coherently present the discussed material, both verbal and in written form;
• Effectively research case studies of audience reception in a wide variety of media cultures

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106109,2022,BAM Master Thesis & Internship,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. RP Rooderkerk'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The Thesis & Internship, including the thesis proposal, constitutes the heart of Block 3 through 5 of the MSc BA Business Analytics & Management. The Master thesis requires students to conduct independent, individual research that applies analytics to one of the functional domains (‘profiles’) in business administration (marketing, supply chain management/operations, finance, accounting, business information management).

The thesis is perceived as a proof of students’ academic level of thinking, especially a proof of intellectual and analytical craftsmanship. During the thesis trajectory, BAM students study a field in business administration in more depth. The thesis provides students with an opportunity to deepen their understanding of an area of interest, train their capabilities in analytics and problem solving, improve their skills in practical scientific business and management research, and develop a personal profile.

The thesis trajectory is followed in combination with an internship at a company or non-profit organization. This provides students with actual problems and a problem context including several stakeholders. It also means that students get exposed to issues such as time pressure, decision cycles, legal constraints, and ethical aspects.

The objective of the thesis trajectory is to deliver not just an “answer” to a single problem instance, but rather a proof of concept or analytics solution that can be applied to a class of problem instances.

As part of the Job Market & Negotiation Skills course students have searched for an internship. By the beginning of February, they hand in their thesis proposal, which outlines the problem they will study and the big picture analytics-based approach to solving it. Using an online system, they submit their proposal, indicating the chosen field of business administration. Due to limited supervision capacity, each domain will impose a certain capacity limit, which can be consulted online. Students are assigned a coach (primary supervisor) and co-reader. They will help the student shape their proposal and supervise the student throughout the Internship & Thesis trajectory. The thesis counts for 16 ECTS and is part of the GPA.
Deadlines for handing in thesis will be announced later.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In order to successfully complete the MSc BA Business Analytics & Management (henceforth BAM) students have to follow a master thesis trajectory. In the BAM master the thesis will be based on an internship .
The learning objectives of the Master Thesis are to enable students to:

column2: • Systematically follow the research cycle for a business analytics project.
• Demonstrate core knowledge on the interaction between an organisation and its broader environment including stakeholders.
• Demonstrate knowledge on analytical methods and core models in the chosen business field of specialization.

• Generate an effective and coherent approach to solving ill-defined business problems which have no standard solution and understand the managerial implications given the trade-off between appropriateness for the problem and practicality.
• Implement advanced analytics solutions given time pressure, decision cycles, legal constraints, and ethical aspects of the thesis/internship context.
• Demonstrate effective skills in communicating with different stakeholders.
• Present research and findings in a sound scientific report.
• Demonstrate critical reflection of your ethical responsibility as well as your influence, abilities, and limitations to instill these ethical values on others.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The BIM Company-Based Research Project (CRP) allows students to replace one free elective course in the program with a full-time thesis / research internship for one of the elective blocks (minimum of 168 hours). During the remaining two elective blocks, the student is recommended to continue working part-time and follow the remaining electives.

The BIM CRP should seek to combine the writing of the thesis with an internship at a company during one of the elective blocks (Blocks, 3, 4, or 5). It is therefore important that the internship is related to the thesis and students will need to decide on an internship in consultation with their thesis coach and the master thesis coordinator. Students must be able to show that the internship will allow them to collect company-specific data (for that specific company), and that it is essential for their thesis project.
The CRP will be assessed separately from the thesis (on a pass/fail basis) by the thesis coach, company supervisor and master thesis coordinator.

If a student opts for the CRP, it will count as a free elective for 6 EC. This will give them the opportunity to work exclusively within the company for a period of 7 weeks. Thesis internships may be agreed for a longer period of time, but a minimum of 168 hours is expected and a maximum of 6 ECTS is credited. During the remaining two elective blocks, the student is recommended to work part-time and follow the remaining electives.

THIS ELECTIVE COUNTS AS A FREE ELECTIVE FOR BIM STUDENTS ONLY. In order to graduate you MUST complete at least two other BIM Programme Electives! Please do not select this elective if you have not signed a contract yet.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After completing the BIM Company-Based Research Project, students should be able to:

column2: • Design and manage a small project to research or solve a practical business problem by using established techniques and insights of research;
• Analyse specific challenges an organization is facing in the contemporary context;
• Conduct a practical research project that addresses these challenges;
• Present a well-structured, well-argued research project, its findings, and your own recommendations;
• Carry out a project under the supervision of a company manager.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106167,2022,BIM Honours Class,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. D Tsekouras', 'Y Kuper, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The BIM Honours Programme offers the most talented and motivated students in the MSc BIM program a challenging extracurricular course in BIM research and practice. Participation is by invitation only. A limited group of 25-30 students will be selected to follow an additional course that runs across the 3rd, 4th, and 5th block of their studies. Selected students are the best performing students of the MSc in BIM programme. The small group size ensures that students have many opportunities for interaction with faculty members and participating companies.

The programme features involvement from multiple companies. The sessions will be highly interactive and require a strong preparation. Cooperation is sought with external partners, who introduce a series of challenges that students need to complete (e.g. consultancy project, data analytics challenge, business process training).

Participation will be limited to the best students in the MSc programme of Business Information Management. The first step in the selection process will be a ranking based on all core courses (Blocks 1 and 2, weighted by ECTS). In the second step in the selection process, the highest ranking students will be asked to submit a motivation letter.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The honours class in Business Information Management puts excellent students in close contact with the latest advancements in research and practice. The course is designed to complement the MSc course portfolio by offering more in-depth training in selected areas of particular interest. The programme is also offering networking opportunities and contacts with executives and companies.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106165,2022,BIM Master Thesis,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. DK Zegners', 'dr. S Mehta', 'Y Kuper, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: During the year you will participate in a structured master thesis trajectory. You will start in September, during the core courses, to familiarize yourself with the research being done at our department and the relevant academic literature and topics available. Staff involved in this MSc will present their current research projects, and you will be invited to link your master thesis to one of these projects. Before Christmas you will decide on a final topic and be assigned a coach who is an expert in the subject area chosen. Early January a thesis clinic will provide you with the foundation that you will need to complete your thesis successfully. In February you will deliver your research proposal after which you will implement your research question and finalize your thesis before the summer. Staff and researchers will provide assistance by coaching you through the entire master thesis process.
The following themes are examples of possible BIM Master Thesis topics:

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The writing of your master thesis – the report of your scientific study – is the most important part of the Business Information Management programme. The master thesis is your opportunity to show your potential as a next generation manager. During this period, you will interact with internationally-recognized companies and well-known researchers in the field of Business Information Management.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106163,2022,BIM Research Methods,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. D Gutt', 'dr. D Tsekouras', 'prof.dr.ir. HWGM van Heck']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In today’s economy, data-driven decision making in firms increasingly replaces decision based on gut feelings. As data is becoming increasingly available for firms from sources both internal and external, the need to understand methods to process and analyze data grows steadily.

Therefore, this course will equip students with the necessary tools to extract knowledge from data to succeed in their master theses and ultimately conduct their own research. To this end, students will be introduced to the fundamentals of selected empirical research methods (case studies and econometrics) and selected types of data provenance (observational, experimental, and survey data). Understanding these methods and data types will be essential for the students’ success in their master theses and, not only but especially, when considering pursuing an academic career after their master’s degree in form of a PhD. Students will have hands-on experience with data to acquire expertise in solving practical data-related issues. These skills are not only crucial to the success in this course but are valuable assets in other courses covering data analytics in their master’s programme as well as in their professional lives, of course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course will provide students with a basic understanding of different methodological issues, including a basic understanding of:

column2: • Describe the basic research methodologies in the BIM field
• Explain how to decide on a research methodology in the domain of empirical research
• Understand how to design a survey
• Clean, organize, and analyze data in R
• Perform basic univariate and multivariate econometric analyses
• Justify certain research methods for the research question at hand
• Evaluate the difference in performance of different statistical methods and discuss advantages and drawbacks of methods

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106168,2022,BIM Thesis Clinic,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. D Tsekouras'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: One of the reasons companies hire university graduates, is because of their academic posture. This includes a critical attitude towards what is presented as “the truth”, the ability to assess the quality of research presented to them, and the competence to study a phenomenon in a structured way. These same qualities are required of you as you design and execute your Master thesis project. This course will focus on the basics of conducting sound scientific research and writing a good master thesis. </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course students should be able to:

column2: • Create (plan & set‐up) a solid scientific research project and understand the key considerations in designing and implementing it.
• Formulate a sound research objective and research question for a research project in Business Information Management.
• Critically evaluate research in the area of Business Information Management and related fields.
• Conduct a literature review and collect, organize and interpret academic literature.
• Comprehend the research methodologies and develop the ability make an informed decision for a research methodology, appropriate for their research objective.
• Understand the foundations of academic writing and develop the vocabulary required to communicate their research.
• Write a sound proposal for an academic study.
