column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course, you will work on a research question in teams of four students under the supervision of a supervisor. Each team is enrolled in a “theme”, a research topic offered by a supervisor within your track. The supervisor of the theme will be the one who coaches you throughout the process and provides you with feedback on your assignments. The supervisor is your main contact during this course, whereas the track coordinator and course coordinator will primarily aid the supervisors.

The core of the project is research, and what type of research will vary by track. The Bachelor Project follows all steps of a research cycle: A managerial problem, a knowledge question, review of evidence, research design, data collection, data analysis, answer to the question, recommendation to management. “Management” should be read as “stakeholder from practice”. The outcome can be a design, hypothesis test, conceptual framework, and in all cases is translated into an answer to a managerial problem. The data can be quantitative or qualitative, primary or secondary, empirical or simulated.

To successfully complete the Bachelor Project, we assume that students participate in Advanced Research Methods (ARM) course (B3101) in parallel or have already completed this course. Moreover, we assume that students have active knowledge of the concepts covered in Research Project (BT2103) or Onderzoeksproject (BK2103). Lastly, the course builds on a lot of knowledge that you should have acquired in previous methods-related courses (e.g., statistics, mathematics). It is your responsibility to dust off this knowledge. Look at material from these courses when things are not top of mind. Do not expect your supervisor to act like a tutor on such topics.

Via five different assignments you will work on your Bachelor Project. Assignment 1 will focus on the Literature Review and assignment 2 on the Project Design. These are group assignments. Assignment 3 is an individual assignment – it is a video in which you discuss the progress so far. You will receive an individual grade for assignment 3. Assignment 4 is a group assignment again and covers the research results captured in the BP Report. You will receive feedback on each group assignment and a grade for the BP report (assignment 4). Assignment 5 is about writing your own individual Conclusion Chapter. Assignment 5 is also graded. After each assignment, feedback will be provided by the supervisor.

The contents of the track modules in your track are not required knowledge for the Bachelor Project. The track modules may help in successfully completing the Bachelor Project. What the Bachelor Project and the track modules share is the focus on a specific area of interest, defined by the contents and the research methods discussed in the track modules.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The learning method in this course consists mainly of “learning by doing”, i.e., by doing something (some of that for the very first time) and then understanding and applying a supervisor’s feedback on that work. You will apply the knowledge gained from the ARM course and you will learn what these principles mean by applying them in your own project. After having completed your Bachelor Project, you should be able to:

column2: • Collect and critically assess academic and professional literature on a specific topic
• Write a critical review of the academic and professional literature
• Identify a relevant managerial problem and translate the managerial question into a research question
• Design a research project that can be executed in the available timeframe
• Collect and analyse data that is needed to answer the research question
• Present research results and defend the choices made

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: In het eerste studiejaar start het CA-onderwijs (Communicatie en Attitude). Hierbij staan de rollen ‘communicator’, ‘beroepsbeoefenaar’ en ‘academicus’ centraal. Bij de rol ‘communicator’ gaat het onder andere om open en respectvolle communicatie met patiënten. De student kan een goede anamnese afnemen, waarbij hij relevante informatie krijgt van de patiënt, actief luistert en begrip en empathie toont. De rol ‘beroepsbeoefenaar’ gaat onder andere over het leveren van patiëntenzorg op integere, oprechte en betrokken wijze. De student herkent ethische dilemma’s en kan omgaan met diversiteit in patiëntenachtergrond. De rol ‘academicus’ houdt onder andere in dat de student staat is om te reflecteren op het eigen handelen. De student kent de grenzen van het eigen kunnen en handelt daarnaarZie voor meer informatie de studentenhandleiding van PKV-CA jaar 1</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Het onderwijs in praktische klinische vaardigheden (PKV) bestaat uit drie onderdelen: PKV-MT (medische technieken), PKV-MA (medische anamnese) en PKV-CA (communicatie en attitude). Het CA-onderwijs begint in Bachelor 1, PKV-MT en PKV-MA starten in Bachelor 2. In Bachelor 3 worden CA, MA en MT ook gecombineerd in de lessen APC (Arts Patiënt Contact). Daarnaast leert de student acute hulp te verlenen.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107794,2022,Ba1 Integratietoets,Nederlands,Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC),,['D.H.J. Pols', 'dr. A. van t Spijker', 'G. Elshout', 'J.J.P. Buteijn - Geuze', 'P.C.J. de Laat', 'R.A. van der Wolf, BA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Iedere vraag is in principe gekoppeld aan een klacht van een patiënt, zogenaamde casusvragen. Voorafgaand aan de toets, minimaal één week van tevoren, ontvangt de student per casus een korte beschrijving van de patiënt en zijn klacht. Dit ‘patiëntvignet’ bestaat uit de volgende informatie:
·          de rol, bijvoorbeeld: je bent huisarts
·          de klachtpresentatie, bijvoorbeeld: sinds vanochtend kortademig

Onderdeel van klinisch redeneren is ook het kunnen inpassen van ontwikkelingen in de wetenschappelijke literatuur. Het beoordelen van resultaten van wetenschappelijk onderzoek op kwaliteit en waarde maakt daarom deel uit van de integratietoets. Dit aspect wordt met name in het eerste bachelorjaar uitvoerig getoetst. Ook wordt leerstof uit de academisch beroepsgebonden vakken, zoals ethiek, filosofie, geschiedenis en recht getoetst, evenals leerstof uit de lijn normale psychologie.
De integratietoets is een gecombineerd schriftelijk tentamen met zowel gesloten als open vragen.
Er zijn twee tentamenmogelijkheden per jaar. Voor de beschrijving van de cesuur wordt verwezen naar de Regels en Richtlijnen voor de Examens.
Meer informatie over deze toets en voorbeelden van toetsvragen staat in de handleiding Klinisch Redeneren van het betreffende bachelorjaar.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: De integratietoets is erop gericht het vermogen tot klinisch redeneren te toetsen, en is de afsluitende jaartoets van de lijn Klinisch Redeneren. In deze toets herhaalt de student zijn verworven (bio)medische kennis uit de thema’s gecombineerd met de kennis over vaardigheden en integreert hij deze kennis door deze in een (nieuwe) klinische context toe te passen. </body>

column1: De gezondheidszorg en het medische beroep zijn in de afgelopen jaren flink veranderd. Zo is er bij de populatie sprake van een toename van chronische ziekten en co-morbiditeit bij steeds ouder wordende patiënten. Er is een toenemende complexiteit en specialisatie in de zorg en een toegenomen diversiteit aan patiënten en zorgverleners. Daarbij is de zorg technologischer en kennisintensiever geworden. Ook de rol van patiënten is veranderd; waar patiënten zorg eerder passief ontvingen, beslissen ze nu actief mee en voeren ze de eigen regie.

De opleiding Geneeskunde moet zo zijn ingericht dat deze toekomstige artsen goed voorbereidt op werken in de snel veranderende gezondheidszorg. Daarbij is het van belang dat artsen kunnen zorg dragen voor een houdbaar gezondheidszorgsysteem in de toekomst. Teamwork, een effectieve samenwerking tussen artsen onderling, tussen artsen en andere zorgverleners en tussen artsen en de patiënt en zijn/haar familie en omgeving, staat hierbij centraal.

Het Erasmus MC heeft dan ook de ambitie om basisartsen op te leiden die onderscheidend zijn als teamspelers, die effectief kunnen samenwerken om optimale (kwalitatief hoogwaardige, veilige en doelmatige) zorg te kunnen leveren in samenspraak met de patiënt en preventie in de praktijk te laten slagen. In het curriculum wordt daarom meer aandacht besteed aan (interprofessioneel) samenwerken, veiligheid, kwaliteit en doelmatigheid van zorg, patiëntgerichte zorg, preventie en een populatiegerichte benadering van ziekte en gezondheid. Dit onderwijs vormt de lijn Samenwerken voor Optimale Zorg en Preventie (SOZP).

Dit onderwijs biedt de gelegenheid je optimaal te kunnen ontwikkelen in de competenties behorend bij de CanMEDS rollen Samenwerker, Organisator en Gezondheidsbevorderaar en op het gebied van de Erasmusarts eindtermen, die vallen onder de clusters Klinische en beroepsgebonden vaardigheden en Maatschappelijke verantwoordelijkheid: zorgvisie en preventie.
De lijn SOZP bestaat uit twee aandachtsgebieden:

column2: Samenwerken en Veiligheid (SV). Dit aandachtsgebied beslaat onder andere de onderwerpen (interprofessioneel) samenwerken, kwaliteit en veiligheid van zorg, patiëntgerichtheid en shared decision making.
Zorgvisie en Preventie (ZP). Dit aandachtsgebied beslaat onder andere de onderwerpen kostenbewustzijn, doelmatigheid en preventie.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: De opleiding Geneeskunde leidt basisartsen op waarvan het profiel is beschreven in het Raamplan 2009. De eindtermen van de opleiding zijn vertaald naar eindtermen per curriculumonderdeel, per opleidingsjaar, welke de basis vormen voor de inrichting van het onderwijs en toetsing.
Voor het aandachtsgebied van Samenwerken en Veiligheid (SV) zijn voor de bachelor de volgende twee eindtermen als uitgangspunten genomen:

column2: De student kan op doeltreffende wijze samenwerken met collega’s, andere zorgverleners, patiënten en/of cliënten en hun naasten om veilige zorg te leveren.
De student kan bijdragen aan interdisciplinaire teams op het gebied van zorg, onderzoek en onderwijs.

column1: Voor het aandachtsgebied van Zorgvisie en Preventie (ZP) zijn voor de bachelor de volgende twee eindtermen als uitgangspunten genomen:

column2: De student kan risicovolle determinanten herkennen en naar aanleiding daarvan adequaat handelen op zowel individueel, groeps- en maatschappelijk niveau.
De student kan actief bijdragen aan verbeteringen van de kwaliteit, veiligheid en doelmatigheid van de gezondheidszorg en maatschappelijke opvang.

column1: De specifieke eindtermen voor de lijn SOZP voor het eerste bachelorjaar staan hieronder weergegeven. Dit is het vereiste beheersingsniveau dat aan het eind van het eerste bachelorjaar voor de lijn SOZP van je wordt verwacht en waarop je wordt getoetst.

column2: De student heeft inzicht in de factoren die essentieel zijn voor het functioneren in een team in het kader van veilige zorg.
De student kan feedback geven en vragen op aspecten van samenwerkvaardigheden.
De student kan reflecteren op zijn/haar eigen sterke en zwakke kanten in het samenwerken.
De student kan de determinanten die de gezondheid kunnen beïnvloeden benoemen.
De student kan de mogelijke niveaus van preventie (primaire, secundaire en tertiaire) benoemen.
De student kan de werking en financiering van de gezondheidszorg op hoofdlijnen beschrijven.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>In het eerste studiejaar start het CA-onderwijs (Communicatie en Attitude). Hierbij staan de rollen ‘communicator’, ‘beroepsbeoefenaar’ en ‘academicus’ centraal. Bij de rol ‘communicator’ gaat het onder andere om open en respectvolle communicatie met patiënten. De student kan een goede anamnese afnemen, waarbij hij relevante informatie krijgt van de patiënt, actief luistert en begrip en empathie toont. De rol ‘beroepsbeoefenaar’ gaat onder andere over het leveren van patiëntenzorg op integere, oprechte en betrokken wijze. De student herkent ethische dilemma’s en kan omgaan met diversiteit in patiëntenachtergrond. De rol ‘academicus’ houdt onder andere in dat de student staat is om te reflecteren op het eigen handelen. De student kent de grenzen van het eigen kunnen en handelt daarnaarZie voor meer informatie de studentenhandleiding van PKV-CA jaar 1</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Het onderwijs in praktische klinische vaardigheden (PKV) bestaat uit drie onderdelen: PKV-MT (medische technieken), PKV-MA (medische anamnese) en PKV-CA (communicatie en attitude). Het CA-onderwijs begint in Bachelor 1, PKV-MT en PKV-MA starten in Bachelor 2. In Bachelor 3 worden CA, MA en MT ook gecombineerd in de lessen APC (Arts Patiënt Contact). Daarnaast leert de student acute hulp te verlenen. </body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: In het eerste studiejaar start het CA-onderwijs (Communicatie en Attitude). Hierbij staan de rollen ‘communicator’, ‘beroepsbeoefenaar’ en ‘academicus’ centraal. Bij de rol ‘communicator’ gaat het onder andere om open en respectvolle communicatie met patiënten. De student kan een goede anamnese afnemen, waarbij hij relevante informatie krijgt van de patiënt, actief luistert en begrip en empathie toont. De rol ‘beroepsbeoefenaar’ gaat onder andere over het leveren van patiëntenzorg op integere, oprechte en betrokken wijze. De student herkent ethische dilemma’s en kan omgaan met diversiteit in patiëntenachtergrond. De rol ‘academicus’ houdt onder andere in dat de student staat is om te reflecteren op het eigen handelen. De student kent de grenzen van het eigen kunnen en handelt daarnaarZie voor meer informatie de studentenhandleiding van PKV-CA jaar 1</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Het onderwijs in praktische klinische vaardigheden (PKV) bestaat uit drie onderdelen: PKV-MT (medische technieken), PKV-MA (medische anamnese) en PKV-CA (communicatie en attitude). Het CA-onderwijs begint in Bachelor 1, PKV-MT en PKV-MA starten in Bachelor 2. In Bachelor 3 worden CA, MA en MT ook gecombineerd in de lessen APC (Arts Patiënt Contact). Daarnaast leert de student acute hulp te verlenen.

column1: The Bachelor Graduation Project offers students guidance in formulating an appropriate and relevant research design, and in structuring and conducting research in the field of Arts and Culture Studies. After successful completion of the Bachelor Graduation Project, students are able to conduct a theoretically informed empirical study and provide an adequate report on their research and findings.
During the Bachelor’s Graduation Project, students are expected to perform the following activities independently, but under the supervision of a lecturer:
•             Demarcate and study a particular subject in the field of Arts and Culture Studies;
•             Formulate a relevant and appropriate definition of a problem and research question(s) that derive from this;

column2: • Formulate a relevant and appropriate research design;
• Formulate an appropriate method of analysis with an adequate reporting and analysis of the results;

• Write a thesis that adequately describes the entire research process, from formulating research problems, creating a theoretical framework, describing the chosen methodology and methods, and provides clear arguments for analyses, results, and conclusions.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>During the Bachelor Graduation Project, students demonstrate and combine the knowledge and skills acquired during the three-year BA program, or one-year premaster program, in the form of a bachelor thesis. Students learn how to formulate and design an appropriate research study in the field of Arts and Culture Studies.</body>

column1: The final product of the Bachelor Project is the bachelor thesis: an individual research report of maximum 8,500 words (10,000 including cover page, table of contents and appendices). Students choose a thesis topic from one of the themes offered. The themes correspond to the content of learning paths in the Public Administration programme.

An introductory session will be held in period 6. During this session, the structure of the Bachelor Project will be explained, and the themes will be presented. The tutorials and supervision for the Bachelor Project will subsequently start in period 7. At least 1 tutorial group consisting of approximately 8 students will be established for each theme and these groups will be supervised by lecturers affiliated with a particular theme. Supervision usually takes place in (smaller) thesis groups consisting of around 4 students. In total, eight sessions have been planned (not including the introductory session).

Admission to the Bachelor Project course is only possible after the student has fully completed the Bachelor 2 (see article 4.2. of the Education and Examination Regulations). Students who do not meet the admission requirements, but still wish to take the Bachelor Project course, will have to submit a request to the Examination Board asking for permission to take this course (see Canvas, Contact: request form Examination Board). It is recommended that students submit this request before period 7 commences. The Public Administration bachelor programme (and therefore the Bachelor Project) must be successfully completed in full in order to gain admission to a master programme. Consult the Education and Examination Regulations (EER) for supplementary admission criteria for Public Administration master programmes.

• The student is able to clearly report the research results in accordance with academic standards in a format that is accessible and understandable for academics and/or policy-makers.
• Based on a concrete scientific research project, the student is able to form an opinion and formulate recommendations.

column1: The bachelor’s thesis is an important assessment in the bachelor’s program because it tests the student’s ability to report about their own small-scale historical research. The bachelor’s thesis follows on the bachelor thesis class of a specific focus area. The bachelor thesis is considered as an independent course within the bachelor’s program. Students have to write their own thesis individually, although they can consult their supervisor by appointment. The different focus areas of
The bachelor’s thesis is an elaboration of the final paper of the bachelor thesis class. This implies that the students are asked to:

column2: • Expand their secondary and primary sources (e.g. longer period, more samples, broader geographical reach and/or a comparative approach).

• The student has to process the remarks of the teacher of the bachelor thesis class in the bachelor’s thesis. Students can find more information on the assessment criteria of bachelor’s thesis on MyEUR.

column1: Deadline: For students following the Bachelor Thesis Class in term 2; the thesis should be written in term 3.Theses that are submitted after the deadline will not be marked and will not get a re-sit opportunity.

The student is able to set up a small-scale research project under supervision. The students are able to formulate an elaborate research question which is the starting-point for their bachelor thesis. They can find and critically interpret different types of primary sources and engage with relevant secondary literature to answer this research question and they also are able to apply theoretical and methodological concepts in their research. Finally, the students are able to write an academic report about their small-scale research.</body>

column1: Students complete their Bachelor's programme by writing a Bachelor's thesis. Although the BA thesis is completed individually, students receive guidance while working on the thesis by means of a weekly thesis class, which starts in term 3 and continues into term 4. The classes are arranged around themes in accordance with the focus areas of IBCoM. In consultation with the lecturer, students develop a research question that is related to the wider theme of their thesis class.

The BA Thesis Class starts with a discussion of potential research subjects and addressing background literature as well as relevant research methods. The main part of the course concerns conducting the actual research. Students are invited to submit questions and to talk about the progress and results of their research.

The BA thesis is a reflection of the knowledge and research skills obtained in the field of Communication and Media. In addition, the BA thesis is designed to further train students' ability to develop, conduct and report on a theoretically informed, practically relevant, empirical study.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106425,2022,Bachelor Thesis Class Authoritarian lives? Society and Culture in Twentieth-Century European Dictatorships,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. L Green', 'L Zurné, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: What is an authoritarian regime, what is it like to live under one, how do authoritarian states co-exist with other states with greater democratic representation, and how do they legitimise their rule? What is the role of propaganda and other forms of media in the imagination of national identity and what narratives do they tell? What is remembered in the cultural memory of these regimes, and what is forgotten? Hannah Arendt located the logic of the so-called totalitarian regimes of twentieth-century Europe in the mechanisation, bureaucratisation, and depersonalisation of modernity. But these authoritarian regimes are just a handful among a range of historical examples spanning centuries. While scholars such as Arendt offer us one way of looking at authoritarianism, this perspective often favours the writing of high political history in the context of the nation state, and which positions authoritarian regimes as ‘other’ to a Western liberal democracy.
Potential case studies might include: Khmer Rouge Cambodia, late-imperial Russia, Nazi Germany, Syria under Assad, Chile under Pinochet, Napoleonic France, Indonesia under Dutch colonial rule/Suharto
Potential themes might include: visual culture, education, international organisations, religion, protest and revolution, gender, childhood, literature, nostalgia, diplomacy, science and technology

While language skills might be necessary for certain combinations of case studies and themes, speak to the course tutors for advice, as many topics can be approached using English-language primary sources using a carefully chosen angle.
Our tutors’ specific areas of expertise include:
- Lara (Eurasia, Europe, C19th-today, revolutionary movements, political violence, gender)
- Lise (Indonesia, 1940-today, popular culture, gender, ritual, memory)

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this Bachelor Thesis Class, we will connect our case studies through the theme of unfreedom. Therefore, you may choose to write a thesis focusing on any aspect of the social, cultural, economic, or international relations histories of any state or society in which people have experienced a lack or loss of political rights. By drawing links across different chronologies, geographies, political philosophies, and systems of rule, we will gain a deeper understanding into the historical specificities of our own case studies. Theses may also explore citizens’ agency in processes of state-building and the ways in which (groups of) people may resist national symbolism in times of political change. Another important theme may be everyday life (Alltagsgeschichte). We will decentre our understandings of unfree polities, societies, and their citizens, moving beyond comparisons to an idealised Western modernity and simplistic models of power relations. We will see that the historical relationship between state and citizen, the international relations of authoritarian states, the role of propaganda, protest and resistance, and economic planning and management are not quite as simple as we first assumed. And, perhaps, we will see that these states and their citizens’ experiences are sometimes not too far from our own.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106424,2022,Bachelor Thesis Class Crisis and Conflict in the Long Twentieth Century,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['BC Fici, MA', 'dr. I Gusc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The first decades of the twenty-first century have been marked by a series of crisis: 9/11, the US-led invasions in the Middle East, the Arab Spring, the Financial Crisis of 2008, the rise populist politics in the West, and the geopolitical and economic tensions arising as a result of the resurgence of Russia and China. Are these crises and conflicts inherent to the international and economic order that has been established post-WWII, or are we living through a rare watershed moment in history that marks the breakdown of the old order in favour of a reconstructed and reconfigured international and economic order?
This course aims to offer students the opportunity to understanding the global turmoil of the twenty-first century through exploring the long twentieth century.

Students are encouraged to pursue their research interests independently to identify a topic that is feasible in terms of source availability and historiographical contribution, but advice and assistance is offered to guide this process.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This course serves to prepare students for researching and writing up the BA thesis. By the end of this course, students are able to formulate a research question, to develop a research methodology, to embed their research question in relevant historiographical debates, and, finally, to locate and analyse critically primary source material to postulate an academically rigorous answer to their research question.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Consumerism and mass consumption are modern phenomena, often seen as linked economically to the industrial revolution and the rise of capitalism. Socially and culturally, it relates to growing individualism, urbanization and the rise of bourgeois or mass culture. The term consumption society came in use in French and Anglo-Saxon scholarship in the 60s, mostly to study how in contemporary times consumption and consumption culture seem to become increasingly important and how consumption was linked with identity, but also how mass consumption was organized or how advertisement used and influenced cultural values. Historians started studying what brought about its current centrality in our lives, societies and cultures? Early modernists have shown that consumption revolution(s) predate the industrial revolution, and rather coincide with the rise of global trade. Moreover, the global turn in history has shed light on consumption and material culture in many different localities worldwide. This also brings into question what consumption is. Note that we call consumption both the acquisition of goods, stuff, items, possessions, and the use of food and other substances or even acts that satisfy bodily needs or experiences. It has to do with commodities as well as with desire. Material culture can be both an object of study in itself and can be a lens through which we study questions of cultural, economic and social history. Material culture left many traces in objects, but also in written records and images, which may be studied by those interested in the social meanings of consumption, its social settings, the politics of consumption, changing behaviour patterns and new commodities consumed. Vast parts of society were increasingly occupied with organizing this consumption from production, distribution, the emergence of sales in shops and retail, rather than markets, through branding and marketing, packaging, delivering and finally the disposal of its waste.
Note: the maximum number of participants is 12

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course focusing on economic and political history approaches, students are offered a new conceptual framework for understanding when and how environmental and biological hazards turned into disasters – and when and how this was prevented. Students learn that history is of great value for helping us understand the long-term economic and political consequences that very short-term hazards could create; and vice-versa, students learn that hazards, shocks and disasters can enrich our study of past societies by opening a window to facets of society hidden from view during “normal times”.

During the course, students focus on classifications and concepts such as “vulnerability”, “resilience”, “adaptation”, and “risk”, and apply these to their own historical case studies, which form the basis of a research proposal that will become the foundation of their BA thesis. Typical kinds of questions that students might want to address using explicitly historical approaches include: how do disasters affect state control of citizens, and how do disasters affect citizens trust towards governments? Do disasters make societies more unequal or equal? Who is to blame for disasters? Do disasters bring communities together or lead to discord? How disasters affect the relationships between states? Are we at greater risk in the age of the Anthropocene, or are we now more protected than in the past via science and technology?

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106429,2022,Bachelor Thesis Class Friendcraft: forging bonds of friendship in Politics and International Relations,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. Y van Hoef'],,"Inhoud
‘But when you talk about friendly relations in politics, it's not the friendship of schoolmates, of the Arbat’

Historians study both individual relationships, such as the famous friendship between Franklin Roosevelt and Winston Churchill, but also positive bonds between nations like the Special Relationship and Franco-German Cooperation. Others consider the role of networks and social movements, and friendships within civil society, even studying friendship within terrorist organizations. Many studies focus on how the meaning of friendship itself has changed through history, for instance how ancient friendship treaties that traditionally represented equality became treaties of subjugation, like those between the young US Republic and the native American nations. Other studies focus on processes of reconciliation, between France and Germany, but also between the latter and Israel.

In this BTC, the weekly class is divided in two parts. In the first part, we discuss in-depth 2-3 important contemporary articles by leading scholars on the subject, while in the second part we focus on a practical aspect of the thesis. In that way, you will gain both an in-depth understanding of the current historiography and of the most modern relevant methods of performing research for your own thesis subject.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>When thinking about maritime history, one will in the first place think of ships and the history of the development of ships. But maritime history also is the history of overseas contacts, struggle between maritime powers over trade routes and colonies, the development of ports and the social conflicts there, the first contacts of Europeans with people from other continents and the position of sailors and their families. It therefore is about trade an trade conflicts, war and colonial expansion, the ideas of Europeans on people from Africa or Asia, on the position of these people when they came in a European port and racial conflicts in ports as shipowners preferred black people over whites as the former were less paid. On the position of women that had to raise a family without a husband as he lived on a ship or even died on sea, and as a consequence the quantitative dominance of women in sailor communities. Of course, it also is about sailing and trade and warfare on sea. In this course we will concentrate on a few aspects:

column2: • Economic aspects: The sea as a link between markets and the enormous growth of transport and ports in the last two centuries
• Political aspects: Ideas about controlling the sea as a method of controlling the world and the competition between the navies of major powers
• Warfare: Why were wars fought on sea, and why not?
• Cultural conflicts and racism: Ports as places where people from diverse background and colour met and the (race) conflicts that resulted from it.
• Women and the sea: how did women cope with the problem that they had to raise their families alone when the men were at sea.

column1: Note: the maximum number of participants is 12.</body>

column1: The interventions, rationales and rhetoric of modern medicine and health are ubiquitous in our contemporary lives. Yet this particular present was very recent in its making. This course looks at the rise of ""medicine"" and ""health"" as objects of inquiry and government intervention, particularly in the colonial and imperial realms. Far from being neutral realms of knowledge, the formation of medicine and ideas of health are intertwined with social, economic and political stratification which are the result of local and global conditions with historical antecedents, often involving regimes of coercion and violence such as imperialism and the concomitants of modernization and globalization. Which groups were included or excluded from medical and health considerations in the past and why? How has imperialism in its various forms affected the cultures of medicine and health in diverse locations?

column1: Twentieth Century International Business in Times of Political and Economic Crisis

The Twentieth Century was marked by a series of crises that changed the world. The First and   Second World War not only caused suffering and death on a scale hitherto unknown, they also profoundly changed the world in both a political and economic sense. The interwar period was marked by slow economic recovery, rising protectionism and a number of severe economic crises, both regional and worldwide. The Cold War prevented a return to the level of globalization that had been destroyed with the outbreak of the First World War. It was only with the end of the Cold War   that globalization would attain the levels it had at the turn of the century. Yet the nature of this late- twentieth century globalization - while very familiar in many aspects - was also very different from what had gone on before. The course allows students considerable leeway in examining how these events impacted international business both on the short and longer term, and particularly the economic and political consequences of both World Wars, the Great Depression, the Cold War, and Decolonization.
Note: the maximum number of participants is 12</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>With the onset of the Industrial Revolution, there also started a process of economic integration. This happens both on a large scale – e.g. globalization processes culminating in the first wave of globalization in the second half of the nineteenth century – and on a smaller scale – e.g. the Dutch and German economies, and what is commonly known as the transnational Rhine economy. Obviously, these are complex and broad subjects, so for your BA-thesis in this theme you should think about a subject that touches on an aspect of this. Below are just a few aspects that have sparked an extensive literature. Use one of these – or another aspect – as a starting point to come up with your own BA-thesis sized research subject:

column2: • Finance: trade needs to be financed, and international investments are a major part of economic globalization. The Dutch were major investors in nineteenth century American railways. Those same railways were part of the First Transport Revolution that caused an agricultural crisis in Europe and a shift in Dutch agriculture towards knowledge-, labor-, and capital-intensive types of agriculture. Money is important in other ways as well: both the reparations payments that France had to pay Germany after the Franco-Prussian War of 1870 and the reparations Germany had to pay the Allies after WW1 caused lasting resentment.
• Trade: trade is the most obvious way in which economies are interwoven. But how does that evolve, and why? How is that transported, what patterns emerge, how do they change, and why?

• International relations theory: the relationship between conflict and economic integration is a much-debated issue in international relations theory. Some argue that is brings peace, because war would interrupt trade, making it too costly. Others argue that the effects are the opposite: when economies become interdependent, this makes a country vulnerable. This could become a reason for the more powerful of the two countries to annex the less powerful country. You could use IR theory to study how disputes regarding trade or border issues are resolved, but there are many other possibilities.

column1: These are but a few examples of how economic integration can have unexpected consequences. I invite you to come up with subjects for your thesis that touch upon an aspect of this theme. Quantitative approaches are welcomed.</body>

column3: Bachelorscriptie bouwt voort op de vakken Leeronderzoek I en Leeronderzoek II  uit Bachelor 2. Het grootste verschil met beide leeronderzoeken is dat in het Bachelorscriptie individueel verslag wordt gedaan van het uitgevoerde onderzoek. Tijdens het uitvoeren van het onderzoek kunnen studenten echter wel deels gezamenlijk optrekken. Sterker nog, in veel gevallen, zoals bij het verzamelen van data, is dat zelfs expliciet de bedoeling, omdat anders het tijdsbestek van dit vak te kort kan zijn. Het onderzoek wordt – net zoals bij de leeronderzoeken – intensief begeleid door een docent. Wat bij de leeronderzoeken – en methodologische vakken – aan bod is gekomen wordt voor het uitvoeren van dat onderzoek echter wel als bekend verondersteld. Het staat studenten natuurlijk vrij om weer bij de hoorcolleges van die vakken aan te schuiven om deze voorkennis weer op te frissen.

Dit vak beoogt studenten te ondersteunen bij de uitvoering van het onderzoek waarmee zij de Bacheloropleiding afronden. Van dit onderzoek dient verslag te worden gedaan in een bachelorscriptie, dat de vorm heeft van een onderzoeksartikel. Het vak bestaat uit zes bijeenkomsten waarin de studenten met de docent die hen begeleidt de voortgang van het onderzoek bespreken. De studenten voeren dit onderzoek uit aan de hand van een onderzoeksthema aangereikt in de vakken Modernisering 3: Beleids- en organisatiesociologie, Cohesion 3: Deviance en Identity 2: Politics and Society.

column1: • De student leert een sociologisch- of beleidsrelevante probleemstelling te formuleren die hij/zij beantwoordt door het uitvoeren van een kleinschalig empirisch onderzoek.
• De student leert gebruik te maken van theorieën door daar hypothesen of kwalitatieve onderzoeksvragen van af te leiden.
• De student leert op een verantwoorde wijze concepten te operationaliseren.
• De student voert zelfstandig empirisch onderzoek uit op secundaire of zelf-verzamelde data, daarbij gebruikmakend van de relevante methoden en technieken voor sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek.
• De student leert de sociologisch-theoretische waarde van haar/zijn onderzoeksbevindingen, alsmede de beleidsrelevantie daarvan.
• De student leert onderzoeksresultaten helder en logisch te rapporteren.

Er zijn verscheidene werkcollegegroepen, elk rondom een bepaald bestuurskundig thema. Studenten kiezen binnen het thema van hun groep voor een specifieke probleemstelling. De docenten begeleiden studenten bij de opzet en uitvoering van het onderzoek en bij het schrijven van het onderzoeksrapport. column1: <body>De volgende ingangseisen gelden voor het Bachelorproject (conform artikel 4.2 van het OER):   1. Toelating tot de onderdelen van bachelor-2 en bachelor-3 kan uitsluitend plaatsvinden nadat de student een positief bindend studieadvies heeft ontvangen.  2. Toelating tot het vak ‘bachelor thesis’, ‘bachelorscriptie’, ‘bachelorwerkstuk’, en/of ‘bachelorproject’ kan uitsluitend plaatsvinden nadat de student bachelor-2 volledig heeft afgerond.   Studenten die niet aan de toelatingseisen voldoen, maar toch het Bachelorproject willen volgen, moeten hiertoe een verzoek indienen bij de Examencommissie. Aan te raden is om dit ruim vóór aanvang van het vak te doen. Voor specifieke vragen kan men zich wenden tot mevr. Nathanja Boers via het contactformulier van het Onderwijsbureau Bestuurskunde en Sociologie.  De bachelor opleiding (en dus het Bachelorproject) dient succesvol te zijn afgerond om toegelaten te kunnen worden tot de master opleiding. Voor aanvullende instroomeisen voor de master, zie het OER.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

During the Bachelor thesis, students will work individually or in small groups on a literature review or an empirical study about a topic of their choice. Topics will be offered by the Psychology teaching staff. Teachers will supervise students during both the data/literature collection process, and the writing process. Furthermore, during the writing process, students will be supported through feedback from fellow students.

As a rule of thumb, literature reviews will include approximately 30 scientific references and will cover 20 pages (line space 1.5) or approximately 7000 words. This word count is excluding title page and references.
Empirical studies will include approximately 20 scientific references and will cover 13 pages (line space 1.5) or approximately 4500 words. This word count is excluding title page and references.

During the library practicals, students will learn to use advanced search techniques to find scientific information on a specific research question. In addition, students will learn to use reference software (RefWorks and Write-N-Cite)

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Being able to answer a research question based on empirical research or a scientific literature review is central to the Bachelor thesis. The Bachelor thesis is part of the academic writing trajectory, which is comprised of the following: year 1: Writing Skills I, year 2: Writing Skills II, year 3: Bachelor thesis, year 4: Master thesis. Within this trajectory, students first learn about basic writing skills (such as structuring paragraphs and creating links between paragraphs), after which they learn more advanced skills (such as sound argumentation based on scientific sources or data, as well as creating links between various sources). A second important skill used in academic writing is the giving and processing of feedback. Finally, a series of library practicals is featured in which students learn how they can systematically get an overview of scientific literature within a specific field of research.

column1: The Bachelor’s Thesis Class offers students guidance in formulating an appropriate and relevant research question and in structuring and conducting research in the field of Arts and Culture Studies. After the BA Thesis Class, students are able to conduct a theoretically informed empirical study and report on this research in their BA thesis.
As for the Bachelor’s Thesis, students are expected to perform the following activities independently under the supervision of a lecturer:
•             Demarcate and study a particular subject in the field of Arts and Culture Studies
•             Formulate a relevant and appropriate definition of the problem and research questions derived from this
•             Draw up a research structure outline, perform and document research
•             Write a thesis that meets academic requirements in terms of substance, composition, and language

Na afloop van de thesis class zijn studenten in staat hun thesis zelfstandig af te maken.

column1: The thesis in an individual piece of research about a subject that fits in with the International Bachelor programme Econometrics and Operations Research, and the International Bachelor programme in Economics and Business Economics. More information about topics, supervisors and the writing process can be found on the thesis hub on Canvas.
You use knowledge from one of the major seminars in Econometrics and Operations Research and in Economics and Business Economics.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• The student demonstrates that he/she can independently conduct research, and execute the different phases of research (formulating a research question, choosing the research design, choosing and executing the research methods, gathering data, drawing conclusions and giving advice based on the results).

column1: <body>This course aims at training and improving students’ academic writing skills and will result in an academic paper of 4,000 words (footnotes, bibliography and appendices not included). This course will guide students through the various stages of writing a larger academic paper, such as: finding and selecting relevant literature and sources; phrasing a research question; planning, drafting and revising the manuscript and using references. Attention will also be paid to research ethics and scholarly integrity. The tutorials will outline and introduce main issues of academic writing and will support the research and writing process. The final result of this course is a well-structured essay which answers a self-selected research question by means of a critical analysis of secondary literature. The paper is written in correct English or Dutch and uses correct references and citations.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104766,2022,Bachelorstage,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['FS Dolgunca', 'J Pels']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In het tweede jaar van de bachelor sociologie loop je tien weken lang stage. De stage heeft tot doel op academisch niveau inzicht te verwerven in, en ervaring op te doen met, de praktijk van sociologische werkzaamheden. In de stage werk je in opdracht van derden, in de meeste gevallen buiten de universiteit.

Naast dat je de kennis die je in de afgelopen anderhalf jaar hebt opgedaan gaat toepassen in de praktijk, biedt de stage je ook de mogelijkheid om te werken aan jouw professionele vaardigheden. Dit begint al in blok 1 en 2. In september vindt er een introductiecollege plaats en in oktober volg je een Sollicitatie- en CV training zodat je goed voorbereid contact kunt gaan leggen met potentiële stage-organisaties. Tijdens de stage zelf verbeter je ook professionele vaardigheden; bijvoorbeeld door te leren zo helder mogelijk jouw inzichten over te dragen aan mensen die (vaak) geen socioloog zijn. Maar de stage biedt ook de kans je op de arbeidsmarkt te oriënteren en relevante contacten op te doen.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Het toepassen van verworven sociologische kennis in de praktijk.
• Het verwerven en verbeteren van professionele vaardigheden.
• Het kritisch kunnen reflecteren op jouw eigen functioneren, dat van de collega’s op de stageplek en van de stage-verlenende instelling in de praktijk.
• Het opbouwen van een persoonlijk netwerk, dat zowel bij verder onderzoek in het kader van de bachelor- en masterscriptie als na afloop van de studie behulpzaam kan zijn.

column1: In de stageperiode kunnen studenten verworven pedagogische kennis en vaardigheden toepassen in de beroepspraktijk. De beroepspraktijk is gevarieerd en een stage kan dan ook verschillende invullingen krijgen. De student kan kiezen uit twee vormen:

column2: De praktijkstage: Een praktijkstage houdt in dat je met een pedagoog of onderwijskundige meeloopt om zo een beter beeld te krijgen over de werkzaamheden en werkwijze van die instelling. Naast het meekijken is het ook de bedoeling dat je, onder begeleiding, leert om je verkregen pedagogische kennis en vaardigheden toe te passen in de praktijk.

De onderzoeksstage: Een onderzoeksstage kun je zowel intern (binnen de afdeling Pedagogische Wetenschappen) als extern (binnen een andere instelling of organisatie) doen. Een interne onderzoeksstage houdt in dat het onderwerp van het onderzoek is gekoppeld aan de onderzoeksgebieden van de opleiding Pedagogische Wetenschappen. Bij een externe stage werkt de student mee aan onderzoeksvragen die aangedragen zijn vanuit de externe instelling of organisatie.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106721,2022,Bankenrecht,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr. CFE Sullivan', 'mr.drs. RE van Lambalgen', 'prof.dr. KWH Broekhuizen']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Dit vak draait in hoofdzaak om de publiekrechtelijke regulering van de bancaire sector. Het gaat over zogenoemd microprudentieel toezichtrecht en macroprudentieel toezichtrecht. Microprudentieel toezicht bevat regels die ervoor moeten zorgen dat banken financieel gezond (solide) zijn én blijven. Om financiële gezondheid te bestendigen, bevat het microprudentiële toezicht allerlei regels over risicobeheersing en andere regels met betrekking tot een goede besturing van banken (governance-regels). Macroprudentieel toezicht richt zich op de stabiliteit van het financiële stelsel. In het vak wordt ruim aandacht besteed aan de kredietcrisis uit 2008, maar wordt bijvoorbeeld ook uitvoerig stilgestaan bij klimaatrisico’s. En vanzelfsprekend zal ook worden nagedacht over de vraag wat een pandemie zoals Corona kan betekenen in de context van soliditeit en stabiliteit.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• De student begrijpt de kernfuncties van banken en kan uitleggen welke bijzondere soliditeitsrisico’s daaraan zijn verbonden.

• De student kan uitleggen wat onder financiële stabiliteit wordt verstaan, wat systeemrisico’s zijn en op welke wijzen banken deze risico’s kunnen veroorzaken respectievelijk daaraan onderworpen kunnen zijn.
• De student kan de redenen van prudentiële toezichtregelgeving overzien, mede in de context van het reduceren van de kans op respectievelijk het beteugelen van financiële crises.
• De student kan de diverse rollen van relevante internationale, Europese en nationale toezichthoudende autoriteiten duiden.
• De student ziet in welke dynamiek kan bestaan tussen regelgeving enerzijds en toezicht in de praktijk anderzijds en kan deze beoordelen.
• De student kan uit nationaal, Europees en financieel toezichtrecht de relevante prudentiële normen destilleren en complexe casusposities oplossen respectievelijk daarover adviseren.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Instructor: Prof. E.C. Perotti (UvA), Dr S. Terovitis (UvA), X. Wang (UvA)

The course reviews the literature on financial intermediation and is relevant for students interested in finance, macroeconomics, and governance. It combines a classic contractual approach with recent work on system-wide risk creation. Drawing from the lesson of the crisis, it focuses on the risk transformation role of banks and shadow banks and the sources of endogenous credit cycles and instability. A key goal is to offer foundations for micro and macro-prudential policy reform, drawing from models of opportunism, risk externalities, or behavioral biases. Topics include debt optimality, moral hazard in risk choices, financial externalities, maturity and liquidity risk transformation, endogenous risk, induced runs, demand for safety, and their implications for capital and liquidity regulation.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students should have an understanding of, ability to apply, judge, and communicate

column2: • The nature of financial intermediation in terms of its effectiveness of mobilizing resources while creating occasional instability
• Theoretical explanations for bank balance sheet structure, insight in the essential task of liquidity transformation
• Modern foundations of demand for safety as a driver of bank funding and instability
• The structural difference between banks and shadow banking business models

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/108820,2022,Banking and Financial Institutions,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. WB Wagner'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This elective examines the business of banks, and other financial institutions. We will analyze how banks carry out their business, what risks they are subject to, and how these risks can be managed. Besides commercial banks, we will also study how investment banks operate and how new developments in fintech interact with traditional banking. A central focus of the course is also on financial innovation (such as credit derivatives and securitization) and how they are used by financial institutions. Finally, we study financial crises and how regulation can mitigate the risk of failures in the financial system.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After having followed this course, students are able to:

column2: • Recognize, understand and explain the key risks in banking;
• Understand and apply modern analytical methods for bank management;
• Understand and explain how regulation affects banks and what the limits to regulation are;
• Be able to analyze the operation of a single bank in a systemic context;
• Recognize, understand and explain recent trends in banking.

column1: The Basestone Research & Writing Project brings together all skills taught in Quad 1 through 3. The aim of this course is to give the students an opportunity to perform a group research project to investigate a pressing societal challenge (i.e., the basestone), to summarise the results in a research report, and present the results of the project. In doing so, this course will help students further develop their writing and research skills that are needed to complete a basestone project. The course comprises a supervised research project supported and complemented by class and supervisory discussions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course will introduce you to the wide, beautiful and interesting world of chemistry. The purpose of this course is to provide a basic knowledge of fundamental chemistry, which can be applied in ensuing LSC courses, such as Biochemistry and Molecular & Cellular Biology. After completing this course, you will understand the periodic table including groups, compounds, metals and non-metals. You will learn about atomic and molecular theories, chemical reactivity and bonding, chemical equilibria, acids and bases theories, solutions, thermodynamics, nuclear chemistry and nomenclature of organic chemistry. Many examples will be drawn from chemical, biological, and medical applications to show you the connections between these scientific disciplines.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completing this course, you will be able to:

column2: • Explain what is atom and able to write electronic configurations of elements
• Explain what is the Periodic Table and name periodic trends
• Name ionic and molecular compounds and write their formulas
• Explain which type of bonding exist between chemical substances
• Understand the properties of liquids and solids
• Name types of solutions and calculate various concentrations
• Calculate different chemical quantities and apply them in the chemical reactions
• Distinguish among different types of reaction and balance chemical equations
• Explain what is the chemical equilibrium and relations between reaction rate and equilibrium constant
• Understand acids-bases concepts and calculate pH of solutions and dissociation constant
• Distinguish between oxidation and reduction reactions and be familiar with electrochemistry
• Understand basics of nuclear chemistry, types of radiation and nuclear reactions
• Classify and name organic and biochemical compounds and draw their structural formulas and isomers

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This 2-day course will explain basic concepts in human genetics and includes some history, basic knowledge of molecular biology, introduction to Mendelian and complex genetics, technical aspects and applications of sequencing and array technologies in genetics and the use of DNA technologies in society. Mendelian genetics will address different approaches to detect mutations in families segregating hereditary diseases, complex genetics will discuss the history and applications of genome wide association studies in populations.
At this moment we are considering a digital form for this course through Microsoft Teams, with live (not pre-recorded) presentations and interactions.

The target audience may come from various disciplines and different backgrounds with an interest in genetic studies in families or populations but do not have the necessary genetic background knowledge.

Students who have followed the NIHES Erasmus Summer Programme ESP57 (“Genomics in Molecular Medicine”) do not have to follow this course because for ESP57 you are expected to already have a basic knowledge level of genetics.

This course is meant to give some introductory background for people wanting to start or become involved in such studies, or just want to know what it is all about. There is ample time for Questions and Answers during and after each talk. Some presentations will have a small quiz to test your knowledge at that point. This short course is also very useful as a step-up for the more advanced “SNP course” which covers a much wider and deeper range of topics in this rapidly evolving field.
The following books can used as reference books for basic knowledge of (molecular) biology (no need to read all of it beforehand):

column2: • ‘Genetics for Dummies’ (2nd ed.; T.R. Robinson, Wiley Publishing, Inc.; ISBN 978-0-470-55174-5, 2010)
• ‘Molecular & Cell Biology for Dummies’ (2nd ed.; R Fester Kratz, ISBN-10: 1119620406, aug 2020)
• ‘Molecular Biology of the Cell’ (6th ed.; Alberts et al.; published by Garland Sciences; ISBN 978-0-815-34432-2, 2015)
• ‘The Problems Book: for molecular biology of the cell’ (5th ed.; W. W. Norton & Company; 5th ed.; ISBN-10: 0815344538, 2015);
• ""Human Molecular Genetics"" (5th ed.; Tom Strachan & Andrew Reed; published by Taylor & Francis Ltd.; ISBN-10: 0815345895, dec 2018).

column1: This course will bring you across a journey that connects some of the most pressing challenges of our time with the basic knowledge in life sciences. For this, we will start by defining what ‘life’ actually is, and how it is organised. Specifically, the overall organisation of living organisms and their characteristics will be covered. We will zoom into the various classes of biomolecules and the way in which they are produced and metabolised within living cells. We will then focus on how life “works”, by discussing the fundamentals of DNA replication, the genetic code, cell division and genetics. Finally, we will zoom out and study the most vital aspects of the organisation of higher animals and plants and the evolution and ecology of living organisms on Earth.

column1: Bayesian Econometrics plays an important role in quantitative economics, marketing research and finance. This course discusses the basic tools which are needed to perform Bayesian analyses. It starts with a discussion on the difference between Bayesian and frequentist statistical approach. Next, Bayesian parameter inference, forecasting and Bayesian testing is considered, where we deal with univariate models, multivariate models and panel data models (Hierarchical Bayes techniques). To perform a Bayesian analysis, knowledge of advanced simulation methods is necessary. Part of the course is devoted to Markov Chain Monte Carlo sampling methods including Gibbs sampling, data augmentation and Monte Carlo integration. The topics are illustrated using simple computer examples which are demonstrated during the lectures.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The students learns the basics of Bayesian statistics (how to derive the posterior distribution)
• The students learn how to conduct Bayesian inference in econometric models.
• The students learn the concepts of Bayesian testing, point estimation and forecasting.
• The students learn how to interpret and use the outcomes resulting from the Bayesian analysis for decision making.
• The students learns the basics of simulation based inference and how to apply these methods for Bayesian inference in advanced econometric/statistical models.

column1: Bayesian Econometrics plays an important role in finance, where taking proper care of uncertainty is crucial for decision making. This course discusses the basic tools which are needed to perform Bayesian analyses. It starts with a discussion on the difference between Bayesian and frequentist statistical approach. Next, Bayesian parameter inference, forecasting and Bayesian testing is considered, where we deal with univariate models, multivariate models and panel data models (Hierarchical Bayes techniques). To perform a Bayesian analysis, knowledge of advanced simulation methods is necessary. Part of the course is devoted to Markov Chain Monte Carlo sampling methods including Gibbs sampling, data augmentation and Monte Carlo integration. The topics are illustrated using simple computer examples which are demonstrated during the lectures.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• The students learn how to conduct Bayesian inference in econometric models.
• The students learn the concepts of Bayesian testing, point estimation and forecasting.
• The students learn how to interpret and use the outcomes resulting from the Bayesian analysis for decision making.
• The students learns the basics of simulation based inference and how to apply these methods for Bayesian inference in advanced econometric/statistical models.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this two-day course, students will be (re)familiarized with the basics of probability theory and introduced into Bayesian statistics. One of the main benefits of Bayesian statistics is that, in contrast to frequentist statistics and the null hypothesis significance test, it allows you to quantify the evidence in favor of the alternative hypothesis and the null hypothesis, thus distinguishing absence of evidence from evidence of absence. The students will be educated in the Bayesian alternative to standard statistical tests, such as the t-test and regression. A significant amount of time will be allocated to assignments and evaluation to ensure that the students receive hands-on experience with this approach to statistics. In addition, students can bring their own data to analyze under the supervision of the teacher.

column2: • Bayesian statistics makes use of a more intuitive form of probability. Namely, uncertainty instead of frequencies of values under a particular distribution (p-values).
• It can incorporate prior beliefs, knowledge, or results of parameters in the analysis.
• It enables comparison of the likelihood of the alternative hypothesis in relation to the null hypothesis as an odds ratio (instead of testing only the null hypothesis in frequentist statistics).
• Results are not based on unobserved data (Frequentist statistics assume hypothetical data under the null hypothesis).
• It is not influenced by sampling design.
• It allows for continual data collection until either the null or the alternative hypothesis is acceptably likely.
• Students will have a basic understanding of the basis and practice of Bayesian statistics and inference.
• They will know the basics of probability theory and the theoretical and philosophical underpinning of Bayesian statistics.
• They will be familiar with the Bayesian counterparts of basic classical tests, such as, linear regression, ANOVA, t-test, etc.
• They will have gained intimate knowledge of the software package JASP.
• They will be able to confidently use basic and more advanced statistical analysis using both frequentist and Bayesian statistics.

column1: Introductory knowledge of statistics is required and some knowledge of data analysis in a statistical software package (e.g., SPSS, R, Excel) is recommended.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Naast een algemene introductie in de uitgangspunten van de interne en externe verslaggeving, waarbij ook het jaarrekeningenrecht aan de orde komt, wordt tijdens het eerste deel van dit vak vooral aandacht besteed aan het boekhoudmodel. Geoefend wordt met het maken van journaalposten en het opstellen van een balans en een winst- en verliesrekening. Daarbij worden de verschillende onderdelen van de balans en de winst- en verliesrekening verder uitgediept: eigen vermogen, vreemd vermogen, opbrengsten en kosten. Er wordt gewerkt met verschillende methoden om in de onderneming aanwezige voorraden te administreren. Daarnaast wordt in dit deel geoefend met het opstellen van een kasstroomoverzicht. In samenhang met het voorgaande wordt ook aandacht besteed aan de financiële analyse van de onderneming.

In het tweede deel van het vak ligt de nadruk op de aansluiting tussen de bedrijfseconomie en het fiscale recht. Eerst komen daarbij de ondernemingen in groepsverband, de concerns, aan de orde. Geoefend wordt met het consolideren van jaarrekeningen, waarbij de balansen en winst- en verliesrekeningen van twee of meer ondernemingen worden samengevoegd tot één geheel. Hierbij worden ook de fiscale concernbepalingen behandeld. Daarna komen de verschillen tussen de bedrijfseconomische en de fiscale jaarrekening aan de orde, evenals de fiscale winstbepaling door middel van vermogensvergelijking. Ten slotte wordt aandacht besteed aan de verwerking van de belastingen in de bedrijfseconomische jaarrekening in de vorm van belastinglatenties.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Belastingheffing van ondernemingen vindt plaats op grond van de fiscale jaarwinst. Bij het vaststellen van de fiscale jaarwinst vormt de bedrijfseconomische jaarrekening meestal het uitgangspunt. Daarom is kennis en begrip van dit onderdeel van de bedrijfseconomie onmisbaar voor de fiscale praktijk.

column2: • Kun je journaalposten maken en een (geconsolideerde) balans, winst- en verliesrekening en een kasstroomoverzicht;
• Kun je een eenvoudige financiële analyse van een onderneming maken;
• Ben je in staat om de verschillen tussen bedrijfseconomische en de fiscale winst te berekenen;
• Kun je de belastbare winst en het belastbaar bedrag op basis van een vermogensvergelijking bepalen;
• Ben je in staat belastinglatenties te bepalen en deze te verwerken in de jaarrekening;
• Kun je fiscaal relevante berekeningen in een begrijpelijk betoog weergeven.

column3: Naast een algemene introductie in de uitgangspunten van de interne en externe verslaggeving, waarbij ook het jaarrekeningenrecht aan de orde komt, wordt tijdens het eerste deel van dit vak vooral aandacht besteed aan het boekhoudmodel. Geoefend wordt met het maken van journaalposten en het opstellen van een balans en een winst- en verliesrekening. Daarbij worden de verschillende onderdelen van de balans en de winst- en verliesrekening verder uitgediept: eigen vermogen, vreemd vermogen, opbrengsten en kosten. Er wordt gewerkt met verschillende methoden om in de onderneming aanwezige voorraden te administreren. Daarnaast wordt in dit deel geoefend met het opstellen van een kasstroomoverzicht. In samenhang met het voorgaande wordt ook aandacht besteed aan de financiële analyse van de onderneming.

In het tweede deel van het vak ligt de nadruk op de aansluiting tussen de bedrijfseconomie en het fiscale recht. Eerst komen daarbij de ondernemingen in groepsverband, de concerns, aan de orde. Geoefend wordt met het consolideren van jaarrekeningen, waarbij de balansen en winst- en verliesrekeningen van twee of meer ondernemingen worden samengevoegd tot één geheel. Hierbij worden ook de fiscale concernbepalingen behandeld. Daarna komen de verschillen tussen de bedrijfseconomische en de fiscale jaarrekening aan de orde, evenals de fiscale winstbepaling door middel van vermogensvergelijking. Ten slotte wordt aandacht besteed aan de verwerking van de belastingen in de bedrijfseconomische jaarrekening in de vorm van belastinglatenties.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Belastingheffing van ondernemingen vindt plaats op grond van de fiscale jaarwinst. Bij het vaststellen van de fiscale jaarwinst vormt de bedrijfseconomische jaarrekening meestal het uitgangspunt. Daarom is kennis en begrip van dit onderdeel van de bedrijfseconomie onmisbaar voor de fiscale praktijk.

column2: • Kun je journaalposten maken en een (geconsolideerde) balans, winst- en verliesrekening en een kasstroomoverzicht;
• Kun je een eenvoudige financiële analyse van een onderneming maken;
• Ben je in staat om de verschillen tussen bedrijfseconomische en de fiscale winst te berekenen;
• Kun je de belastbare winst en het belastbaar bedrag op basis van een vermogensvergelijking bepalen;
• Ben je in staat belastinglatenties te bepalen en deze te verwerken in de jaarrekening;
• Kun je fiscaal relevante berekeningen in een begrijpelijk betoog weergeven.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Beeldvorming is een gecompliceerd sociaal, cognitief en psychologisch proces waarbij mensen zich (denk)beelden vormen over verschijnselen in de werkelijkheid. Tekstuele, visuele en auditieve representaties verspreid en herhaald via diverse media spelen een dominante rol in de sociale constructie van werkelijkheid. Welke verhalen vertellen deze teksten en beelden  over onze hedendaagse wereld, over de Ander, over onszelf? Welke verhalen en beelden zijn dominant en in hoeverre bevestigen zij bestaande stereotypen en machtsverhoudingen? Een belangrijk deel van de cursus zal gewijd zijn aan verhaal- en beeldanalyses van speelfilms, documentaires en fotografie. De actualiteit biedt altijd voldoende aanknopingspunten om een kritische en analytische blik te ontwikkelen ten aanzien van beelden en mediale beeldvormingsprocessen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Studenten hebben kennis van en inzicht in:

column2: • Het sociaal-psychologisch proces van beeldvorming via media en de wijzen waarop 'beelden' van de actuele werkelijkheid door media worden geproduceerd, gecultiveerd en geframed;
• De belangrijkste theoretische en analytische benaderingen van diverse visuele vormen van beeldvorming
• Het toepassen van relevante theoretische inzichten in de werking en analyse van beelden uit de actualiteit
• Kritisch reflecteren op (onderzoek naar) processen van beeldvorming en de rol van media daarin.

Het huidige blok M1.2 bouwt logischerwijs voort op je vorderingen in Blok M1.1 en richt zich op hoe problematische opvoedings- en leersituaties positief kunnen beïnvloed worden en dit vanuit het perspectief van een meervoudig risicomodel, vanuit de verschillende invalshoeken zoals die vertegenwoordigd worden in het meervoudig risicomodel, Dit is analoog aan de brede blik van de orthopedagoog: hij/zij heeft oog voor niet alleen de problematiek of zelfs crisissituatie op basis waarvan de verwijzing heeft plaatsgevonden, maar ook voor beschermende en verder bedreigende factoren (e.g. traumatische gebeurtenissen, mate van sociale steun, persoonlijkheidskenmerken, ) in de verschillende contexten waarin de problematiek zich voordoet (kind-, gezins- en wijdere omgevingsniveau).

column1: Behavioral decision theory incorporates commonly found deviations from rationality in decision models.  People are driven by emotions and use simplifying heuristics rather than advanced optimization. We thus observe excessive risk aversion in overly prudent investments and in the equity premium puzzle. At the same time, risk seeking underlies public lotteries, speculation, entrepreneurial activities, and the absence of sufficient security measures in health and business. People systematically lose money due to inconsistencies in their intertemporal and risky decisions (arbitrage). We analyze these phenomena quantitatively, indicating possibilities to benefit from irrationalities in decisions, to nudge or improve decisions. Applications are given to finance, marketing, management science, health economics, and: your private life. This course is advanced, quantitative, and prescriptively oriented. It is nevertheless accessible to students with no maths background.
The material of this course comprises fewer pages than for other courses, but takes more time and requires better understanding per page than for other courses.
The course has 10 weekly sessions. All sessions will be in class, but for the first six presence is voluntary and not compulsory. For the last four, presence in class is compulsory.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Modeling, avoiding/exploiting irrationalities in human decision making; providing tools to nudge or convince others of best decisions</body>
