column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Het zenuwstelsel vormt de basis van ons waarnemen, denken, voelen en doen. In dit blok wordt ingegaan op de relatie tussen de werking van het zenuwstelsel enerzijds en overt en covert gedrag anderzijds. Daartoe wordt allereerst gekeken naar de anatomie en werking van het centrale en perifere zenuwstelsel, alsmede naar de principes van neurotransmissie. Vervolgens zal aandacht worden besteed aan de onderzoeksmethoden die in de biologische psychologie worden gebruikt. Naast onderzoek met reeds langer bestaande elektrofysiologische methoden, zoals EEG, ECG en meting van de huidgeleiding, is er het afgelopen decennium veel fascinerend onderzoek gedaan met behulp van moderne beeldvormende technieken zoals fMRI, MEG, en PET. De werking van deze technieken, en wat er mee kan worden onderzocht zullen in dit blok aan bod komen. Daarna zal worden ingegaan op de hersencircuits voor perceptie, cognitie, emotie en motoriek.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Doel van dit blok is het verwerven van kennis van en inzicht in de biologische basis van perceptie, cognitie, emotie en gedrag. Naast biopsychologische mechanismen, komen ook de specifieke neurowetenschappelijke onderzoekstechnieken aan bod.

column1: This module follows on module 1.5 Developmental Psychology and deals in greater depth with the biological origin of learning and behavior. The module examines the relationship between functioning of the nervous system on the one hand, and overt and covert behaviour on the other. First, students will study the anatomy and functioning of the central and peripheral nervous system, the principles of neurotransmission, and plasticity of the nervous system. Later, biological foundations of memory, learning, emotions, stress, and sleep are discussed. The program will cover the research methods used in biological psychology.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <div>At the end of the course student will be able to:

column2: • Describe the anatomy, the development and the function of the central nervous system
• Describe the relevance of the theory of evolution for pedagogical sciences
• Describe the biological underpinnings of memory, learning, emotions, stress and sleep

column1: Research Master and PhD students (and others) often experience that not all expertise for biomedical techniques or essays they need to perform for their research project is readily available in their department. The organization of the Graduate school offers a wonderful opportunity to exchange this expertise. Therefore, the course ‘Biomedical Research Techniques’ is organized to create an overview of techniques routinely used in the various departments. This course is also part of the Research MSc Infection & Immunity.
The program is organized according to a logical order in 5 steps: DNA, RNA, Proteome, Cell, Tissue and Organ.
This implies the following program in 5 days:

column2: • Day 1: primers and probes, sequencing, SNP-analysis, methylation
• Day 2: RNA, RNA expression arrays, RT PCR, siRNA, data mining (morning) and site visit core facilities labs genomics (afternoon)
• Day 3: proteomes, mass spectrometry (morning) and site visits to the mass spectrometry facilities (afternoon)
• Day 4: Flow cytometry, Cytotoxicity & Multi-parameter assays (morning); microscopy: quantitative confocal microscopy, image analysis, FRET, FRAP & computer modeling (afternoon)
• Day 5: Applied Molecular Imaging: MRI, CT, Nuclear, Optical in vivo (morning); BSL Lab and Pathology services (afternoon)

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: As a PhD candidate, you have to get your research published to share it with a wider audience. But writing a paper can be daunting. During the writing process, there’s a lot you have to get right. Of course, it is important to represent your research accurately. However, it is equally important to do so in a way that is accessible and engages your readers. This course is to help you feel capable and confident when you navigate this complex task. Topics we will address include the writing process, scientific structure, paragraph organisation, language flow, giving and receiving feedback, and, most importantly, reader-friendliness.

This course is only open to PhD students who are in the process of writing a PhD thesis or academic article. Participants must be able to produce examples of their own written work, as this will be a part of the material used in the course.
Workshops, self-study, peer feedback, group discussion
Please note that for the course English level C1 or IELTS 7.0 score is required.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course is geared towards writing effective research papers. It is designed to help participants become aware of what it is that makes a text accessible and engaging for the audience, and it will help them apply this knowledge in practice. During the course, participants will be handed a range of practical
tools to make their writing more effective on text, paragraph, and sentence level.
This course aims to achieve the following learning goals:
1. To use language and style appropriate for scientific communication
2. To write accessibly, using different strategies to achieve cohesion and flow
3. To make optimal use of the different sections in a formal biomedical research paper
4. To look critically at the work of others and give feedback effectively
All participants are expected to follow each week’s class. In addition, all assignments must be completed by the deadlines.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Is euthanasie bij diep demente personen moreel toelaatbaar? Wanneer moeten artsen bij medisch begeleide voortplanting verzoeken om nieuwe technieken in te zetten weigeren? Bestaat er zoiets als een morele plicht om weesmedicijnen te financieren en te vergoeden? Wat horen overheid, industrie en individuen te doen om problemen als obesitas of orgaandonatie op te lossen? Zijn nieuwe technieken om menselijke  vermogens (cognitie, sociaal gedrag, stemming, uiterlijk) te verbeteren wel moreel wenselijk?

Biomedische ethiek en volksgezondheidsethiek zijn interessante en complexe onderzoeksvelden. Als discipline bevatten ze uiteenlopende theoretische benaderingen maar elke aanpak focust op concrete gevallen en probeert de uitdagingen waarmee de medische wetenschappen ons confronteren op te pakken en een zinvolle bijdrage te leveren aan het doordenken en beslechten ervan. In deze cursus worden prangende bio-ethische kwesties bestudeerd en onderzocht hoe theoretische benaderingen, concepten en methoden kunnen helpen om met die kwesties om te gaan. U wordt uitgedaagd om actief uw beredeneerde standpunt te bepalen en te verdedigen in discussies met uw medestudenten.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Aanwezigheid bij de colleges is verplicht. Bij afwezigheid maakt de student een vervangende opdracht.

Het kunnen identificeren en analyseren van ethische kwesties in de gezondheidszorg, bijvoorbeeld issues rond medisch begeleide voortplanting, beslissingen rond het levenseinde, of het gebruik van nieuwe genetische technieken.
Een beter begrip ontwikkelen van sleutelconcepten, waarden en theorieën die relevant zijn voor de gezondheidszorg, zoals autonomie, competentie, informed consent, paternalisme, ziekte en gezondheid.

Het kunnen reflecteren op een moreel probleem op het vlak van gezondheidsethiek door de argumenten voor en tegen mogelijke antwoorden te onderzoeken, als basis voor een redelijk en te rechtvaardigen oordeel.
Het kritisch kunnen reflecteren op de eigen morele overtuiging en in staat zijn de eigen aanbevolen handelwijze te rechtvaardigen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: During the second half of the nineteenth and the first half of the twentieth century the way societies viewed themselves changed. With the rise of nationalism came a remarkably biological view of human groups, that was inspired by half-understood advances made in biology at roughly the same time. The desire to categorise people in a small number of races, and to delineate belonging to a nation or state in terms of heredity, led to tremendous changes. It contributed greatly to some of the most gruesome acts of violence and genocide the world has ever seen. But is also inspired innovations in food policy, maternal healthcare and the rise of the welfare state.
In this course, we will unpick the ways in which “biopower” (the term was invented by Michel Foucault) created much of the modern world, as well as many aspects of our current societies.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This course aims to introduce students to era(s) of high imperialsim and total war through the spectre of biologically-inspired ideology and policy. In each lectuire, we will discuss an aspect of biopower at work. As we do so, students will be trained in reading academic papers, improve their writing, and be forced to think about methodology a great deal.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The block seminar is s a one-week course within the CEMS programme that takes place at the beginning of Term 1 at all CEMS schools. Block Seminars bring together professors and students from various CEMS institutions. Subjects derive from different cultural and academic perspectives; many topics are not a part of the universities’ standard curricula.

The Block Seminar is a mandatory element of the programme and accounts for 3 EC and students receive a letter grade for the Block Seminar in their CEMS curricular progress. For the MSc International Management curriculum, it is evaluated based on pass/fail.

RSM offers two parallel Block Seminars in cooperation with CEMS social partner & RSM corporate partner, the European Space Agency. The first block seminar, The Entrepreneurial Challenge: Turning Technology into Business (TTB) focuses on developing a (non-space) business application of a European Space Agency (ESA) technology. It learns the students about entrepreneurship and developing new, viable businesses. The second block seminar is about strategy consulting and to support entrepreneurs with the development of their new business.
Students are assigned to teams of 4-6 persons and as a team they work on a group assignment.

For the module TTB, the assignment is to develop a viable business concept using space technology. The business concept needs to be presented at the end of the working week. For the module NVC, the assignment is to provide entrepreneurs with actionable recommendations how to improve their new business. These recommendations also need to be presented at the end of the week.

The group project is a joint effort. This means that all team members should contribute equally and fully participate throughout the week. Lecturers, facilitators and experts will support and coach the students in their assignments during the week. The quality of the final work will be graded by the course lecturers in collaboration with an independent jury.
Further details on the course organization and assignment will be provided on Canvas and during the first meeting.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Both seminars offer a great opportunity to work closely together in teams on high-tech business opportunities and to learn more about the space tech industry. At the end of the seminar students should be able to:

column2: • Understand the role and potential value of space technology and business in today's and tomorrow's world.
• Write a business plan and develop a viable business model around a new space technology (Turning Technology into Business)
• Develop strategic recommendations for entrepreneurs to support them in the successful growth of their ventures (New Venture Creation)
• Pitch their work and ideas persuasively to outsiders
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students will be assessed based on the quality of the final group work and the presentation. All students in the team will receive the same grading. RSM students will receive a pass or fail which will count towards their MSc International Management degree. In addition, they receive a letter grade for the Block Seminar in their CEMS curricular progress.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The importance of Frugal Innovation has begun to thaw; people, companies and governments are exploring and grasping the importance of embedding society within business practice to achieve longer-term survivability and positive growth prospects. The question for this three day bootcamp is how you can design an inquisitive and explorative process to tackle your field assignment. It will be the first time that the groups for the field assignments will work intensively together. Therewith the bootcamp is an important stepping stone towards a more precise formulation of your field assignment and getting the experience of working in a multidisciplinary group. At the end of the course, you present your outcomes to experts in the field. This is a high-paced, innovative course that allows you to apply your skills. As such, be prepared to work fast and think creatively!

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

column2: Define a problem by using a user story
Apply creative problem solving methods to generate unexpected ideas
Critically assess identify the riskiest assumptions underpinning your solution
Develop a proposal to test your assumptions during your field assignment
Present and pitch their solutions to real multiple (real) stakeholders
Reflect on the experience of working in a group consisting of diverse backgrounds

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/104944,2022,Brain and Cognition: Perception,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. R Zeelenberg'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In deze cursus leer je over visuele en auditieve waarneming. Je leert over theorieën over de perceptie van bijvoorbeeld contrast, beweging, kleur en objecten. Daarnaast leer je over experimentele paradigma's die onderzoekers gebruiken om perceptie en aandacht te bestuderen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Aan het einde van de cursus verwachten we dat je in staat bent tot het volgende:
•    Het beschrijven van de anatomie en fysiologie van het oog en het oor, en de structuren en processen in de hersenen die een rol spelen bij de waarneming van visuele en auditieve stimuli.
•    Uitleggen hoe mensen beslissingen nemen over de aan- of afwezigheid van een stimulus.
•    Uitleggen hoe mensen verschillen in stimulusintensiteit waarnemen.
•    Uitleggen hoe mensen kleuren waarnemen en welke tekortkomingen in kleurperceptie er zijn.
•    Het beschrijven van gangbare theorieën over hoe het cognitieve systeem visuele en auditieve elementen groepeert en interpreteert en hoe objecten en auditieve patronen worden herkend.
•    Uitleggen hoe en wanneer diepte wordt waargenomen.
•    Uitleggen hoe en wanneer beweging wordt waargenomen.
•    Het beschrijven van de (bidirectionele) relatie tussen perceptie en actie.
•    Het beschrijven van de belangrijkste paradigma's die worden gebruikt om aandacht en perceptie te bestuderen.
•    Het selecteren en interpreteren van statistische analyses van bevindingen verkregen met onderzoek dat gebruik maakt van deze paradigma's.

column1: <body>De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.</body>

column1: From a marketing standpoint, the brand is the most valuable asset of the firm. Brands embody a firm’s strategy and drive its execution. As such, managing and developing a brand is a complex task, that requires sharp critical-thinking skills, an advanced understanding of marketing concepts, and an imaginative mind.

The goal of this course is to equip students with the fundamentals of brand development through a mix of research-driven frameworks, case-based discussions, and hands-on projects. After taking this course, students will possess a solid understanding of how, why, and when brands drive value; in-depth knowledge of the opportunities, issues, and challenges a brand can face throughout its life; the ability to critically evaluate brand positions and branding decisions.

This course is of particular relevance to students who destined themselves to become brand managers, as the concepts and skills that they will learn directly relate to this executive role. Beyond this specific role, the course is also relevant to students who seek to work in strategy and/or marketing departments: Understanding the function and strategic roles of brands will help them adopt a longer-term orientation in their decisions.

As this course is the last elective of the MSc in Marketing Management, it is also designed to facilitate the transition for students from consumers of knowledge to marketing practitioners. The cases and examples developed in the lectures are specifically picked to show how the extensive knowledge of consumer behavior and marketing strategy that you have accumulated in the MSc can be used to generate novel insights for success in the marketplace.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand the strategic importance of brands to companies
• Measure brand equity and evaluate a brand’s strategic position
• Reflect on the usefulness and limitations of marketing frameworks
• Use branding decisions to drive value in heterogeneous circumstances
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: A brand is often considered to be the company’s most valuable asset, although the origin of this value resides in the mind of the consumer. This Branding course takes a strong consumer‐based view on branding, so we will discuss the foundation of branding in consumer behavior and consumer psychology. The course provides insight into how consumers perceive brands and the roles these brands play in their everyday lives.

We will look at product and service brands and we will look at brands and branding in international consumer markets as well as in international industrial markets. We will focus on the value of brands, brand associations, consumer‐brand relationships, brand building strategies, the leverage of brand value, brand architecture, and brand image measurement. Although the basis for our approach is the consumer, we will continuously translate these consumer insights into operational and strategic brand management practice.

We will build a strong theoretical foundation by studying journal articles about brands and branding, but we will continuously translate the models and concepts of this theory to practice by means of short articles from the business press, discussions on company's branding strategies (including several guest presentations by brand designers and brand managers) and practical team assignments. Apart from instructive and interesting, this course has the potential to be a lot of fun! We are confronted with brands every single day, and it is challenging to explore the processes by which these are built and communicated to you.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:
•Appraise the main academic branding theories and concepts;
•Integrate practice cases of branding to solve brand questions;
•Discuss brand logos, mantras (slogans), personalities and identities.
•Integrate branding in company and marketing strategies;
•Discuss marketing plans to introduce and position new brands.
•Discuss marketing communication plans to launch and manage brands.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Brands are often considered to be organizations’ most valuable assets, where the origin of this value resides in the mind of the customer. Establishing a brand in the customer’s mind is a crucial part of the marketing strategy of any business. This course provides insight into how customers perceive brands and the roles that a brand can play in their everyday lives. The course focuses on the importance of brands, brand associations, target population, segmentation, value proposition, brand positioning, brand building strategies and the leveraging of brand value. Students will work on an ongoing research assignment, which will be based around an established company. As such, students will design a small research study, and collect and analyze their own data to examine the associations of brands and their interactions with customers. Through giving presentations and discussion about papers, students will gain an in-depth insight into the structures that create brands, branding strategy and the manner of which brand associations are created in customers minds. Several important theories on branding will be discussed and applied to existing companies. As such, the course combines theoretical components with strong case-based components and uses numerous recent examples of the use of branding within (well-known) corporates and startups.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The development of brands, branding and brand associations.
• Focused and practical research designs and methods to examine branding strategies & practices.
• Design and execute a small-scale empirical study.
• Report on their findings in oral and written form.
• Critically reflect on the limitations and the connections made within their research.
• Evaluate their own work and others’ research work.

column1: Building my Career runs across block 1-5 and consists of various (digital) questionnaires, exercises, lectures, and other formats to prepare you for the labour market and your future career. As this preparation is not a straightforward, easy process we invite you first to start with an internal journey and learn more about yourself – in terms of personal drivers, interests and values and then find a fit with the external side – the industries. During the second part of this course you work on your personal career narrative and practice building up a personal professional network effectively in a series of workshops and assignments.

The diverse tools as used in this course will include not only job search and acquisition techniques, but also the tools for personal career development that provide the best insight into tactical decision-making; identifying and choosing from options with the goal of optimal career fulfilment now and in the future.

Using both a theoretical and practical approach, the goal of the lectures, workshops, exercises digital tools and between-class assignments is to produce competitive job candidates who enter the market well prepared to make informed career decisions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The objective of this course is to provide students with an understanding of and the tools to practice the fundamental principles underlying proactive career management. The immediate application is most evident during the post-graduation job search, but the foundational skills learned are applicable during all dynamic phases of a career.
By the end of the course, students will:

column2: • Understand the characteristics of the recruitment and application process
• Analyze strengths and weaknesses, personal values and skills as relevant for an individual student
• Identify career preparation gaps and create action points to fill the gaps
• Develop a relationship with one or more mentor and people in business
• Reflect and navigate through ethical dilemma’s

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Het burgerlijk procesrecht is als het ware het sluitstuk van het materiële privaatrecht. Hier komen civielrechtelijke vakken als het goederen- en verbintenissenrecht, samen bij het bestuderen van de wijze waarop een partij haar geschil aan de overheidsrechter kan voorleggen en een uitspraak van de rechter ten uitvoer kan leggen. Het materiële recht dient als basis voor de bestudering van het burgerlijk procesrecht. Het wordt dan ook bekend verondersteld.

Wanneer partijen een tussen hen bestaand civiel geschil niet in onderling overleg kunnen oplossen, kunnen zij hun geschil voorleggen aan de overheidsrechter. Het burgerlijk procesrecht geeft de spelregels hoe partijen hun recht kunnen verwezenlijken. In dit vak krijg je een voorproefje van de rechtspraktijk: is het verstandig om te gaan procederen, hoe kan je het nodige bewijs leveren, welke procedure kies je, hoe begin je een procedure, hoe verloopt een procedure, welke ruimte heb je als rechter om over een zaak te beslissen, hoe kan een rechterlijke uitspraak ten uitvoer worden gelegd, kan tegen de uitspraak een rechtsmiddel worden ingesteld, hoe loopt de procedure daarna verder? Je gaat ook reflecteren op de botsende belangen in een procedure. Denk aan de wens van de politiek om procedures sneller te laten verlopen enerzijds en het belang van partijen om een gedegen beslissing in hun zaak te krijgen anderzijds.

Onderdeel van het vak maakt uit het concipiëren van eenvoudige processtukken. In dit vak is er aandacht voor de procesrechtelijke eisen waaraan een processtuk moet voldoen. Deze vaardigheid zal in de quizzes worden geoefend.
Omdat geschillen zich niet tot de landsgrenzen beperken, zal enige aandacht worden besteed aan grensoverschrijdend procederen.

De procedure voor de overheidsrechter is niet altijd de meest geëigende weg om het geschil op te lossen. In het vak burgerlijk procesrecht komen daarom ook alternatieve wijzen van geschiloplossing aan de orde, zoals arbitrage, bindend advies en mediation.

Ter illustratie worden op Canvas een procesdossier en voorbeelden van processtukken geplaatst waaraan tijdens de colleges en in de quizzes wordt gerefereerd. Zo kan je nog beter kan zien ‘hoe het er werkelijk aan toe gaat’. Het bekijken van informatie op rechtspraak.nl kan daarbij ook helpen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Uitleggen welke invloed de beginselen van procesrecht hebben op de beslechting of oplossing van geschillen en beoordelen of de beginselen in de procedureregels voldoende zijn gewaarborgd.
• De procedureregels in vorderings- en verzoekzaken in eerste aanleg omschrijven en in concrete gevallen toepassen.
• De procesrechtelijke regels toepassen bij het opstellen van eenvoudige processtukken.
• De regels rond de feitenvaststelling, de bewijslevering en bewijslastverdeling omschrijven, uitleggen en in concrete gevallen toepassen.

• De mogelijkheden om een uitspraak aan te tasten, beschrijven en in concrete gevallen toepassen en de procedureregels van de procedure in verzet en hoger beroep uitleggen en in concrete gevallen toepassen.
• De maatregelen tot bewaring van rechten en executie van uitspraken omschrijven en de specifieke regels in concrete gevallen toepassen.
• De procedureregels van de voornaamste vormen van alternatieve geschilbeslechting (arbitrage, bindend advies, mediation) uitleggen en in eenvoudige zaken toepassen.
• De bronnen van de regels voor de beslechting van grensoverschrijdende geschillen omschrijven en in eenvoudige zaken toepassen.
• Het materiële recht (verbintenissenrecht en goederen- en faillissementsrecht) toepassen bij het oplossen van procesrechtelijke vraagstukken, waaronder het opstellen van processtukken.

C Zondervan', 'mr. FE van Lierop', 'mr. FM Ruitenbeek - Bart', 'mr. HV Hovhannisyan', 'mr. IJ Van Meggelen', 'mr. N Mellah', 'mr. TLC Vos', 'mr. UB Bout', 'prof.mr. column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/108155,2022,Business & Politics,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['AG Andrei, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Considering the growing impact of governments and their policies (or of structures such as the E.U.) on business, attention to politics is not only warranted but also increasingly relevant in any business study. Business & politics: a “two-way street” and a topic that is complex on multiple levels. How do Businesses and Politics mix? Should they? When it comes to this topic, companies and their boards juggle two dominant views: (1) corporate political activities are a minefield with the potential of triggering corporate crises, and (2) ignoring politics may be even riskier.

Any business leader/decision maker/professional should be aware of these complexities and learn how to navigate them while driving business change or implementing/developing business strategies. To help broaden this perspective, the course covers a wide range of topics, among which: the role and function of institutions, types of political systems, mechanisms through which politics directly and indirectly impact business environments, strategies that businesses use to have a say in policy development and decision making or even ensure their societal license to operate (the so-called non-market strategies), and an introduction to corporate governance, its role and mechanisms important in designing non-market strategies. The students will be helped in navigating all these topics though the use of instructional videos, lectures, business cases, and academic articles (required literature).

By learning about the complexities of the intersection between business and politics, students will gain a more complete toolbox to assess a business’ environment - which is wider than shareholders, customers, suppliers, etc.- and will understand how businesses may also impact societies, the environment, and policies. Having this broader perspective on business strategy, may help one think and develop better strategies, or have a positive impact on a firm’s strategy. Additionally, the course builds on and broadens the knowledge gained in courses such as Strategic Management, and Responsible Business Leaders.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After following this course, the student is able to:

column2: • Understand the business-government interface and the inventory of political strategies used by firms around the world
• Understand how politics may impact business and the relevance of a corporate political strategy
• Evaluate different non-market strategies that firms can employ and think strategically about their implementation.
• Evaluate a crisis situation within a firm and recognize the potential for developing/applying a non-market strategy.
• Define and explain what corporate governance, non-market strategies, and societal license to operate are.
• Create a high-level non-market strategy for a firm in crisis.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106053,2022,Business Analytics,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. CLP Pennings', 'dr. J van Dalen']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The business analytics course is about statistical and machine learning methods and techniques and the application of these techniques in research situations. The course has a theoretical part, which explains the background of these methods and techniques, and an applied part, which builds the skills for using them in research situations. The lectures address the theoretical background of measurement and analysis techniques and give examples of survey development and the application of data processing techniques. The weekly assignments train the programming skills to apply the techniques in practice. The group assignments embed these techniques in a relatively unstructured task to address a self-selected topic in the sustainability domain, specifically the sharing economy. The course contributes to independent evaluation and application of quantitative empirical research.
Specifically, the following topics will be covered:

column2: • General methodological topics related with causal inference, hypothesis formulation, conceptual frameworks, and measurement scales
• Classification methods using logistic regression, decision trees, random forests,  gradient boosting, and naive Bayes
• Clustering by means of k-means and hierarchical methods
• Assessing the performance of estimated models, both regression models and classification techniques
• Elementary text mining and sentiment analysis, using Tweets, news articles, and possibly other online sources
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The objective of this course is to learn quantitative empirical methods and techniques commonly used in practice, and to train the programming skills to apply these methods in research practice. In specific, the learning objectives of this course are:

column2: • Design and execute empirical research following the common stages of the empirical cycle, viz., problem definition, formulation of hypotheses, (online) data collection, preparing data for analysis, analyze and report
• Understand and apply the common statistical and analytics methods used in business, both in terms of assumptions and operation

• Ability to apply statistics and analytics in programming, involving data processing, selection and application of relevant analytical functions, collect and present the outcomes of analyses; solve non-trivial statistical problems using a programming language and environment, e.g., R and RStudio
• Demonstrate the ability to effectively communicate ideas, solution approaches, and findings to diverse stakeholders
• Critically reflect on ethical ramifications of data collection, teamwork and proposed implementations of analytical findings.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106105,2022,Business Analytics Applications with Python,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. PB Cornelius'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Business analytics is becoming a key driver of competitive advantage. Only firms that can harness their data and develop strong analytic capabilities across all their business functions will be able to survive in fast-moving modern markets. In this course, students will learn how to use Python to manage and analyse large data sets, and present and communicate the results of their analyses in a manner that makes them actionable and understandable to business managers.

Coding is a key component of this course. Students need to be comfortable writing Python code by themselves. To be able to follow this course, students need to have prior Python coding experience at the level of BM04BAM Management Science. Students need to have taken all BAM core courses beforehand (in particular Machine Learning & Learning Algorithms).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After this course, students are able to:

column2: • analyse business data using appropriate statistical models with Python (2, 4);
• interpret the results of statistical analyses and models with a focus on business implications (4, 6);
• communicate the results of statistical analyses and models in a concise and understandable manner (6).

column1: The corresponding programme-level intended learning objectives (ILOs) are in parentheses.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/105998,2022,Business Analytics PT,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. CLP Pennings', 'dr. J van Dalen']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Het vak business analytics gaat over statistische en machine learning methoden en technieken en de toepassing van deze technieken in onderzoek. Het vak heeft een theoretisch deel, dat de achtergrond van deze methoden en technieken uiteen zet, en een toegepast deel, dat de vaardigheden opbouwt om ze in onderzoek toe te passen. De hoorcolleges gaan in op de theoretische achtergrond van meet- en analysetechnieken en geven voorbeelden van het ontwikkelen van enquêtes en de toepassing van technieken op data. De wekelijkse opdrachten trainen de programmeervaardigheden om de technieken in de praktijk toe te kunnen passen. De groepsopdrachten omvatten deze technieken in een relatief ongestructureerde taak over het onderwerp deeleconomie. Het vak draagt bij aan onafhankelijke evaluatie en toepassing van kwantitatief empirisch onderzoek.
Concreet komen de volgende onderwerpen aan bod:

column2: • Algemene methodologische onderwerpen met betrekking tot causale inferentie, hypothesevorming, conceptuele kaders en meetschalen
• Classificatiemethoden met behulp van logistische regressie, beslissingsboom, random forests, gradient boosting en naive Bayes
• Clustering door middel van k-means en hiërarchische methoden
• Beoordeling van de prestaties van geschatte modellen, van zowel regressiemodellen als classificatie technieken
• Elementaire tekstmining en sentiment analyse, met behulp van tweets, nieuwsartikelen en mogelijk andere online bronnen
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Het doel van dit vak is het leren van kwantitatieve empirische methoden en technieken die in de praktijk veel worden gebruikt, en het verkrijgen van de benodigde programmeervaardigheden om deze methoden toe te passen in de onderzoekspraktijk. Specifiek zijn de leerdoelen van dit vak:

column2: • Ontwerp en uitvoer van empirisch onderzoek volgens de gangbare stadia van de empirische cyclus, namelijk probleemstelling, formulering van hypothesen, (online) dataverzameling, prepareren van data voor analyse, analyseren en rapporteren
• Begrijpen en toepassen van statistische methoden die in het bedrijfsleven veelvuldig worden gebruikt, zowel wat betreft aannames als werking

• Vaardigheid om statististische analyses toe te passen bij het programmeren, waaronder dataverwerking, selectie en toepassing van relevante analyse methoden, het verzamelen en presenteren van de resultaten van analyses; niet-triviale statistische problemen oplossen met behulp van een programmeertaal en omgeving, bijvoorbeeld met R en RStudio
• Demonstreren van het vermogen om ideeën, oplossingsgerichte aanpakken en bevindingen effectief te communiceren aan diverse belanghebbenden
• Kritisch kunnen reflecteren op de ethische gevolgen van dataverzameling, teamwerk en voorgestelde implementaties van analytische bevindingen.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106102,2022,Business Analytics Workshop,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. M Margolin, MA', 'dr. M Szymanowski', 'dr. T Kucukyilmaz']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The Business Analytics Workshop course involves completing a data analytics project for a company or organization. Together with the partner organization, teams of students formulate research questions, obtain and analyze data, and interpret and present their results.

Students are guided through the project by faculty supervisors. Guidance provided to students focuses on two domains: general skills and knowledge, and specific feedback on the project they conduct. Guidance related to general knowledge and skills focuses on project management, choice and application of research methods, and visual and oral presentation of results. In addition, students receive continuous feedback on their project progress from their peers as well as from supervisors.

Before the start of the course, students must indicate their preference for one of three tracks: (1) marketing, (2) supply chain management & business information management, or (3) accounting & finance. Based on these preferences, faculty supervisors form teams and allocate the teams to projects ahead of the course start.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course has 11 learning objectives across two domains.
A. Learning to use knowledge of business analytics in real-life situations:

column2: Formulate appropriate research questions given stakeholders' interests and practical limitations
Define data needs and obtain necessary data from relevant stakeholders
Combine appropriate analytical methods with core models of marketing, finance, operations, information systems, or accounting to analyze data
Interpret findings and formulate implications of results
Assess and provide constructive feedback on data analytics projects

column1: B. Learning complementary skills needed in data analytics projects:

column2: Develop and update a project plan and manage a project in a diverse team
Develop and follow a structured approach towards the solution of an ill-defined business problem
Communicate with relevant stakeholders to set up and manage a data analytics project
Report project progress and results to diverse audiences
Reflect on ethical aspects of a project and the own role in the project

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/107285,2022,Business Analytics for International Managers,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. MSG Quinn', 'dr. S Mehta']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The rapid growth in data generation coupled with the decrease in storage cost created new markets and business opportunities, leading to major technical and managerial challenges. But how to take advantage of these growing data, popularly known as Big Data? What framework to adopt? What model to choose? And how to draw insights from it?
Business leaders must face those challenge with new tools and methods, allowing them to implement organizational changes that are critical to shift a business towards a data-driven approach.

This course will introduce students to business analytics and their main challenges. The course will cover the fundamentals of Data Science, including data preparation, modeling, evaluation, and deployment. Specifically, students will learn how to identify data problems and opportunities and how to structure, design, and deploy data-driven solutions that provide value to the business and social sectors. Students will have hands-on experience solving practical cases using R.
While prior experience with data analysis and a statistical software is a plus, there is no requirements to take the course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The key goal of this course is to provide students with a deeper view and understanding of the concepts and methodologies used in scientific research over large datasets that can be applied and implemented in industry contexts, with direct impact on firms’ performance. After the class, students should be able to make decisions in data-driven structures, i.e.:

column2: • Know what data science method to apply to a specific problem
• Understand the whole process behind data-driven markets, from collecting data to deriving actionable insights
• Assess how shifting to a data-driven approach might pose potential ethical and regulatory hurdle depending on the firm’s industry
• Gaining practical knowledge of how to run statistical prediction models and learn how to work with R

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/106161,2022,Business Architecture and Transformation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. JR Sweeney', 'dr. MSG Quinn', 'Z Yang, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In Business Architecture & Transformation we aim to explain the role of digital and leadership capabilities within organizations and how to assess these capabilities. We will present you with the concept of operating models and demonstrate on real life examples which operating model fits which kind of company. We will explain the difference between digital operations and digital strategy. Further, we will look into how investments in IT can be assessed.   We will point out the importance of IT governance to achieve strategic alignment between IT and business. Finally, we will talk about what really makes a true management leader in IT.

While you have looked into how to strategically use information and how to design business applications in the first block of your core courses we try to give you a perspective on how you can manage IT projects on a higher level. We look into the business and management perspective of transformation processes and how strategic decisions on a CIO-level should be made.
This course is a combination of lectures, guest lecturers, in class case analysis, and discussions.

Specific course guidelines will be made available via Canvas prior to the beginning of the course and need to be read and understood by each participant. Further, the textbook for the course needs to be purchased prior to the start of the course.
The assessment of the course can be divided into 2 main parts: (1) Individual: Final Exam, and (2) Group Assignments.

Group assignments focus on transformation projects for which students will face challenges in which they need to practically apply the tools and methods that they have theoretically studied for the course. Through specific grading criteria and feedback we help students to be able to recap their work and learn from its positive as well as negative aspects.

In the final exam students are assessed based on their understanding of the complete course both from a theoretical as well as practical perspective. The exam covers all themes presented in the lectures and guest lectures as well as the complete reading material.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course Business Architecture & Transformation focuses on managing activities of information resources within firms that are crucial for firm success. Although, understanding information technologies and their role in transforming businesses is important this offers only one part of the picture. Success of firms depends on both digital and leadership capabilities.
At the end of Business Architecture & Transformation a student is able to:

column2: • Evaluate the Digital and Leadership Capabilities within an organization
• Create a Digital Strategy for an organization
• Apply the main concepts of a Digital Transformation to an organizational context
• Determine the appropriate Digital Governance Structure for an organization
• Analyze the IT Funding Guidelines of an organization

column1: The course is divided into weekly themes containing several topics per theme.</body>

column1: The financial crisis of 2008 raised public discussion about a possible lack of moral conduct in the corporate world. Ethics and compliance became terms often used in the financial sector. The pressure for financial organizations to comply with laws and regulations and implement compliance measures to live up to ethical standards is ever-increasing. Compliance measures and ‘ethics & compliance’ departments are now commonplace within the financial sector. This course will provide students with background knowledge on what business ethics means in practice for financial organizations. It will help students to better understand crucial ethics and compliance concepts and how their own ethical behavior is sometimes influenced by external factors. Being aware of these concepts can help the finance professional to have a better awareness on potential ethical issues.
For this course it is needed that students actively participate during the lectures and make the two assignments.
Workshop 1: Ethics and misconduct in the Financial Sector: Welcome to the Dark Side?

We discuss what is meant with the terms “ethics” and “compliance” in the context of a business organization. In the lecture we take a behavioral (as opposed to a philosophical) approach in order to understand what factors influence human behavior concerning ethics & compliance. What influences people towards morally good or bad decisions? We discuss different examples of misconduct from the financial sector.

We will further discuss several examples of ethical issues and compliance violations from the financial sector in an interactive way. We have studied academic articles on behavioral concepts, and we will use these to apply and deepen our knowledge gained in the first lecture.
Workshop 3: Compliance Management: Rules to protect us from the Dark Side?
We will discuss several examples on how to manage ethical behavior. We will discuss the following questions:

column2: • How can we make employees comply with laws, regulations and guidelines?
• What are the pitfalls of all these rules and controls?
• How does an organization make the best use of compliance instruments like a Code of Conduct and a whistleblowing procedure?
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After having followed this course students are able to understand important concepts of ethical behavior and how this knowledge can be used for managing compliance in an organization. After following this course students are better equipped to recognize the ethical pitfalls of dilemma situations within a working environment.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: prof. dr. W.E.H. Dullaert (VU), prof. dr. W. Stam (VU), prof. dr. ir. B.G.C. Dellaert (EUR), prof. dr. S.N. Khapova (VU), prof. dr. A. Menkveld (VU), prof. dr. M.H. Huysman (VU).

The course provides a synopsis of the types of decisions each business field faces, highlighting the most relevant topics and problems per field, as well as how data science can help to address these business problems. The broad objective of this course is to present the students with a business framework that will allow them to see how future courses relate to each other. It is not designed to answer all business questions, as the business world is much too complex to be “covered” in a single course. Instead, this course is designed to generate more questions than can be answered. The answers to those questions will come later as students proceed through the business data science curriculum all the way to their research master thesis.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to:
1. Understand the basic principles of business, including the types of decisions that each business discipline faces.
2. Explain how the various functional areas of a business (such as marketing, organization, logistic, finance) contribute to the formulation of common business decisions.
3. Identify relevant business problems per research discipline.
4. Understand how data science can be used to address these business problems.

5. Have an understanding of business that allows them to broadly read and understand the current scientific literature in business and management, and follow scientific debates across these sciences.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Fashion has often been studied from a cultural or costume history perspective. This course aims to highlight other important aspects of fashion and focuses on the fashion industry. The main objective of this minor is to gain insight into the business historical dimensions of the fashion industry and the importance of fashion for the global and local economy. It delves into the history of fashion companies and intermediaries, the economic characteristics of the fashion products and its markets. Students will thus study past and recent developments in the fashion industry. They will gain a historical, business, economic perspective of the fashion industry through a mix of lectures, seminars, guest lecturers and field trips.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The main objective is to look into the history of the fashion industry and the world behind the glamorous catwalks and shiny magazines. It aims to analyse fashion from a business history perspective, to look for similarities and differences with other industries. After completing the minor, students should have a wide-range knowledge and critical understanding of the historical, business, economic dimensions of fashion and of the particularities of fashion products, businesses, and intermediaries.</body>

column1: During the past decades, advances in information technology (IT) have fundamentally altered essential aspects of our society, our economy, and our individual lives. The Internet and digital technologies in general have radically impacted our personal and professional routines and challenged our perception of physical and social boundaries, of distance and speed, of how we want to live, work, learn, communicate, compete, collaborate, and socialize. The verdict is still out on whether digital technologies isolate us or brings us closer together, whether they provide a voice to the marginalized or help to suppress them, whether they bring about prosperity for the many or only for the few. Business plays a critical role in answering these questions since it is both, fundamentally affected by digital change and a main driver of the same. Traditional industries often struggle to adapt to this changing environment, with their business models being disrupted by new, agile competitors. Evidence can be found in the multitude of startups transforming a variety of sectors, such as energy, mobility, health, and finance. At the same time, the past decade has brought about a new set of platform-based business giants, including Google, Apple, Uber, Airbnb, and Amazon, which dominate the public discourse surrounding digitalization and raise new questions related to power and regulation in a digital world.

This course, Business Information Management acquaints students with the role of information technology in today’s economy and society. On the one hand, it provides a varied perspective on central discourses related to digitalization, such as the power of digital platforms, the boost digital technologies provide for the exchange of knowledge and ideas, but also the threat that a lack of regulation may pose. On the other hand, the course equips students with an understanding of digital technologies and with basic skills in algorithmic thinking, database management, and modelling required to thrive in today’s workplaces and academic programs. The course is offered by the Business Information Management group of RSM’s Department of Technology and Operations Management.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Discuss the evolution of digital technologies and current technological trends.
• Evaluate the impact of established and emerging digital technologies on business, society, and your personal lives.
• Apply BPMN techniques to derive a business process model for a given business process.
• Organize a database model in a systematic way using Entity-Relationship-Modelling.
• Formulate SQL queries that manipulate databases to achieve a given outcome.
• Develop basic algorithms in R that achieve a given objective.

column1: During your career as a (future) manager, you will come across with multiple types of contracts and applicable legal rules that regulate your business transactions and your company. Law and legal principles govern and influence our daily lives and business. The aim of this course is to give IBA-students a general introduction to the legal issues that manager usually will face while running an economic activity or a business unit. The goal is to provide basic insights in legal thinking and reasoning, allowing future managers to detect possible risks, flaws and opportunities legal rules can offer to their business. The course raises awareness for core principles of law.

To this end, a number of basic legal concepts, classifications and techniques are first presented (sources and principles of law). Subsequently, the aspects of private and public law on which economic activities are founded are discussed. Furthermore, the course will address various topics of commercial law, such as basic concepts of company law, distribution agreements, etc.

These topics are discussed from a transnational point-of-view. Taking into account the diverse and international background of IBA-students, the idea is to provide you an overview of general principles of (contract) law which are common to civil (continental) as well as Anglo-Saxon legal systems (such as e.g. UK common law); rather than providing a detailed description of two or more national legal systems. As such, awareness will be raised to similarities and differences between legal systems and the reasons behind these differences.

The ultimate goal of this course is to allow students to (i) identify, (ii) recognize, (iii) synthesize and (iv) assess the general, theoretical legal framework behind many commercial contracts and business transactions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At the end of this course, you will be able to:

column2: • identify legal issues relevant to a company;
• evaluate which scenario is most appropriate for a business client / company;
• apply national and international legislation as well as case law to a specific case;
• understand a valid and legally binding contract;
• recognize and predict possible flaws and omissions in a contractual relationship.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Businesses are in dire need of innovative minds who can design and implement high-performance work practices, processes, and strategies. These minds will also help businesses discover opportunities for sustainable social and economic growth.

To achieve these objectives, the minor in Business Management will help you wield knowledge on the fundamental theories and practices in several management fields. The study contents of the minor are related, but not necessarily limited, to decision-making processes of strategic, tactical, and operational nature, and the factors that support those processes.

Students participating in the minor can expect to learn about and perform analysis at individual, team and organizational levels. Key to these analyses and the overall work in the minor is the study of customers and competitors and of how organizations (and their members) can leverage their resources (e.g., human capital, financial, value offering) to respond to the behavior of the latter and achieve high levels of performance.

The minor comprises three modules that cover topics that are critical for the long term development of a business organization,  (i) Organizational Behavior; (ii) Accounting and Financial Management; and (iii) Innovation Management. Overall, the minor answers a basic but foundational question: What are the key insights and best practices in business management?

While strategies, investments, and operations are important for organizational success, an organization cannot excel if attention is not paid to its social capital – the human resources. This module provides an introduction to the study of human behavior in organizations. These behaviors are mainly explained in reference to psychological mechanisms, situational factors, individual differences, and group phenomena that influence the way people interact in the organizational context. The module, therefore, focuses on an individual level of analysis and on a team level of analysis.

This module is specifically designed for students with no background in accounting and finance. Regardless of previous experience, by the end of the module, students would have developed a strong economic intuition.

The module will cover, elaborate on and explore the basic building blocks of (corporate) finance so that students will understand how financial managers make decisions on a day-to-day basis (for example decisions related to liquidity), why and how firms invest in new projects (net present value and other investment decision criteria, capital structure theory) and how the value of a firm is increased (shareholder value maximization). Additionally, the module explores the abstract concept of risk and makes it tangible and measurable by working through and applying the Capital Asset Pricing Model.

In order to achieve this, part of the work, during the module, will focus on significant parts of accounting, with a special emphasis on the core logic and mechanisms of balance sheet, income statement and cash flow statement. This will allow engaging in the analysis of a firm’s most important “health”-parameters (i.e. financial statement analysis: liquidity, profitability, asset management efficiency, capital structure and market value).

The synthesis of all these elements is achieved through case analysis. In addition to bringing together the different theoretical elements in the context of concrete business problems, active participation in case analyses will (1) allow students to enhance their problem-solving and decision-making abilities in various areas of marketing and (2) provide an opportunity to develop, present, and defend their own recommendations, and to examine and discuss the recommendations of others critically.

Innovation Management encompasses everything that firms do in and around the process of turning ideas into new products, new services, new methods, new materials or new business models. This process is typically multidisciplinary in nature in that people from different backgrounds and with various specializations work together (such as psychology, creativity, marketing, technology, strategy, and organizational design). Firms that effectively and efficiently integrate these backgrounds and their respective inputs are likely to be innovative, have a strong competitive advantage, and high survival rates. This module focuses on some of the most important aspects of managing the innovation process, from both a strategic and an operational perspective. In Innovation Management we discuss, amongst others, the adoption of innovations, creativity, idea management, innovation strategy, portfolio management, innovation process management, and innovation networks.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Where theoretical knowledge serves as the foundation of your education as a manager, the ability to effectively and insightfully apply this knowledge is the key to success in most management jobs. Developing the ability to apply and translate theoretical knowledge to real world situations in which taking decisions and implementing them is central is of crucial importance for future managers and is the key aim of this course. Just like pilots learn to fly in a flight simulator, you and your team will learn through a simulation to run a company for the next 9 years (9 decision periods)! You start with a portfolio of existing brands and your ultimate goal is to maximize your stock price index 9 years later, through value creation for your consumers. During these 10 years, you and your team decide which segment(s) to focus on and with which brand(s); how to target each segment and which price to charge. You are responsible for the effective management of a portfolio of brands:  you can reposition existing brands, redevelop them or discontinue them, but you can also introduce and launch new brands and products. Moreover, you get the opportunity to conquer a completely new market and to create value through sustainable choices. Apart from having an in-depth understanding of the strategic aspects of marketing, it is of vital importance that you learn to interpret market research studies accurately. On top of that, just as in real life, your company doesn’t operate in a vacuum but in a competitive environment. Your team competes with five other firms (five other teams) for consumers’ attention within the ‘markstrat world’. Effective and timely anticipation of your competitors’ (re)actions is of crucial importance for successful management of your firm.

In this course, you will deepen your knowledge and understanding of marketing, strategy, finance, product development and leadership. Through active engagement in the simulation, you will develop the skills to translate this knowledge into actionable decisions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• The student will have an in-depth understanding of concepts, theories and instruments important to marketing, and have the skills to apply these effectively in a way that creates value to the consumer. Therewith, the student obtains an understanding of how marketing can be a ‘force for positive change’ to the consumer.
• The student will have the knowledge and skills to appreciate and interpret different market research studies within a team.
• The student has insights in optimal resource allocation strategies and in quantifying returns on marketing investment within a team operating in a competitive landscape
• The student has the skills to anticipate forces and changes in the market and responses from key stakeholders while operating within a team.
• The student has developed leadership skills within the team to together with the skills to match external changes (in the market) with internal changes (in team structure and responsibilities)

• The student has obtained an understanding of different biases that interfere with optimal decision making of themselves and others within their role as a manager, and has the skills to fight these biases (e.g., overconfidence; attentional blindness)

column1: This PhD course is organized by CPO, the Consultation Center for Patient-related Research. CPO is a cross-departmental organization within Erasmus MC with the mission to stimulate and maintain the top position of Erasmus MC in clinical research.
The programme and dates are still yet to be determined.

column1: Erasmus MC Graduate School charges a cancellation fee of €75 for all cancellations made more than 22 days before the start of the course. Fifty percent of the course fee, with a minimum of €75, is due for cancellations made between21 and 10 days before the start date. The full course fee is due for cancellations made less than 10 days before the start date, or in case of no-show without cancellation. For Erasmus MC PhD candidates the full course fee in case of the cancellation policy will be the equivalent of the number of course days times €100. All invoices will be sent to the head of department or for external participants to the e-mail address provided upon registration. Those who register for a PhD course agree with these financial conditions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Het betreft een verdiepend vak, dat met name Europeesrechtelijk van aard is. Naast een aantal principes uit de Europese verdragen en richtlijnen komt de jurisprudentie over de BTW van het Hof van Justitie aan de orde, alsmede de ontwikkelingen op het terrein van de BTW en andere indirecte belastingen in Europa. Het vak vormt een aanvulling op het vak Omzetbelasting dat in de bachelorfase wordt aangeboden.

Voor elk college dienen de studenten twee stellingen te formuleren en vooraf in te leveren, om over de collegestof een mening te vormen. Iedere stelling moet gemotiveerd worden met een tekst van circa 1 A4 (450 woorden).

Tijdens de colleges gaan de docenten nader in op de stellingen en de daarover gevormde meningen van de studenten. Het gemiddelde van de stellingen vormt 50 procent van het eindcijfer. Het schriftelijk tentamen vormt de overige 50 procent van het eindcijfer.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Beter en verdiepend inzicht verwerven in het Europese BTW-systeem in het bijzonder met betrekking tot specifieke en verdiepende deelonderwerpen.
• Het kritisch vermogen ontwikkelen om – zeker bij de deelproblemen – bij grensoverschrijdende transacties zelfstandig de fiscale belemmeringen op te sporen en op te lossen.
• De vaardigheid ontwikkelen om dwarsverbanden te leggen en zelf met een deelonderwerp aan de slag te gaan, bijvoorbeeld voor het schrijven van een masterscriptie.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Het kenmerkende karakter van het vak is dat het een verdiepend vak is. Dat betekent dat een aantal onderdelen die ook in de algemene vakken internationaal belastingrecht en Europees belastingrecht zijn behandeld, hier op een diepgaander niveau aan de orde komen. Daarnaast wordt aandacht besteed aan een aantal specifieke deelterreinen van het internationaal en Europees belastingrecht.
Thema's die de revue passeren zijn onder andere:

Voor elk college dienen de studenten twee stellingen te formuleren en daarover hun mening te vormen. Elke stelling moet gemotiveerd worden met een tekst van circa 300 woorden. Het gemiddelde van de stellingen vormt 50 procent van het eindcijfer. Het schriftelijk tentamen vormt de overige 50 procent van het eindcijfer.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Beter en verdiepend inzicht verwerven in het internationale en Europese belastingrecht, in het bijzonder met betrekking tot specifieke en verdiepende deelonderwerpen.
• Het kritisch vermogen ontwikkelen om – zeker bij de deelproblemen – bij grensoverschrijdende transacties zelfstandig de fiscale belemmeringen op te sporen en op te lossen.
• De vaardigheid ontwikkelen om dwarsverbanden te leggen en zelf met een deelonderwerp aan de slag te gaan, bijvoorbeeld voor het schrijven van een masterscriptie.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Het vak is afgelopen jaar positief geevalueerd. De opzet, inhoud en structuur blijven ongewijzgd. Wel vindt actualisering plaats van de stof hetgeen ook leidt tot een enkele aanpassing in de literatuur.</body>
